title:
Global Newlander-Nirenberg theorem on domains with finite smooth
  boundary in complex manifolds

sections.text:
#### Abstract

Let $M$ be a relatively compact $C^{2}$ domain in a complex manifold $\mathcal{M}$ of dimension $n$. Assume that $H^{1}(M, \Theta)=0$ where $\Theta$ is the sheaf of germs of holomorphic tangent fields of $M$. Suppose that the Levi-form of the boundary of $M$ has at least 3 negative eigenvalues or at least $n-1$ positive eigenvalues pointwise. We first construct a homotopy formula for $\Theta$-valued $(0,1)$-forms on $\bar{M}$. We then apply a Nash-Moser iteration scheme to show that if a formally integrable almost complex structure of the Hölder-Zygmund class $\Lambda^{r}$ on $\bar{M}$ is sufficiently close to the complex structure on $M$ in the Hölder-Zygmund norm $\Lambda^{r_{0}}(\bar{M})$ for some $r_{0}>5 / 2$, then there is a diffeomorphism $F$ from $\bar{M}$ into $\mathcal{M}$ that transforms the almost complex structure into the complex structure on $F(M)$, where $F \in \Lambda^{s}(M)$ for all $s<r+1 / 2$.

# 1. InTRODUCTION 

We consider a complex manifold $\mathcal{M}$ of complex dimension $n>1$. Let $\Theta$ is the sheaf of germs of holomorphic tangent fields of $\mathcal{M}$. Let $M=\{\rho<0\}$ be a relatively compact domain with $C^{2}$ boundary in $\mathcal{M}$. In this paper, we will prove the following.

Theorem 1.1. Let $M$ be a relatively compact domain with $C^{2}$ boundary in $\mathcal{M}$ with $H^{1}(M, \Theta)=0$. Suppose that at each point of $b M$ the Levi form of $\rho$ has $n-1$ positive eigenvalues or at least 3 negative eigenvalues. Fix $r_{0}>5 / 2$. There exists $\delta>0$ satisfying the following: if $A \in C_{(0,1)}^{1}(\bar{M}, \Theta)$ defines a formally integrable (see definition below) almost complex structure $H$ on $\bar{M},\|A\|_{\Lambda^{r_{0}}(M)}<\delta$ and $A \in \Lambda^{r}(M)$ with $r_{0}<r \leq \infty$, then there exists an embedding $F \in \Lambda^{s}(M)$ for all $s<r+1 / 2$ from $\bar{M}$ into $\mathcal{M}$ that transforms $H$ into the complex structure on $F(\bar{M})$.

Here $\Lambda^{r}(M)$ denotes the Hölder-Zygmund space defined in Section 3. See Theorem 8.2 for the full version of Theorem 1.1. The rest of the introduction provides the motivation of the main theorem and related open problems.

Given a complex manifold $\mathcal{M}$, let $T \mathcal{M}$ and $T \mathcal{M} \otimes \mathbb{C}$ denote respectively its real and complex tangent bundles. Assume that $M \Subset \mathcal{M}$ is a relatively compact domain with $C^{2}$ boundary. The complex structure on $\mathcal{M}$ or its restriction on $M$ will be denoted by $H_{\text {st }}$. An almost complex structure on the closure $\bar{M}$ is defined by a complex subbundle $H$ of $T_{\mathbb{C}} \bar{M}:=(T \mathcal{M} \otimes \mathbb{C})|_{\bar{M}}$ such that $T_{\mathbb{C}} \bar{M}=H \oplus \bar{H}$. For each $p \in U_{k} \cap \bar{M}, H_{p}$ has a basis

$$
X_{k, \bar{\alpha}}=\sum_{\beta=1}^{n}\left\{A_{k, \bar{\alpha}}^{\beta}\left(z_{k}\right) \frac{\partial}{\partial z_{k}^{\beta}}+B_{k, \bar{\alpha}}^{\bar{\beta}}\left(z_{k}\right) \frac{\partial}{\partial \bar{z}_{k}^{\beta}}\right\}, \quad \alpha=1, \ldots, n
$$

when $z_{k}=\left(z_{k}^{1}, \ldots, z_{k}^{n}\right)$ are holomorphic coordinates on $U_{k} \subset \mathcal{M}$ with $\bar{M} \subset \cup U_{k}$. The almost complex structure will also be denoted by $H$. We always assume that $H$ has finite distance from the standard complex structure on $\bar{M}$, i.e. $\left(B_{k, \bar{\alpha}}^{\bar{\beta}}\right)_{1 \leq \alpha, \beta \leq n}$ are invertible. By changing bases, we take $\left(B_{k, \bar{\alpha}}^{\bar{\beta}}\right)$ as the identity matrix. This determines $A_{k, \bar{\alpha}}^{\beta}$ uniquely and $A:=\sum_{\alpha, \beta} A_{k, \bar{\alpha}}^{\beta}\left(z_{k}\right) d \bar{z}_{k}^{\alpha} \otimes \partial / \partial z_{k}^{\beta}$ is a global section of $\Theta$-valued $(0,1)$ form on $\bar{M} . H$ is formally integrable if it is closed under the Lie bracket $[H, H] \subset H$, or equivalently, if $\bar{\partial} A=-\frac{1}{2}[A, A]$ (see Section 3 for details).

We say that the almost complex structure $H$ is locally integrable on the interior of $M$ if for each $p \in M$, there exist a neighborhood $U$ of $p$ in $M$ and a diffeomorphism

$F$ from $U$ into $\mathcal{M}$ such that $F_{*}(H)=H_{s t}$, i.e. $F_{*} X_{k, \bar{\pi}}$ are in the span of $\left\{\frac{\partial}{\partial z_{k}^{n}} ; 1 \leq\right.$ $\beta \leq n\}$. Assuming the existence of $F$, since $\operatorname{span}\left\{\overline{\mathbb{P}_{k}^{n}}\right\}$ is closed under the Lie bracket, we know that $H$ is closed under the Lie bracket. In other words, if $H$ is locally integrable on $M$ then it is formally integrable on $M$.

The celebrated Newlander-Nirenberg theorem [45] states that the converse is true locally. Namely, at each interior point $p$ of $M$, if $H$ is formally integrable near $p$, then there exists a neighborhood $U_{p}$ of $p$ in $M$ on which $H$ is integrable. In this case, we refer the corresponding diffeomorphism $F$ from $U_{p} \Subset M$ into $\mathcal{M}$ as a local embedding for $H$. This classical theorem now has several proofs due to Kohn [26], Malgrange [39] and Webster [58]. See Yao [61] for counter-examples on sharpness of the coordinate maps. The reader is also referred to the optimal regularity results in Street [57] on the elliptic structures in general.

The global analogue of the above result, known as the global Newlander-Nirenberg problem, can be stated as follows. Suppose the almost complex structure $H$ is formally integrable on $\bar{M}$ and is sufficiently close to the complex structure on $\mathcal{M}$, is $H$ integrable on $\bar{M}$ ? i.e. does there exist a global embedding $F$ for $H: \bar{M} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}$ ? Here by "sufficiently close" we mean that the $A$ given above is small in certain norms. A similar local boundary version of the Newlander-Nirenberg problem asks whether a formally integrable $H$ admits an embedding near boundary point of the domain $M$.

It turns out that certain geometric assumption on the boundary is needed for the global or boundary Newlander-Nirenberg theorem to hold. We now describe this phenomena. Following Hörmander [25], we say that the domain $M$ (or its boundary $b M$ ) satisfies the condition $a_{q}$, if $M=\{\rho(p)<0: p \in \mathcal{M}\}$ has a $C^{2}$ definition function $\rho$, and the Levi-form of $\rho$ at each boundary point $p \in U_{k} \cap b M$, defined by $L_{p}(\rho, t)=\sum_{\alpha, \beta=1}^{n} \frac{\partial^{2} p}{\partial z_{k}^{n} \partial \bar{z}_{k}^{n}}(p) t^{\alpha} \overleftrightarrow{t^{\beta}}$, has at least $n-q$ positive or $q+1$ negative eigenvalues on $T_{p}^{(1,0)}(b M):=\left\{\sum_{\alpha} t^{\alpha} \frac{\partial}{\partial z_{k}^{n}} \left\lvert\,{ }_{p}: \sum_{\alpha} t^{\alpha} \frac{\partial \rho}{\partial z_{k}^{n}}(p)=0\right.\right\}$. In [24], Hill showed that if the Levi form on the boundary of the domain has exactly 1 negative eigenvalue, then there are many formally integrable smooth almost complex structures for which local embedding for the structures fails to exist at each boundary point.

We now describe positive results. In pioneering work [18-20], Hamilton proved the existence of a $C^{\infty}$ global embedding for $H$ on $\bar{M}$ when both $H, b M$ are $C^{\infty}$ and $M$ is $a_{1}$. Hamilton's result has to assume that the perturbation $A$ is small in some norm $\|\cdot\|_{\Lambda^{\prime \circ}}$ with unspecified (large) $r_{0}$. Catlin [3] and Hanges-Jacobowitz [21] solved a local version of Newlander-Nirenberg problem near boundary points of a strong pseudoconvex domain. It is worth emphasizing that all these results are only for $C^{\infty}$ category for the structures and the boundary of the domains, and the proofs are based on $\bar{\partial}$-Neumann type methods.

When the domain is strongly pseudoconvex in $\mathbb{C}^{n}$, Gan and the first-named author [11] showed the existence of global solutions that have a loss of derivatives with respect to the finite smoothness of the given almost complex structure. This result has been improved significantly in the very recent work of the second-named author [52].

Therefore, Theorem 1.1 proves the existence of solution for the global NewlanderNirenberg problem on $a_{1}^{+}$domains (i.e. the ones satisfying $a_{1}, a_{2}$ conditions) with the almost $1 / 2$ regularity gain.

To prove Theorem 1.1, we will employ the homotopy formula methods together with a modified Nash-Moser type iteration. The idea is to find a sequence of embedding $F^{j}: M_{j} \rightarrow M_{j+1}$, with $M_{0}=M$, so that the the error $A^{j}$ converges to 0 . We then show that the maps $\widetilde{F}_{j}:=F^{j} \circ F^{j-1} \circ \cdots \circ F^{0}$ converge to the embedding $F$ which is the solution.

These techniques were originally employed by Webster [58-60] to investigate the classical Newlander-Nirenberg theorem, the CR vector bundle problem, and the more challenging local CR embedding problem. These techniques, together with a more precise interior regularity estimate for Henkin's integral solution operators of $\bar{\partial}_{b}$ on strong pseudoconvex real hypersurfaces, were successfully used by GongWebster [15-17] to obtain a sharp version of CR vector bundle problem and the local CR embedding problem; see [12] also for a parameter version of FrobeniusNirenberg theorem by using similar techniques. The scheme of the proof of Theorem 1.1 is similar to the ones in Gan-Gong [12] and Shi [52]. However, we mention an important new feature in the present work. Here we must deal with the failure of local homotopy formula for $a_{1}$ domains near the concave side of the boundary. Noticeably, the lack of homotopy formulas with good estimates was shown by Nagel-Rosay [44] in the situation for local CR embedding problem in dimension 5. In our setting, it was proved by Laurent-Thiébaut and Leiterer [35, Prop. 0.7] that there is no local homotopy formula with good estimates for $(0, q)$ forms near a boundary point of the concave side of some $a_{q}$ domain.

For the proof Theorem 1.1, we construct a global homotopy formula on $a_{1}^{+}$ domains. Let us introduce notations. Note that for an $a_{q}$ domain $M, b M$ is the disjoint union of $b_{n-q}^{+} M$ and $b_{q+1}^{-} M$, where $b_{n-q}^{+} M$ (resp. $b_{q+1}^{-} M$ ) is the union of the components of $b M$ on which $L_{\zeta}(\rho, t)$ has at least $(n-q)$ positive (resp. $(q+1)$ negative) eigenvalues at each $\zeta \in b_{n-q}^{+} M$ (resp. $b_{q+1}^{-} M$ ). Define

$$
|\rho|_{a}^{*}:=\max \left\{|\rho|_{C^{2}(\mathcal{M})},\|\rho\|_{\Lambda^{n}(\mathcal{N})}\right\}
$$

for a fixed neighborhood $\mathcal{N}$ of $b_{q+1}^{-} M$ in $\mathcal{M}$. We say that $M$ is an $a_{q}^{+}$domain if it satisfies conditions $a_{q}$ and $a_{q+1}$.

Theorem 1.2. Suppose that $M$ defined by a $C^{2}$ function $\rho$ in $\mathcal{M}$ satisfies condition $a_{q}^{+}$with $q>0$. Let $V$ be a holomorphic vector bundle on $\mathcal{M}$. Assume that $H^{q}(D, \mathcal{O}(V))$ vanishes. Let $r>0, \varepsilon>0$ and $0 \leq \delta \leq 1 / 2$. Then

$$
\varphi=\bar{\partial} R_{q} \varphi+R_{q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi
$$

where $\varphi$ is a $V$-valued $(0, q)$ form with $\varphi, \bar{\partial} \varphi \in \Lambda^{r}(M)$. Furthermore, for $j=q, q+1$,

$$
\left\|R_{j} f\right\|_{\Lambda^{r+\delta}(M)} \leq C_{r, \delta, \varepsilon}\left(|\rho|_{r+2+\delta}^{*}|\rho|_{2+\varepsilon}^{b}\|f\|_{\Lambda^{r}(M)}+\|f\|_{\Lambda^{r}(M)}\right)
$$

Here the positive constants $b, C_{r, \delta, \varepsilon}$ depend on $\nabla \rho, \nabla^{2} \rho$ and are stable under small perturbation of $\rho$ as defined in Section 3.

Theorem 1.2 on homotopy formulas for $a_{q}^{+}$domains in a complex manifold is interesting in its own right. We briefly mention a few related results. The construction of $\bar{\partial}$ solution operators for strongly pseudoconvex domains in $\mathbb{C}^{n}$ has a long history. Almost $1 / 2$ gain for $\bar{\partial}$ solutions was obtained by Kerzman [28] and the exact $1 / 2$ gain estimate was obtained by Henkin-Ramanov [23]. For higher order derivative estimate with exact $1 / 2$ gain on Hölder spaces, $\bar{\partial}$ solution operators were constructed by Siu [55] for $(0,1)$ forms and by Lieb-Range [37] for $(0, q)$ forms for $q \geq 1$ when the boundaries of the strongly pseudoconvex domains are

sufficiently smooth. For a homotopy formula on strongly pseudoconvex domains in $\mathbb{C}^{n}$ with $C^{2}$ boundary, Gong [12] obtained the $1 / 2$ gain for Hölder-Zygmund spaces and Shi [52] obtained an almost $1 / 2$ gain for $L^{p}$ Sobolev spaces. In this paper we will use Rychkov extension introduced to the study of $\bar{\partial}$-problem by Shi-Yao [54]. We also mention that integral formulas and canonical solutions (with minimum $L^{2}$ norms) also play important roles in the study of Kerzman's problem [28] on super-normal estimates for polydiscs and more general product domains; a problem was solved recently by Li [36] and Yuan [63] independently. The interested reader should consult $[7,12,36,53,63]$ and references therein.

It is worthy to give an example for which Theorem 1.1 applies. Using a vanishing theorem on harmonic forms of Shaw [50, Thm. 2.2], we can prove the following global Newlander-Nirenberg theorem on a shell domain.

Corollary 1.3. Let $D=D_{2} \backslash \bar{D}_{1}$, where $D_{1}, D_{2}$ are two bounded strongly pseudoconvex domains with $C^{2}$ boundary in $\mathbb{C}^{n}, \overline{D_{1}} \subset D_{2}$, and $n \geq 4$. Assume that $r_{0}>5 / 2$. There exists $\delta>0$ satisfying the following: if $r_{0} \leq r<\infty$ and $A \in \Lambda_{(0,1)}^{\mathrm{r}}(D, \Theta)$ satisfies $\bar{\partial} A=-\frac{1}{2}[A, A]$ and $\|A\|_{\Lambda^{r_{0}}(D)}<\delta$, then the almost complex structure on $D$ defined by $A$ can be transformed into the standard complex structure on $F(D)$ via an embedding $F \in \Lambda^{s}(D)$ from $\bar{D}$ into $\mathbb{C}^{n}$ for all $s<r+1 / 2$.

We conclude the introduction with the following open problems.
Problem 1.4. In Theorem 1.2, replace $a_{q}^{+}$condition by $a_{q}$ condition on $M$ with $C^{2}$ boundary. Determine if there is a homotopy formula $f=\bar{\partial} A_{q} f+A_{q+1} \bar{\partial} f$ satisfying

$$
\left\|A_{j} g\right\|_{\Lambda^{r+1 / 2}(M)} \leq C_{r}\|g\|_{\Lambda^{r}(M)}, \quad j=q, q+1, \forall r>0
$$

Problem 1.5. Under conditions of Theorem 1.1, determine if there is a solution $F \in \Lambda^{r+1 / 2}(M)$ when $A \in \Lambda^{r}(M)$.

One would expect that a solution to the last question would have applications. For instance, it might be helpful to settle the sharp regularity result left open in the local CR embedding problem $[17,38,60]$ for dimension 7 or higher.

# 2. OUTLINE OF THE PAPER 

Section 3 contains some elementary facts about the Hölder-Zygmund spaces $\Lambda^{r}$. We construct a Moser type smoothing operator $S^{t}: C^{0}(\bar{D}) \rightarrow C^{\infty}\left(\mathcal{N}_{t}(D)\right)$, where $D$ is a bounded Lipschitz domain. The important new feature here is that $S^{t} f$ is defined on a neighborhood $\mathcal{N}_{t}(D)$ of $D$. This fact is needed to estimate each iterating embedding $F^{j}$, which is defined as the time-1 flow of the vector fields $-S^{t_{j}} P^{j} A^{j}$ for a sequence of $A^{j}$ on $M_{j}$ for Sections 7 and 8.

In Section 4, we derive estimates for the time-1 flow of a vector field. The main estimate is (4.5), where we estimate the $\bar{\partial}$ of the flow in terms of the $\bar{\partial}$ of the vector fields. We also prove the crucial estimate (3.8) for the commutator $\left[\nabla, S^{t}\right]=\nabla S^{t}-S^{t} \nabla$, which is the key to obtaining optimal convergence in the Nash-Moser iteration. All results in Sections 3 and 4 can be applied in general situations beyond the scope of this paper.

In Section 5, we improve the local homotopy formulas constructed in [14] for $a_{q}^{+}$ domains by using an estimate on the commutator $[\mathcal{E}, \bar{\partial}]$ for the Rychkov extension operator due to Shi-Yao $[53,54]$ on spaces $\Lambda^{r}(M)$ when $0<r \leq 1$.

Section 6 contains proof of Theorem 1.2, i.e., the construction of a global homotopy formula on $a_{q}^{+}$domains. First, we use the Grauert bumping method and the local homotopy formulas to construct an approximate global homotopy formula on some bigger $C^{\infty}$ domain $\widetilde{M}$ that is a small $C^{2}$ perturbation of $M$, with $M \Subset \widetilde{M}$ and

$$
\varphi=\bar{\partial} T_{q} \varphi+T_{q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi+K_{q} \varphi, \quad \text { on } \widetilde{M}
$$

Here $K_{q} \varphi$ is a $(0, q)$ form with $C^{\infty}(\widetilde{M})$ coefficients (See Proposition 6.7.) We can then apply the $\bar{\partial}$-Neumann formula $I=\square_{q} N_{q}+H_{q}^{0}$ to $K_{q} \varphi$ on $\widetilde{M}$ to get

$$
K_{q} \varphi=\bar{\partial}_{q-1} \bar{\partial}_{q-1}^{*} N_{q} K_{q} \varphi+\bar{\partial}_{q}^{*} \bar{\partial}_{q} N_{q} K_{q} \varphi+H_{q}^{0} K_{q} \varphi
$$

The operator $H_{q}^{0}$ maps $L_{(0, q)}^{2}(\widetilde{M}, V)$ to the space of harmonic forms $\mathcal{H}_{(0, q)}(\widetilde{M}, V)$.
A well-known result of Hörmander states that the condition $H^{q}(M, \mathcal{O}(V))=0$ is stable under small perturbations of an $a_{q}$ domain and thus hold for $M$ replaced by $\widetilde{M}$. Using this fact we can prove that $\mathcal{H}_{(0, q)}(\widetilde{M}, V)=0$ and thus $H_{q}^{0} K_{q} \varphi=0$. See Theorem 6.10 for a general statement allowing non-vanishing of $H^{q}(M, \mathcal{O}(V))$.

Now $\widetilde{M}$ is still an $a_{q}^{+}$domain since it is a small perturbation of $M$, and the $a_{q}^{+}$ condition allows us to commute $\bar{\partial}_{q}$ with $N_{q}: \bar{\partial}_{q} N_{q}=N_{q+1} \bar{\partial}_{q}$, thus the second term on the right-hand side of (2.2) becomes $\bar{\partial}_{q}^{*} N_{q+1} \bar{\partial}_{q} K_{q} \varphi$. Combining all these facts in (6.5) and (2.2) we obtained (Theorem 1.2) a global homotopy formula on $M$ :

$$
\varphi=\bar{\partial} R_{q} \varphi+R_{q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi
$$

where $R_{q} \varphi:=T_{q}+\bar{\partial} \partial^{*} N_{q} K_{q} \varphi$ and $R_{q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi:=T_{q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi+\bar{\partial}^{*} N_{q+1} \bar{\partial} K_{q} \varphi$. We remark that $\bar{\partial} K_{q} \varphi$ depends only on $\bar{\partial} \varphi$ and not on $\varphi$. This important fact follows from the Grauert-bumping procedure (Propoitions 6.4 and 6.6).

Section 7 contains the main step in a Nash-Moser iteration for the proof of Theorem 1.1. We will finish the proof of the theorem in Section 8. The proof of Theorem 1.1 is more subtle when $M$ is not strongly pseudoconvex since Theorem 1.2 requires many derivatives for $b M$. We will solve this difficulty by combining the Hartogs's extension and the Nash-Moser iteration scheme.

# 3. Preliminaries 

In this section, we first recall elementary properties of Hölder norms $\|\cdot\|_{C^{\alpha}(M)}$ with $0 \leq a<\infty$ and Hölder-Zygmund norms $\|\cdot\|_{\Lambda^{\alpha}(M)}$ with $0<a<\infty$ where $M$ is a Lipschitz domain. For abbreviation, we also write $\|\cdot\|_{C^{\alpha}(M)}$ as $\|\cdot\|_{M, a}$ and $\|\cdot\|_{\Lambda^{\alpha}(M)}$ as $\left|\cdot\right|_{M, a}$. We then describe some properties of the Nash-Moser smoothing operator.

A domain $D \Subset \mathbb{R}^{d}$ is called a Lipschitz domain, if there is a finite open covering $\left\{V_{i}\right\}_{i=1}^{N}$ of $\bar{D}$ such that $V_{i}$ is relatively compact in $D$ or $V_{i} \cap D$ is given by $1>$ $y_{d}>h_{i}\left(y^{\prime}\right)$ where $\left(y^{\prime}, y_{d}\right)$ is a permutation of the standard coordinates of $\mathbb{R}^{d}$ and $h_{i}$ is a Lipschitz function on some ball $V_{i}^{\prime}$. We say that a constant $C(D)$ is stable under perturbations of $D$ if $C(D)$ depends only on upper bounds of $N$ and Lipschitz norms of $h_{1}, \ldots, h_{N}$.

A constant $C(\tilde{\rho})$, depending on functions $\tilde{\rho}$, is stable under smaller perturbations of a $C^{2}$ function $\rho$ if $C(\tilde{\rho})$ can be chosen independent of $\tilde{\rho}$ provided $\|\tilde{\rho}-\rho\|_{C^{2}}<\delta$ for some $\delta$ depends only on $\rho$. Such a constant will be denoted by $C\left(\nabla \rho, \nabla^{2} \rho\right)$.

3.1. Notations. Let $\mathbb{N}$ be the set of non-negative integers. Throughout the paper we assume the following.
(i) $M$ is a relatively bounded domain in a complex manifold $\mathcal{M}$ and $b M$ is at least $C^{2}$.
(ii) The almost complex structures $H$ on $\bar{M}$ have finite distance from the standard complex structure on $\bar{M}$ and $H \in C^{1}(\bar{M})$.
(iii) If $g$ is a $C^{1}$ mapping from $V \subset \mathbb{C}^{n}$ to $\mathbb{C}^{n}$, we define Jacobean matrices

$$
g_{z}:=\left(\frac{\partial g^{\alpha}(z)}{\partial z^{\beta}}\right)_{1 \leq \alpha, \beta \leq n}, \quad g_{\bar{z}}:=\left(\frac{\partial g^{\alpha}(z)}{\partial \bar{z}^{\beta}}\right)_{1 \leq \alpha, \beta \leq n}, \quad g_{(z, \bar{z})}=\left(g_{z}, g_{\bar{z}}\right)
$$

3.2. Covering of coordinate charts for domains and norms. We will fix a finite open covering $\left\{U_{1}, \ldots, U_{k_{\ell}}\right\}$ of a neighborhood of $\bar{M}$. We may assume $\mathcal{M}=\cup U_{j}$. For each $k$, we assume
(i) there is a holomorphic coordinate map $\psi_{k}$ from $U_{k}$ onto $\hat{U}_{k} \Subset \mathbb{C}^{n}$, and $\psi_{k}$ is biholomorphic on an open set $\hat{U}_{k}$ containing $\overline{U_{k}}$;
(ii) $M_{k}:=U_{k} \cap M \neq \emptyset, \overline{U_{k}} \subset M$ if $\overline{U_{k}} \cap b M \neq \emptyset$, and $D_{k}:=\psi_{k}\left(U_{k} \cap M\right)$ are Lipschitz domains;
(iii) there is a partition of unity $\left\{\chi_{k}\right\}$ such that $\operatorname{supp} \chi_{k} \Subset U_{k}, \chi_{k}^{1 / 2} \in C^{\infty}(\mathcal{M})$, and $\sum \chi_{k}=1$ on a neighborhood $\mathcal{U}$ of $\bar{M}$, and set $\hat{\chi}_{j}=\chi_{j} \circ \psi_{j}^{-1}$;
(iv) for a subset $A$ of $E=\mathbb{R}^{d}$ or $\mathbb{C}^{n}$, we use $\mathcal{N}_{\delta}(A):=\left\{x \in E: \operatorname{dist}_{A}(x)<\delta\right\}$ and $\operatorname{dist}_{A}$ is the distance from $A$.
We will write $z_{k}=x_{k}+i y_{k}=\psi_{k}=\left(z_{k}^{1}, \ldots, z_{k}^{n}\right)$ as local holomorphic coordinates on $U_{k}$. We will write $\nabla^{\ell}$ as the set of partial derivatives of order $\ell$ in local real coordinates. When $M^{\prime}$ is a small $C^{2}$ perturbation of $M$, the above conditions are still satisfied for $M^{\prime}$, without changing $\psi_{k}, U_{k}, \chi_{k}, \mathcal{U}$.

We now use the local charts to define norms.
Let $r=k+\beta$ with $k \in \mathbb{N}$ and $0<\beta \leq 1$. Let $D$ be a bounded Lipschitz domain in $\mathbb{R}^{d}$. Let $\|u\|_{C^{r}(\bar{D})}$ denote the standard Hölder norm for a function $u \in C^{r}(\bar{D})$. The Hölder-Zygmund space $\Lambda^{\beta}(D)$ is the set of functions $u \in C^{0}(\bar{D})$ such that

$$
\|u\|_{\Lambda^{\beta}(D)}:=\sup _{x \in D}|u(x)|+\sup _{x, x+h, x+2 h \in D, h \neq 0}|h|^{-\beta}\left|\Delta_{h}^{2} u(x)\right|<\infty
$$

Here $\Delta_{h} u(x)=u(x+h)-u(x)$ and $\Delta_{h}^{2} u(x)=u(x+h)+u(x+2 h)-2 u(x+h)$. When $r=k+\beta$ with $k \in \mathbb{N}$ and $0<\beta \leq 1$, define $\|u\|_{\Lambda^{r}(D)}=\|u\|_{C^{k}(D)}+\left\|\partial^{k} u\right\|_{\Lambda^{\beta}(D)}$.

We also write $\|\cdot\|_{C^{a}(D)}$ as $\|\cdot\|_{D, a}$ and $\|\cdot\|_{\Lambda^{a}(D)}$ as $\left|\cdot\right|_{D, a}$.
For discussions on various equivalent forms of the norm $\left|\cdot\right|_{D, r}$ on bounded Lipschitz domains $D$, see [14, sect. 5]. For instance, a theorem in [1, Thm. 18.5, p. 63] says that $u \in \Lambda^{k+\beta}(D)$ if and only if

$$
\sup _{x \in D}|u(x)|+\sup _{x, x+h, \ldots, x+(k+2) h \in D, h \neq 0}|h|^{-k-\beta}\left|\Delta_{h}^{k+2} u(x)\right|<\infty
$$

Further, the latter and $|u|_{D, k+\beta}$ are equivalent norms.
For $r \in[0, \infty)$, we say that an $L^{2}$ function $f$ on $\mathbb{R}^{d}$ belongs to $H^{r}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ if

$$
\|f\|_{H^{r}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)}^{2}:=\int_{\xi \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left(1+|\xi|^{2}\right)^{r}|\hat{f}(\xi)|^{2} d \xi<\infty
$$

If $D$ is a bounded domain with Lipschitz boundary in $\mathbb{R}^{d}$, let $H^{r}(D)$ be the set of functions $f \in L^{2}(D)$ such that

$$
\|f\|_{H^{r}(D)}:=\inf _{\left.\tilde{f}\right|_{D}=f}\|\tilde{f}\|_{H^{r}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)}<\infty
$$

Assume that $V$ is a holomorphic vector bundle on $\mathcal{M}$. We fix the coordinate charts so that $V$ over $U_{k}$ admits a holomorphic basis $\left\{e_{k, 1}, \ldots, e_{k, m}\right\}$. For the holomorphic tangent bundle $\Theta$ of $\mathcal{M}$, we always use $\frac{\partial}{\partial z_{k}^{l}}, \ldots, \frac{\partial}{\partial z_{k}^{r}}$ as its basis on $U_{k}$.

Definition 3.1. When $u$ is a function on $\bar{M}$, define $u_{k}=u \circ \psi_{k}^{-1}$ and

$$
|u|_{M, r}:=\|u\|_{\Lambda^{r}(M)}:=\max _{k}\left|u_{k}\right|_{D_{k}, r}, \quad\|u\|_{H^{r}(M)}:=\max _{k}\left\|u_{k}\right\|_{H^{r}\left(D_{k}\right)}
$$

Let $\varphi$ be a section $V$-valued $(0, q)$ forms on $\bar{M}$ where $q=0,1, \ldots, n$. Write $\left.\varphi\right|_{U_{k}}=$ $\sum_{j=1}^{m} \sum_{|I|=q} \varphi_{k, I}^{j}\left(z_{k}\right)\left(d \bar{z}_{k}\right)^{I} \otimes e_{k, j}\left(z_{k}\right)$. Set

$$
|\varphi|_{M, r}:=\|\varphi\|_{\Lambda^{r}(M)}:=\max _{k, I, j}\left|\varphi_{k, I}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}, r}
$$

To apply the Nash-Moser iteration, we need to consider domains $\widetilde{M}$ that vary in $\mathcal{M}$. However, these domains will be small $C^{2}$ perturbations of $M$. Thus, we can use the same coordinate charts $\left\{U, \psi_{k}\right\}$ to define the norms $\left|\cdot\right|_{\widetilde{M}, r}$. We will also need to define norms of a diffeomorphism $F$ from $M$ onto its image that is a small perturbation of the identity mapping $\operatorname{id}_{M}$. Thus, we can define the following.

Definition 3.2. Let $M, \widetilde{M}$ be domains in $\mathcal{M}$. Let $F: M \rightarrow \widetilde{M}$ be a diffeomorphism. Set

$$
F_{k}\left(z_{k}\right):=\psi_{k} F \psi_{k}^{-1}\left(z_{k}\right)=z_{k}+f_{k}\left(z_{k}\right)
$$

where $f_{k}$ are sufficiently small. Define $|F-\left.\mathrm{id}\right|_{M, r}=\max _{k}\left|f_{k}\right|_{D_{k}, r}$.
3.3. Convexity of norms and stability of constants. For bounded Lipschitz domains, the following Hölder estimates for interpolation, product rule and chain rule are well-known.

Proposition 3.3. Let $M, \widetilde{M}$ be Lipschitz domains in $\mathcal{M}$. Let $\varepsilon>0$. Then for $a>0$ and functions $u, v$ on $M$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& |u v|_{M, a} \leq C_{a}\left(|u|_{M, a}\|v\|_{M, 0}+\|u\|_{M, 0}|v|_{M, a}\right) \\
& \left|\frac{1}{u}\right|_{M, a} \leq C_{a, \varepsilon}\left(1+\left|u^{-1}\right|_{M, \varepsilon}\right)^{a+2}\left(1+|u|_{M, \varepsilon}^{a+1}\right)|u|_{M, a}
\end{aligned}
$$

Suppose that $g$ maps $M$ into $\widetilde{M}$ and $\|g-\mathrm{id}\|_{M ; 1}<C(M)^{-1}$. Then for $a>1$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \|u \circ g\|_{M, 1} \leq C_{\varepsilon}\|u\|_{\widetilde{M}, 1}\left(1+|g|_{M, 1+\varepsilon}\right) \\
& |u \circ g|_{M, a} \leq C_{a, \varepsilon}\left(|u|_{\widetilde{M}, a}\left(1+|g|_{M, 1+\varepsilon}^{2}\right)+|u|_{\widetilde{M}, 1+\varepsilon}|g|_{M, a}+\|u\|_{\widetilde{M}, 0}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Here, $C_{a}, C_{a, \varepsilon}, C_{\varepsilon}$ are stable under a small $C^{1}$ perturbation of $M$. The estimates hold for $\varepsilon=0$ if all norms are replaced by the corresponding $\|\cdot\|$ norms.

Proof. The case $\mathcal{M}=\mathbb{C}^{n}$ is proved in [15]. The general case is reduced to local coordinate charts via Definition 3.2.

Lemma 3.4. Let $\left\{M^{\ell}\right\}_{\ell=0}^{\infty}$ be a sequence of Lipschitz domains in $\mathcal{M}$. Assume $F^{\ell}$ maps $M^{\ell}$ into $M^{\ell+1}$ and all $M^{\ell}$ are small perturbations of $M^{0}$. Suppose that $\left\|F^{\ell}-i d\right\|_{M^{\ell}, 1}<\frac{1}{C\left(M^{0}\right) \ell^{2}}$ for all $\ell \geq 0$. Then for $\varepsilon>0, r>1$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|u \circ F^{m-1} \circ \cdots \circ F^{0}\right|_{M^{0}, r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}^{m+1}\left\{|u|_{M^{m}, r}+\sum_{i}|u|_{M^{m}, 1+\varepsilon}|f^{i}\right|_{M^{i}, r} \\
& \left.+|u|_{M^{m}, r}|f^{i}\right|_{M^{i}, 1+\varepsilon} ^{2}\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

The estimates hold for $\varepsilon=0$ and $r \geq 0$ if all norms are replaced by the corresponding $\|\cdot\|$ norms.

Proof. When $\mathcal{M}$ is $\mathbb{C}^{n}$, the lemma is in [15]. In general case, we need to use Definition 3.2. Thus, we write

$$
u \circ F^{m} \circ \cdots \circ F^{0} \circ \psi_{k}^{-1}=\tilde{u} \circ \tilde{F}^{m} \circ \cdots \circ \tilde{F}^{0}
$$

with $\tilde{F}_{k}^{j}=\psi_{k} \circ F^{j} \circ \psi_{k}^{-1}$ and $\tilde{u}_{k}=u \circ \psi_{k}^{-1}$. Then the estimate follows from the definition and the lemma for $\mathcal{M}=\mathbb{C}^{n}$.
3.4. Smoothing operators. We now modify the smoothing operator in Moser [43] as follows.

Lemma 3.5. Fix an integer $m_{*} \geq 0$. Let $\omega$ be an open set in $\mathbb{R}^{d}$. There is a smooth function $\mu$ on $\mathbb{R}^{d}$ with compact support in $\omega$ such that $\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}} x^{I} \mu(x) d x=0$ for $I \in \mathbb{N}^{d}$ with $0<|I| \leq m_{*}$ and $\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}} \mu(x) d x=1$.

Proof. Consider $d=1$. Given an interval $(a, a+\varepsilon)$. Let us find smooth functions $\chi_{0}, \ldots, \chi_{m_{*}}$ with compact support in $(a, a+\varepsilon)$ such that

$$
\int_{\mathbb{R}} \sum_{j} c_{j} \chi_{j}(t) d t=1, \quad \int_{\mathbb{R}} \sum_{j} c_{j} \chi_{j}(t) t^{i} d t=0, \quad i=1, \ldots, m_{*}
$$

It suffices to find $\chi_{0}, \ldots, \chi_{m_{*}}$ such that

$$
A_{m_{*}}:=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
\int_{\mathbb{R}} \chi_{0}(t) d t & \cdots & \int_{\mathbb{R}} \chi_{m_{*}}(t) d t \\
\vdots & \cdots & \vdots \\
\int_{\mathbb{R}} t^{m_{*}} \chi_{0}(t) d t & \cdots & \int_{\mathbb{R}} t^{m_{*}} \chi_{m_{*}}(t) d t
\end{array}\right)
$$

is non-singular.
The case $m_{*}=0$ is trivial. Suppose we have found $\chi_{0}, \ldots, \chi_{m_{*}-1}$ so that $A_{m_{*}-1}$ is non-singular. By row reduction, we find a matrix $B_{m_{*}}$ such that $B_{m_{*}} A_{m_{*}}=$ $\left(c_{i j}\right)_{0 \leq i, j \leq m_{*}}$ is an upper triangular matrix with all diagonal entries being non-zero except for possible the last one:

$$
c_{m_{*} m_{*}}=\int_{\mathbb{R}} \chi_{m_{*}}(t) p(t) d t, \quad p(t)=t^{m_{*}}-b_{0}-\cdots-b_{m_{*}-1} t^{m_{*}-1}
$$

where $b_{i}$ depend only on $\int_{\mathbb{R}} t^{i} \chi_{j}(t) d t$ for $i=0, \ldots, m_{*}$ and $j<m_{*}$. Since $p$ is not identically zero on $(a, a+\varepsilon)$, we can find a desired $\chi_{m_{*}}$. Now $\mu(t)=\sum_{j} c_{j} \chi_{j}(t)$ satisfies the condition when $d=1$.

For $d>1$, we can take $\mu(x)=\mu_{1}\left(x_{1}\right) \cdots \mu_{d}\left(x_{d}\right)$ for suitable $\mu_{1}, \ldots, \mu_{d}$.
We now prove additional properties for the Moser smooth operator. A useful feature of the smoothing operator is that it extends functions form $D$ to a fixed and slightly larger domain.

Lemma 3.6. Fix a positive integer $m_{*}$. Let $D \Subset \mathbb{R}^{d}$ be a Lipschitz domain. There exist operators

$$
S^{t}: C^{0}(\bar{D}) \rightarrow C^{\infty}\left(\mathcal{N}_{t}(D)\right), \quad t \in(0,1]
$$

such that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|S^{t} u\right|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(D), r} \leq C_{r, s} t^{s-r}|u|_{D, s}, \quad 0<s \leq r<\infty \\
& \left|\left(I-S^{t}\right) E u\right|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(D), s} \leq C_{r, s} t^{r-s}|u|_{D, r}, \quad 0<s \leq r+m_{*}
\end{aligned}
$$

Here the constants $C_{r, s}$ depend only on $r, s, m_{*}$ and the Lipschitz norm of $D$. Further, when $u \in \Lambda^{r}(D)$ with $0<r \leq 1$, the $\left[\nabla, S^{t}\right] u$ is defined by

$$
\left[\nabla, S^{t}\right] u=\lim _{z \rightarrow 0^{+}}\left[\nabla, S^{t}\right] S^{c} u
$$

The same estimates hold for the Hölder norms including $r=0$.
Proof. We will use a similar construction in [52]. We cover $\bar{D}$ by finitely many open balls $B_{j}$ where $\left\{B_{j}\right\}$ is a stable covering for a small perturbation on $D$, namely $B_{j} \Subset D$ if $B_{j} \cap \partial D \neq \emptyset$. Let $\left\{\chi_{j}\right\}$ be a partition of unity subordinate to $\left\{B_{j}\right\}$. Thus, $\sum \chi_{j}=1$ on $\mathcal{U}$ where $\mathcal{U}$ is a fixed neighborhood of $\bar{D}$.

Let $E: C^{0}(\bar{D}) \rightarrow C_{0}^{0}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ be the Stein extension operator [56]. Note that $E$ is linear and

$$
|E f|_{\mathbb{R}^{d}, a} \leq C_{a}(D)|f|_{D, a}, a>0 ; \quad\|E f\|_{\mathbb{R}^{d}, a} \leq C_{a}(D)\|f\|_{D, a}, a \geq 0
$$

Let $f_{j}=\chi_{j} f$, which is well-defined on $\bar{D}$. Note that $f_{j}$ vanishes on $\mathcal{N}_{c_{1}}\left(\bar{D} \backslash B_{j}\right)$ for some $c_{1}>0$. We have

$$
\operatorname{supp} \chi_{j} \Subset D \quad \text { or } \quad B_{j} \cap \partial D \neq \emptyset
$$

Thus we can find an open set $\omega_{j}$ such that

$$
\mathcal{N}_{t}\left(B_{j} \cap D\right)-t \omega_{j} \subset \bar{D}, \quad \forall t \in[0,1]
$$

Fix a compact set $K_{j}$ such that its interior $K_{j}^{o}$ satisfies

$$
\emptyset \neq K_{j}^{o} \subset K_{j} \subset \omega_{j}
$$

By Lemma 3.5, we find a smooth function $\mu_{j}$ on $\mathbb{R}^{d}$ such that $\int y^{I} \mu_{j}(y) d y=0$ for $|I|>0, \int \mu_{j}(y) d y=1$ and

$$
\operatorname{supp} \mu_{j} \subset K_{j}^{o}
$$

By (3.10)-(3.12), for $t \in[0,1]$

$$
S_{j}^{t} f_{j}(x)=\int_{y \in \omega_{j}} f_{j}(x-t y) \mu_{j}(y) d y
$$

is a well-defined smooth function on $\mathcal{N}_{t}\left(B_{j} \cap D\right)$. Now by adjusting $\omega_{j}$ if necessary we have $S_{j}^{t} f_{j}=0$ on $\mathcal{N}_{c_{1}}\left(\bar{D} \cap \partial B_{j}\right)$ for some $c_{1}>0$. Define $S_{j}^{t} f_{j}=0$ on $\mathcal{N}_{t}\left(D \backslash B_{j}\right)$. Then $S_{j}^{t} f_{j}$ is smooth on $\mathcal{N}_{t}(D)$. We still have (3.13) and

$$
\left[\nabla, S_{j}^{t}\right] f_{j}=0
$$

Let $E_{j} f=\chi_{j} E f$. By (3.10) and (3.13), $S_{j}^{t} f_{j}=S_{j}^{t} E_{j} f$ on $\mathcal{N}_{t}(D)$. In other words, on $\mathcal{N}_{t}(D), S_{j}^{t} E_{j} f$ is independent of $E_{j}$.

By properties of Moser's smoothing operator, we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left|S_{j}^{t} E_{j} f\right|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(D), r} \leq C_{r, s} t^{s-r}\left|E_{j} f\right|_{D_{j}, s} \leq C_{r, s}^{\prime} t^{s-r}|f|_{D, s}, 0<s \leq r<\infty \\
\left|\left(I-S_{j}^{t}\right) E_{j} f\right|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(D), r} \leq C_{r, s} t^{s-r}\left|E_{j} f\right|_{D_{j}, s} \leq C_{r, s}^{\prime} t^{s-r}|f|_{D, s}, 0<r \leq s+m_{*}
\end{gathered}
$$

Note that these properties are usually stated for Hölder norms; via interpolation they hold for Zygmund norms too. The reader is referred to [14, sect. 5], for instance, on the equivalence of norms when interpolation is applied.

On $\mathcal{N}_{t}(D)$, we define

$$
S^{t} f:=\sum S_{j}^{t}\left(\chi_{j} f\right)
$$

We obtain (3.4)-(3.7) immediately from the estimates for $S_{j}^{t}$ and the inequality

$$
\left|\chi_{j} f\right|_{r} \leq C_{r}|f|_{r}
$$

via (3.2). We now prove (3.8). We first consider the case that $r>1$. We have $S^{t}(\nabla f)=\sum S_{j}^{t}\left(\chi_{j} \nabla f\right)$. On $\mathcal{N}_{t}(D)$, by (3.14)

$$
\nabla S^{t} f=\sum S_{j}^{t}\left(\nabla\left(\chi_{j} f\right)\right)=S^{t} \nabla f+\sum S_{j}^{t}\left(f \nabla \chi_{j}\right)
$$

To finish the proof, we use the crucial fact that $S_{j}^{t}\left(f \nabla \chi_{j}\right)=S_{j}^{t}\left(E f \nabla \chi_{j}\right)$ by (3.10). Therefore,

$$
\left[\nabla, S^{t}\right] f=\sum\left(S_{j}^{t}-\mathrm{id}\right)\left(E f \nabla \chi_{j}\right)+E f \sum \nabla \chi_{j}
$$

The last sum vanishes since $\sum_{j} \chi_{j}=1$ on $\mathcal{N}_{t}(D)$. Now (3.8) for $r>1$ follows from (3.6)-(3.7).

Consider now $0<r \leq 1$. By (3.7), the $S^{\varepsilon} u$ converges to $u$ in $C^{0}(\bar{D})$ norm as $\varepsilon \rightarrow 0$. Since (3.8) holds when $u$ is replaced by $S^{\varepsilon} u$, we have

$$
|h|^{-r}\left|\Delta_{h}^{2} u(x)\right|=\lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0}|h|^{-r}\left|\Delta_{h} S^{\varepsilon} u(x)\right| \leq C_{r, s} t^{s-r} \liminf _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0}\left|S^{\varepsilon} u\right|_{s} \leq C_{r, s} t^{s-r}|u|_{s}
$$

for any $x, x+h, x+2 h \in D$ and $h \neq 0$. This verifies (3.8) via equivalent norms.
Next, we extend the above definition and properties of $S^{t}$ for sections of holomorphic vector bundles on $M$. For our use, we will replace $\nabla$ by the global operator $\bar{\partial}$.

Recall that $\left\{U_{k}\right\}$ is an open covering of $\bar{M}$ and $z_{k}=\psi_{k}: U_{k} \rightarrow \hat{U}_{k}$ are coordinate maps. Let $\left\{\chi_{k}\right\}$ be a partition of unity subordinated to $\left\{U_{k}\right\}$ such that $\sqrt{\chi_{k}} \in$ $C^{\infty}(\mathcal{M}), \sum \chi_{k}=1$ in a neighborhood $\mathcal{U}$ of $M$ and $\operatorname{supp} \chi_{k} \Subset U_{k}$ and let $\hat{\chi}_{k}=$ $\chi_{k} \circ \psi_{k}^{-1}$. Let $D_{k}=\psi_{k}\left(M_{k}\right)$.

Set $M_{t}=\cup \psi_{k}^{-1}\left(\mathcal{N}_{t}\left(D_{k}\right)\right)$ for $t>0$, which is a neighborhood of $\bar{M}$ in $\mathcal{M}$.
Definition 3.7. Let $V$ be a holomorphic vector bundle on $\mathcal{M}$ with holomorphic basis $\left\{e_{k, 1}, \ldots, e_{k, m}\right\}$ on $U_{k}$. Suppose that $v=\sum_{j, I} v_{k, I}^{j}\left(z_{k}\right) d \bar{z}_{k}^{I} \otimes e_{k, j}\left(z_{k}\right)$ is in $C_{0, q}^{0}(\bar{M}, V)$. Define an extension $E v \in C_{(0, q)}^{0}(\mathcal{M}, V)$ by

$$
E v:=\sum_{k} \sum_{|I|=q} \sum_{j=1}^{m} \tilde{v}_{k, I}^{j}\left(z_{k}\right) d \bar{z}_{k}^{I} \otimes e_{k, j}\left(z_{k}\right), \quad\left|\tilde{v}_{k, I}^{j}\right|_{D_{k} ; r} \leq C_{r}|v|_{M, r}
$$

Here $\tilde{v}_{k, I}^{j}\left(z_{k}\right)=\chi_{k}^{1 / 2} E_{D_{k}}\left(\hat{\chi}_{k}^{1 / 2} v_{k, I}^{j}\right)\left(z_{k}\right)$ on $\mathcal{M}$ (and $\tilde{v}_{k, I}^{j}=0$ on $\mathcal{M} \backslash U_{k}$ ).

Let $S_{k}^{t}$ be a smoothing operator for functions on $D_{k}=\psi_{k}\left(U_{k} \cap M\right)$ satisfying Lemma 3.6. Then $\left(S_{k}^{t}\left(\check{\chi}_{k} \check{v}_{k, I}^{j}\right)\right)\left(z_{k}\right) d \check{z}_{k}^{I} \otimes e_{k, j}$ is smooth on $U_{k} \cap \mathcal{N}_{t}(M)$ and vanishes on $\mathcal{N}_{c_{2}}\left(\mathcal{N}_{t}(M) \cap \partial U_{k}\right.$ for some $\left.c_{2}>0\right)$. Hence, it is well-defined and smooth on $\mathcal{N}_{t}(M)$ by setting it to be zero on $\mathcal{N}_{t}(M)) \backslash U_{k} \cap \mathcal{N}_{t}(M)$.
Definition 3.8. Let $v \in C_{[0, q)}^{0}(\bar{M}, V)$. Define on $\mathcal{N}_{t}(M)$

$$
S^{t} v=\sum_{k} \sum_{|I|=q} \sum_{j=1}^{m} \chi_{k}^{1 / 2}\left(S_{k}^{t}\left(\check{\chi}_{k}^{1 / 2} v_{k, I}^{j}\right)\right)\left(z_{k}\right) d \check{z}_{k}^{I} \otimes e_{k, j}
$$

Here $\chi_{k}^{1 / 2}\left(S_{k}^{t}\left(\check{\chi}_{k}^{1 / 2} \check{v}_{k, I}^{j}\right)\right)\left(z_{k}\right)$, vanishing on $\mathcal{N}_{t}(M) \backslash U_{k}$, are smooth on $\mathcal{N}_{t}(M)$.
Note that on $\mathcal{N}_{t}(M)$, the $S^{t} E v=S^{t} v$ depends only on the values of $v$ on $M$. Therefore, we can express

$$
S^{t} \check{v}-\check{v}=\sum_{k} \sum_{j, I}\left(\check{\chi}_{k}^{1 / 2}\left(S_{k}^{t}-\mathrm{id}\right) E_{D_{k}}\left(\check{\chi}_{k}^{1 / 2} v_{k, I}^{j}\right)\right)\left(z_{k}\right) d \check{z}_{k}^{I} \otimes e_{k, j}
$$

Lemma 3.9. Let $S^{t}$ be given by (3.16). Then

$$
S^{t}: C_{0, q}(\bar{M} ; V) \rightarrow C_{0, q}^{\infty}\left(\mathcal{N}_{t}(M) ; V\right)
$$

For all $v \in \Lambda^{s}(\bar{M})$, the following hold

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|S^{t} v\right|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M), r} & \leq C_{r, s} t^{s-r}|v|_{M, s}, \quad 0<s \leq r<\infty \\
\left|\left(I-S^{t}\right) E v\right|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M), r} & \leq C_{r, s} t^{s-r}|v|_{M, s}, \quad 0<r \leq s+m_{*}, \\
\left|\left[\bar{\partial}, S^{t}\right] v\right|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M), s} & \leq C_{r, s} t^{r-s}|v|_{M, s}, \quad 0<s \leq r<s+m_{*}
\end{aligned}
$$

Here $C_{r, s}$ are stable under smaller perturbations of Lipschitz domains of $M$, and $\left[\bar{\partial}, S^{t}\right] v:=\lim _{e \rightarrow 0^{+}}\left[\bar{\partial}, S^{t}\right] S^{e} v$ when $s \in(0,1]$.
Proof. The first two inequalities follows from (3.16), (3.17), and the previous lemma immediately.

We now estimate $\left[\bar{\partial}, S^{t}\right]$. Recall that on $\mathcal{N}_{t}(M) \cap U_{k}, S^{t}(\bar{\partial} v)$ depends only on the value of $\bar{\partial} v$ on $M$. Let $v=\sum_{j, I} v_{k, I}^{j}\left(z_{k}\right) d \check{z}_{k}^{I} \otimes e_{k, j}$. We have

$$
\bar{\partial} v=\sum_{|I|=q} \sum_{j=1}^{m} \bar{\partial} v_{k, I}^{j}\left(z_{k}\right) \wedge d \check{z}_{k}^{I} \otimes e_{k, j}
$$

Hence,

$$
S^{t}(\bar{\partial} v)=S^{t}(\bar{\partial} v)=\sum_{k, j, I} \chi_{k}^{1 / 2}\left(S_{k}^{t}\left(\check{\chi}_{k}^{1 / 2} \bar{\partial} v_{k, I}^{j}\right)\right)\left(z_{k}\right) \wedge d \check{z}_{k}^{I} \otimes e_{k, j}
$$

On $U_{k} \cap \mathcal{N}_{t}(M)$, we also have $\bar{\partial} S_{k}^{t}=S_{k}^{t} \bar{\partial}$ on $\mathcal{N}_{t}\left(D_{k}\right) \cap \operatorname{supp} \check{\chi}_{k}$. Therefore, on $\mathcal{N}_{t}(M)$ we can express

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{\partial} S^{t} v= & \sum_{k, j, I} \bar{\partial}\left(\chi_{k}^{1 / 2} S_{k}^{t}\left(\check{\chi}_{k}^{1 / 2} v_{k, I}^{j}\right)\right)\left(z_{k}\right) \wedge d \check{z}_{k}^{I} \otimes e_{k, j} \\
= & \sum_{k, j, I} \bar{\partial} \chi_{k}^{1 / 2} \wedge\left(S_{k}^{t}\left(\check{\chi}_{k}^{1 / 2} v_{k, I}^{j}\right)\right)\left(z_{k}\right) d \check{z}_{k}^{I} \otimes e_{k, j} \\
& +\sum_{k, j, I} \chi_{k}^{1 / 2}\left(S_{k}^{t}\left(\bar{\partial}\left(\check{\chi}_{k}^{1 / 2} v_{k, I}^{j}\right)\right)\right)\left(z_{k}\right) \wedge d \check{z}_{k}^{I} \otimes e_{k, j}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
{\left[\bar{\partial}, S^{t}\right] v=} & \sum_{k, j, I} \bar{\partial} \chi_{k}^{1 / 2} \wedge\left(S_{k}^{t}\left(\tilde{\chi}_{k}^{1 / 2} v_{k, I}^{j}\right)\right)\left(z_{k}\right) d \tilde{z}_{k}^{I} \otimes e_{k, j} \\
& +\sum_{k, j, I} \chi_{k}^{1 / 2}\left(S_{k}^{t}\left(v_{k, I}^{j} \bar{\partial} \tilde{\chi}_{k}^{1 / 2}\right)\right)\left(z_{k}\right) \wedge d \tilde{z}_{k}^{I} \otimes e_{k, j} \\
= & \sum_{k, j, I} \bar{\partial} \chi_{k}^{1 / 2} \wedge\left(\left(S_{k}^{t}-I\right)\left(\tilde{\chi}_{k}^{1 / 2} v_{k, I}^{j}\right)\right)\left(z_{k}\right) d \tilde{z}_{k}^{I} \otimes e_{k, j} \\
& +\sum_{k, j, I} \chi_{k}^{1 / 2}\left(\left(S_{k}^{t}-I\right)\left(v_{k, I}^{j} \bar{\partial} \tilde{\chi}_{k}^{1 / 2}\right)\right)\left(z_{k}\right) \wedge d \tilde{z}_{k}^{I} \otimes e_{k, j} \\
& +\sum_{k, j, I}\left(\left(2 \tilde{\chi}_{k}^{1 / 2} \bar{\partial} \tilde{\chi}_{k}^{1 / 2}\right)\left(v_{k, I}^{j}\right)\left(z_{k}\right)\right) \wedge d \tilde{z}_{k}^{I} \otimes e_{k, j}
\end{aligned}
$$

The last summation is zero, as it equals $\sum_{k}\left(2 \chi_{k}^{1 / 2} \bar{\partial} \chi_{k}^{1 / 2}\right) \wedge v$ and $\sum \chi_{k}=1$. Now the lemma follows from (3.7) and the smooth approximation of $v$ via $S^{c} v$ for (3.20) when $s \in(0,1]$.

# 4. Estimates of the flows 

In this section, we describe a formally integrable complex structure that has finite distance to the complex structure of $\mathcal{M}$ in a $C^{1}$ section of $\Theta$-valued $(0,1)$ form on $\bar{M}$. We show the time-one mapping $F^{1}$ of the smoothing $S^{t} v$ of a vector filed $v$ defined on $M$ can be estimated on the same domain $M$. We also derive estimates for $\bar{\partial} F^{1}$ in terms of $\bar{\partial} v$ for non-holomorphic $v$.
4.1. Almost complex structures in coordinate charts. An almost complex structure $X$ on $\bar{M}$ that has a finite distance to the standard complex structure on $\mathcal{M}$ is given in local coordinates $z_{k}$ by

$$
X_{k, \bar{\sigma}}=\frac{\partial}{\partial \bar{z}_{k}^{\alpha}}+\sum_{\beta} A_{k, \bar{\sigma}}^{\beta}\left(z_{k}\right) \frac{\partial}{\partial z_{k}^{\beta}}, \quad \alpha=1, \ldots, n
$$

By definition, the span of $\left\{X_{k, \bar{\sigma}}\right\}$ is the same as the span of $\left\{X_{j, \bar{\sigma}}\right\}$ on $U_{k} \cap U_{j}$. Thus $A:=A_{k, \bar{\beta}}^{\alpha}\left(z_{k}\right) d \bar{z}_{k}^{\beta} \otimes \frac{\partial}{\partial z_{k}^{\alpha}} \in C_{(0,1)}^{1}(\bar{M}, \Theta)$ is a global section. We have

$$
\bar{\partial} A=\sum_{\beta<\gamma}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial \bar{z}_{k}^{\beta}} A_{k, \bar{\gamma}}^{\alpha}-\frac{\partial}{\partial \bar{z}_{k}^{\gamma}} A_{k, \bar{\beta}}^{\alpha}\right) d \bar{z}_{k}^{\beta} \wedge d \bar{z}_{k}^{\gamma} \otimes \frac{\partial}{\partial z_{k}^{\alpha}}
$$

The formal integrability means that $\left[X_{\alpha}, X_{\beta}\right]$ is in the span of $X_{k, \bar{\gamma}}, \ldots, X_{k, \bar{\pi}}$. One can check that equivalently, we have $\left[X_{k, \bar{\sigma}}, X_{k, \bar{\beta}}\right]=0$, i.e. $\bar{\partial} A=-\frac{1}{2}[A, A]$, where in local coordinates the Lie bracket is defined by

$$
\begin{aligned}
{[A, A]: } & =\sum_{\alpha, \beta, \gamma} Q_{k, \overline{\beta \gamma}}^{\alpha}(A) d \bar{z}_{k}^{\beta} \wedge d \bar{z}_{k}^{\gamma} \otimes \frac{\partial}{\partial z_{k}^{\alpha}} \\
Q_{k, \overline{\beta \gamma}}^{\alpha}(A) & :=\sum_{\tau} A_{k, \bar{\beta}}^{\tau}\left(z_{k}\right) \frac{\partial A_{\bar{\sigma}}^{\alpha}}{\partial z_{k}^{\tau}}-A_{k, \bar{\gamma}}^{\tau}\left(z_{k}\right) \frac{\partial A_{k, \bar{\beta}}^{\alpha}}{\partial z_{k}^{\tau}}
\end{aligned}
$$

The standard complex structure on $M$ corresponds to $A=0$.

We will use the following lemma in Webster [58] showing how an almost complex structure changes with respect to a transformation of the form $F=\mathrm{id}+f$ where $I$ is the identity mapping. It provides a useful formula for $A^{\prime}$ in terms of $A$ and $F$.

We will use matrix $A_{k}=\left(A_{k, \bar{\sigma}}^{\alpha}\right)_{1 \leq \alpha, \beta \leq n}$. Denote by $I$ the $n \times n$ identity matrix.
Lemma 4.1. Let $M$ be a relatively compact domain in $\mathcal{M}$ with $C^{2}$ boundary and let $M^{\prime} \Subset \mathcal{M}$ be a small $C^{2}$ perturbation of $M$. Let $\left\{X_{\bar{\sigma}}\right\}_{\alpha=1}^{n}$ be a $C^{1}$ almost complex structure on an open set $\bar{M}$ that has finite distance to the standard complex structure on $M$. Let $F$ be a $C^{1}$ mapping from $\bar{M}$ onto $\bar{M}^{\prime}$. Let $F_{k}=\psi_{k} F \psi_{k}^{-1}=\mathrm{id}+f_{k}$. There is a constant $\delta$ depends on $\|A\|_{0}$ such that if

$$
\|F-\mathrm{id}\|_{M, 1}<\delta
$$

then $F$ is a $C^{1}$ diffeomorphism and $\left(F_{k}\right)_{*} X_{k, \bar{\sigma}}$ are in the span of

$$
X_{k, \bar{\sigma}}^{\prime}=\frac{\partial}{\partial \bar{z}_{k}^{\alpha}}+\sum_{\beta} A_{k, \bar{\sigma}}^{\prime \beta}\left(z_{k}\right) \frac{\partial}{\partial z_{k}^{\beta}}, \quad \alpha=1, \ldots, n
$$

Furthermore, $X_{k, \bar{\sigma}} F_{k}^{\beta}=\left(X_{k, \bar{\sigma}} F_{k}^{\bar{\sigma}}\right)\left(A^{\prime \beta}{ }_{k, \bar{\sigma}}^{\beta} \circ F_{k}\right)$. Equivalently, as matrices,
(4.1) $A_{k}\left(z_{k}\right)+\left(f_{k}\right)_{\bar{z}_{k}}+A_{k}\left(z_{k}\right)\left(f_{k}\right)_{\bar{z}_{k}}=\left(I+\left(\bar{f}_{k}\right)_{\bar{z}_{k}}+A_{k}\left(z_{k}\right)\left(\bar{f}_{k}\right)_{z_{k}}\right) A_{k}^{\prime} \circ F_{k}\left(z_{k}\right)$.

Therefore, a $C^{2}$ diffeomorphism from $M$ onto $M^{\prime}$ that is close to the identity transforms $A \in C_{(0,1)}^{1}(M, \Theta)$ into $A^{\prime} \in C_{(0,1)}^{1}\left(M^{\prime}, \Theta\right)$ that still satisfies $\bar{\partial} A^{\prime}=$ $-\frac{1}{2}\left[A^{\prime}, A^{\prime}\right]$ on $M^{\prime}$. Thus, the solution to the global Newlander-Nirenberg theorem is meant to find an $F$ with a desired regularity such that $F$ transforms $A$ into $A^{\prime}=0$, according to the relation (4.1).
4.2. Time-one maps of vector fields of type $(1,0)$. The advantage of expressing an almost complex structure via a global section $A \in C_{(0, r)}^{1}(M, \Theta)$ is to use the time-one map of a global section $v \in C^{1}(M, \Theta)$ to transform the structure. This however requires the vector fields to be defined on a domain slightly larger than $M$.

We will study the flows of a type $(1,0)$ vector field $v$ on $\mathcal{M}$, i.e. the $v$ that has the form $v=\sum v_{k}^{\alpha}\left(z_{k}\right) \frac{\partial}{\partial z_{k}^{\alpha}}$, and let $F^{\lambda}$ be its flow. We will also estimate $\bar{\partial} F^{\lambda}$ in terms of $\bar{\partial} v$. Define

$$
\psi_{k} F^{\lambda} \psi_{k}^{-1}\left(z_{k}\right)=z_{k}+f_{k}^{\lambda}\left(z_{k}\right), \quad f_{k}^{\lambda}\left(z_{k}\right)=\lambda v_{k}\left(z_{k}\right)+w_{k}\left(z_{k}, \lambda\right)
$$

Recall that $\left\{U_{k}\right\}$ covers a neighborhood of $\bar{M}$. In the following, let us denote

$$
|v|_{\mathcal{N}_{a}(M), r}=\max _{k, \alpha}|v_{k}^{\alpha}|_{\mathcal{N}_{a}\left(D_{k}\right), r}
$$

Define $\|v\|_{\mathcal{N}_{a}(M), r}$ analogously. Define

$$
|v|_{r}=\max \left|v_{k}\right|_{U_{k}, r}, \quad\|v\|_{r}=\max \left\|v_{k}\right\|_{U_{k}, r}
$$

When we smooth a vector field $v$ on $M, S^{t} v$ is defined on a slightly large domain $\mathcal{N}_{t}(M)$. This allows us to estimate the time-one map of the smoothed vector field without shrinking the original domain. More precisely, we have the following.
Proposition 4.2. Let $M$ be a relatively compact Lipschitz domain in $\mathcal{M}$. Let $v=\sum v_{k}^{\alpha}\left(z_{k}\right) \frac{\partial}{\partial z_{k}^{\alpha}}$ be a $C^{1}$ vector field defined on $\mathcal{M}$ and let $F^{\lambda}$ be its flow. There are positive constants $C_{n}, \delta_{0}, \delta_{1}, \delta_{1}^{\prime}, \delta_{2}$ such that if $\|v\|_{1} \leq \delta_{1}$, then the flow $F^{\lambda}$ of $v$ is well-defined on $\mathcal{N}_{\delta_{0}}(M)$ for $\lambda \in[-1,1]$ and

$$
F^{\lambda}\left(\mathcal{N}_{\delta}(M)\right) \subset \mathcal{N}_{\delta+C_{n}\|v\|_{0}}(M), \quad 0 \leq \delta \leq \delta_{0}, \quad \lambda \in[-1,1]
$$

In particular, when $0 \leq \delta \leq \delta_{0}$ and $C_{n}\|v\|_{0} \leq \delta_{0}$,

$$
M^{1}:=F^{1}(M) \subset \mathcal{N}_{C_{n}\|v\|_{0}}(M), \quad F^{-1}\left(M^{1}\right) \subset \mathcal{N}_{C_{n}\left(C_{n}+1\right)\|v\|_{0}}(M)
$$

Further, for fixed $\varepsilon>0, w_{k}:=F_{k}^{\lambda}-\mathrm{id}-\lambda v_{k}$ satisfy the following
(a) If $|v|_{1+\varepsilon}<\delta_{1, \varepsilon}^{\varepsilon}$ and $r>1$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|w_{k}(\cdot, \lambda)\right|_{\mathcal{N}_{\delta}\left(D_{k}\right), r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}(M)|v|_{r}^{*} \\
& \left|w_{k}(\cdot, \lambda)\right|_{\mathcal{N}_{\delta}\left(D_{k}\right), r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}(M)|v|_{r+1}^{*}|v|_{1+\varepsilon}^{*}
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) If $|v|_{2+\varepsilon}<\delta_{2, \varepsilon}$ and $r>1$, then

$$
\left|\bar{\partial} w_{k}(\cdot, \lambda)\right|_{\mathcal{N}_{\delta}\left(D_{k}\right), r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}|\bar{\partial} v|_{r+1}^{*}|v|_{1+\varepsilon}^{*}+C_{r, \varepsilon}(M)|\bar{\partial} v|_{1+\varepsilon}^{*}|v|_{r+1}^{*}
$$

Here $|v|_{r}^{*}=|v|_{\mathcal{N}_{\delta+C_{n}\|v\|_{0}}(M), r}$. Further, $C_{n}$ depends only on $n$, and $C_{r, \varepsilon}(M), \delta_{0}$, $\delta_{1}, \delta_{1, \varepsilon}^{\varepsilon}, \delta_{2, \varepsilon}$ are stable under small perturbations of $b M$. The estimates (4.3)-(4.5) hold for $\varepsilon=0$ if all $|\cdot|$ norms are replaced by the corresponding $\|\cdot\|$ norms.

Proof. The uniqueness and the local existence of $C^{1}$ flows for $C^{1}$ vector fields is a standard theorem; see [33, Thm. 4.2]. We need to verify (4.2) and the rest of estimates.

Recall that $z_{k}$ maps $U_{k}, U_{k}^{\prime}$ onto $\hat{U}_{k}, \hat{U}_{k}^{\prime}$ respectively. In the coordinate chart $\left(U_{k}, z_{k}\right)$, let $v_{k}=\left(v_{k}^{1}, \ldots, v_{k}^{n}\right)$ be the components of $v$. Write $F^{\lambda}$ as

$$
F_{k}^{\lambda}\left(z_{k}\right)=z_{k}+\lambda v_{k}\left(z_{k}\right)+w_{k}\left(z_{k}, \lambda\right)
$$

It suffices to solve for $\lambda \in[-1,1]$

$$
w_{k}\left(z_{k}, \lambda\right)=\left(T_{k} w_{k}\right)\left(z_{k}, \lambda\right)
$$

where $T_{k}$ is the map defined by

$$
\left(T_{k} w_{k}\right)\left(z_{k}, \lambda\right):=\int_{0}^{\lambda}\left\{v_{k}\left(z_{k}+s v_{k}\left(z_{k}\right)+w_{k}\left(z_{k}, s\right)\right)-v_{k}\left(z_{k}\right)\right\} d s
$$

Let $B^{0}$ be the set of families $\left\{w_{k}\right\}$, where $w_{k}$ is a $C^{0}$ mapping from $\widehat{\mathcal{N}_{\delta}\left(D_{k}\right)} \times[-1,1]$ into the polydisc $\overline{\Delta_{2 a}^{n}}$ with $a=\left\|v_{k}\right\|_{U_{k} ; 0}$. On $B^{0}$, we use the metric

$$
d\left(\tilde{w}_{k}, w_{k}\right)=\left\|\tilde{w}_{k}-w_{k}\right\|_{0}
$$

Here and in what follows, we denote $\left\|w_{k}\right\|_{\mathcal{N}_{\delta}\left(D_{k}\right) \times[0,1], r},\left|w_{k}\right|_{\mathcal{N}_{\delta}\left(D_{k}\right) \times[0,1], r}$ by $\left\|w_{k}\right\|_{r}$ and $\left|w_{k}\right|_{r}$ respectively.

We now choose $C$ so large that $z_{k}+s \tilde{v}_{k}+\tilde{w}_{k} \in \mathcal{N}_{\delta+C_{2}^{2} v_{k} \|_{0}}\left(D_{k}\right)$, when

$$
z_{k} \in \mathcal{N}_{\delta}\left(D_{k}\right), \quad \tilde{v}_{k} \in \Delta_{a}^{n}, \quad \tilde{w}_{k} \in \Delta_{2 a}^{n}
$$

By the contraction mapping theorem, when $\left\|v_{k}\right\|_{\hat{U}_{k}, 1}<\delta_{1}$, there is a unique solution $w_{k} \in B^{0}$ satisfying (4.6). Thus, $w_{k}$ satisfies

$$
w_{k}\left(z_{k}, \lambda\right)=\int_{0}^{\lambda} v_{k}\left(z_{k}+s v_{k}\left(z_{k}\right)+w_{k}\left(z_{k}, s\right)\right)-v_{k}\left(z_{k}\right) d s
$$

To simplify notation, we drop subscript $k$ in $w, v$. We write $w_{z}$ and $w_{\bar{z}}$ for the Jacobean matrices in $z$ and $\bar{z}$, respectively. Write $\bar{v}(z)=\overline{v(z)}$. We also write

$|w(\cdot, \lambda)|_{\mathcal{N}_{\delta}\left(D_{k}\right), a}$ as $|w(\cdot, \lambda)|_{a}$. Differentiating (4.7), we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
w_{z}(z, \lambda)= & \int_{0}^{\lambda} v_{z}(z+s v(z)+w(z, s))-v_{z}(z) d s \\
& +\int_{0}^{\lambda} v_{z}(z+s v(z)+w(z, s))\left(s v_{z}(z)+w_{z}(z, s)\right) d s \\
& +\int_{0}^{\lambda} v_{\bar{z}}(z+s v(z)+w(z, s))\left(s \bar{v}_{z}(z)+\bar{w}_{z}(z, s)\right) d s
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly, for the $\bar{z}$ derivatives, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
w_{\bar{z}}(z, \lambda)= & \int_{0}^{\lambda} v_{\bar{z}}(z+s v(z)+w(z, s))-v_{\bar{z}}(z) d s \\
& +\int_{0}^{\lambda} v_{z}(z+s v(z)+w(z, s))\left(s v_{\bar{z}}(z)+w_{\bar{z}}(z, s)\right) d s \\
& +\int_{0}^{\lambda} v_{\bar{z}}(z+s v(z)+w(z, s))\left(s \bar{v}_{\bar{z}}(z)+\bar{w}_{\bar{z}}(z, s)\right) d s \\
= & I_{1}+I_{2}+I_{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

Applying the contraction mapping again, one can show that when $v \in \Lambda^{r}$ with $r>1, w_{(z, \bar{z})}(\cdot, \lambda)$ are in $\Lambda^{r-1}\left(\mathcal{N}_{\delta}\left(D_{k}\right)\right)$ when $\lambda$ is fixed.

We will first derive estimate (4.3). Suppose $r>1$. By (4.7) and (3.5), we get

$$
|w(\cdot, \lambda)|_{r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}\left\{|v|_{r}^{*}(1+|v|_{1+\varepsilon}^{*}+\sup _{|s| \leq|\lambda|}|w(\cdot, s)|_{1+\varepsilon}\right)^{1+2 \varepsilon}+|v|_{1+\varepsilon}^{*}\left(|v|_{r}^{*}+\sup _{|s| \leq|\lambda|}|w(\cdot, s)|_{r}\right)\right\}
$$

Using $\sup _{|s| \leq 1}|w(\cdot, s)|_{1+\varepsilon} \leq C_{\varepsilon}^{\prime}|v|_{1+\varepsilon}^{*} \leq C_{\varepsilon} \delta_{1, \varepsilon}^{\prime}<1 / 2$, we solve for $\sup _{|s| \leq 1}|w(\cdot, s)|_{r}$. This yields (4.3) immediately.

We now use (4.3) to derive better estimates. Let us rewrite (4.7) as
$w(z, \lambda):=\int_{0}^{\lambda} \int_{0}^{1} v_{(z, \bar{z})}\left(z+s_{1} s v(z)+s_{1} w(z, s)(s v(z)+w(z, s), s \bar{v}(z)+\bar{w}(z)\right)^{T} d s_{1} d s$.
For $r>1$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& |w(\cdot, \lambda)|_{r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon^{\prime}}|v|_{1+\varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}\left(|v|_{r}^{*}+\sup _{|s| \leq|\lambda|}|w(\cdot, s)|_{r}\right)+C_{r, \varepsilon^{\prime}}\left(|v|_{\varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}+\sup _{|s| \leq|\lambda|}|w(\cdot, s)|_{\varepsilon^{\prime}}\right) \\
& \times\left(|v|_{r+1}^{*}+|v|_{2+\varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}\left(1+|v|_{r}^{*}+\sup _{|s| \leq|\lambda|}|w(\cdot, s)|_{r}\right)\right) \\
& \leq C_{r, \varepsilon^{\prime}}|v|_{1+\varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}|v|_{r}^{*}+C_{r, \varepsilon^{\prime}}^{\prime}|v|_{1+\varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}\left(|v|_{r+1}^{*}+|v|_{2+\varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}\left(1+|v|_{r}^{*}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, we obtain $|v|_{2+\varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}|v|_{r}^{*} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon^{\prime}}\|v\|_{r+1-\varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}|v|_{1+2 \varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}$. Taking $\varepsilon^{\prime}=\varepsilon / 2$, we get (4.4).
To verify (4.5), we write the first integral in (4.9) as
$I_{1}(z, \lambda):=\int_{0}^{\lambda} \int_{0}^{1}\left(v_{\bar{z}}\right)_{(z, \bar{z})}\left(z+s_{1} s v(z)+s_{1} w(z, s)\right)(s v(z)+w(z, s), s \bar{v}(z)+\bar{w}(z))^{T} d s_{1} d s$.

Using (3.5) and $|v|_{c}^{*}+\sup _{|s|\leq|\lambda|}|w(\cdot, s)|_{\varepsilon}<c$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|I_{1}(\cdot, \lambda)\right|_{r} \leq & C_{r, \varepsilon^{\prime}}\left(|\bar{\partial} v|_{r+1}^{*}+|\bar{\partial} v|_{2+\varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}\right)\left(|v|_{c}^{*}+\sup _{|s| \leq|\lambda|}|w(\cdot, s)|_{\varepsilon}\right) \\
& +C_{r, \varepsilon}|\bar{\partial} v|_{1+\varepsilon}^{*}\left(|v|_{r}^{*}+\sup _{|s| \leq|\lambda|}|w(\cdot, s)|_{r}\right) \\
\leq & C_{r, \varepsilon^{\prime}}^{\prime}\left(|\bar{\partial} v|_{r+1}^{*}+|\bar{\partial} v|_{2+\varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}|v|_{r}^{*}\right)|v|_{1+\varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}+C_{r, \varepsilon^{\prime}}|\bar{\partial} v|_{1+\varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}|v|_{r}^{*} \\
\leq & C_{r, \varepsilon^{\prime}}^{\prime \prime}|\bar{\partial} v|_{r+1}^{*}|v|_{1+\varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}+C_{r, \varepsilon^{\prime}}^{\prime \prime}|\bar{\partial} v|_{1+2 \varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}|v|_{r+1-\varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}|v|_{1+\varepsilon^{\prime}}+C_{r, \varepsilon^{\prime}}|\bar{\partial} v|_{1+\varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}|v|_{r}^{*}
\end{aligned}
$$

Here we have used $|\bar{\partial} v|_{2+\varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}|v|_{r}^{*} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon^{\prime}}\left\|\bar{\partial} v\right\|_{r+1-\varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}\left|v\right|_{1+2 \varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}+C_{r, \varepsilon^{\prime}}\left\|\bar{\partial} v\right\|_{1+2 \varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}\left|v\right|_{r+1-\varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}$. Using (3.5), $|v|_{1+\varepsilon}^{*} \leq \delta_{1, \varepsilon}^{\prime}$, and $\sup _{|s| \leq 1}|w(\cdot, s)|_{1+\varepsilon}<C$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|I_{2}(\cdot, \lambda)\right|_{r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}\left(|v|_{r+1}^{*}+|v|_{2+\varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}\left(1+2|v|_{r}^{*}\right)\right)\left(|\bar{\partial} v|_{c}^{*}+\sup _{|s| \leq|\lambda|}|\bar{\partial} w(\cdot, s)|_{\varepsilon}\right) \\
& +C_{r, \varepsilon}|v|_{1+\varepsilon}^{*}\left(1+|v|_{1+\varepsilon}+\sup _{|s| \leq|\lambda|}|\bar{\partial} w(\cdot, s)|_{1+\varepsilon}\right)\left(|\bar{\partial} v|_{r}^{*}+\sup _{|s| \leq|\lambda|}|\bar{\partial} w(\cdot, s)|_{r}\right) \\
& \left|I_{3}(\cdot, \lambda)\right|_{r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}\left(|\bar{\partial} v|_{r}^{*}+|\bar{\partial} v|_{1+\varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}\left(1+2|v|_{r}^{*}\right)\right)\left(|v|_{1+\varepsilon}^{*}+\sup _{|s| \leq|\lambda|}|\bar{\partial} w(\cdot, s)|_{1+\varepsilon}\right) \\
& +C_{r, \varepsilon}|\bar{\partial} v|_{\varepsilon}^{*}\left(1+|v|_{1+\varepsilon}+\sup _{|s| \leq|\lambda|}|\bar{\partial} w(\cdot, s)|_{1+\varepsilon}\right)\left(|v|_{r+1}^{*}+C_{r, \varepsilon} \sup _{|s| \leq|\lambda|}|\bar{\partial} w(\cdot, s)|_{r+1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& |\bar{\partial} w(\cdot, \lambda)|_{r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}|\bar{\partial} v|_{r+1}^{*}|v|_{1+\varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}+C_{r, \varepsilon}|\bar{\partial} v|_{1+2 \varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}|v|_{r+1} \\
& +C_{r, \varepsilon}\left(|v|_{2+\varepsilon}^{*}+|v|_{r+1}\right) \sup _{|s| \leq|\lambda|}|\bar{\partial} w(\cdot, s)|_{\varepsilon}+C_{r, \varepsilon}|v|_{1+\varepsilon}^{*} \sup _{|s| \leq|\lambda|}|\bar{\partial} w(\cdot, s)|_{r}
\end{aligned}
$$

Taking $r=\varepsilon^{\prime}$ and using $|v|_{2+\varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}<\delta_{2}$, we first get

$$
\sup _{|s| \leq 1}|\bar{\partial} w|_{\varepsilon^{\prime}} \leq C_{\varepsilon^{\prime}}|\bar{\partial} v|_{1+\varepsilon}^{*}|v|_{1+\varepsilon}^{*}+C_{\varepsilon^{\prime}}|v|_{2+\varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}|\bar{\partial} v|_{\varepsilon}^{*}
$$

Using the above and solving for $\sup _{|s| \leq 1}|\bar{\partial} w(\cdot, s)|_{r}$ from (4.10) with $\lambda=1$, we obtain

$$
\sup _{|s| \leq 1}|\bar{\partial} w(\cdot, s)|_{r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}\left(|\bar{\partial} v|_{r+1}^{*}|v|_{1+\varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}+|\bar{\partial} v|_{1+2 \varepsilon^{\prime}}^{*}|v|_{r+1}^{*}\right)
$$

This shows (4.5). We can replace $\varepsilon^{\prime}=0$ in the above computation when we take $\varepsilon=0$ and replace all norms in the above computation by the Hölder norms. We have verified the lemma.

# 5. LOCAL HOMOTOPY FORMULAS 

Let $M$ be a relatively compact domain in $\mathcal{M}$ defined by $\rho<0$, where $\rho$ is a $C^{2}$ defining function with $d \rho(p) \neq 0$ when $\rho(p)=0$. Following Henkin-Leiterer [22], we say that $b M$ is strictly $q$-convex at $p \in b M$, if the Levi-form $L_{p} \rho$, i.e. the restriction of the complex Hessian $H_{p} \rho$ on $T_{\rho}^{1,0}(b M)$, has at least $q$ positive eigenvalues. We say that $b M$ is strictly $q$-concave at $\zeta \in b M$, if $L_{\zeta} \rho$ has at least $q$ negative eigenvalues. Thus, a domain is strongly pseudoconvex if and only if it is strictly $(n-1)$-convex.

Thus, $M$ is an $a_{q}$ domain if and only if $b M$ is either $(n-q)$ convex or $(q+1)$ concave, in which case we decompose $b M=b_{n-q}^{+} M \cup b_{q+1}^{-} M$ where $b_{i}^{+} M$ (resp. $\left.b_{i}^{-} M\right)$is the components of $b M$ that has at least $i$ positive (resp. $i$ negative) Levi eigenvalues.

In this section, we will derive the local homotopy formulas near each boundary point of an $a_{q}$ domains. One of the important tools is the commutator $[\bar{\partial}, E]=\bar{\partial} E-$ $\bar{\partial} E$ for suitable extension operators $E$. The commutator $[\bar{\partial}, E]$ was introduced by Peters [47] and has been used by Michel [40], Michel-Shaw [41] and others. It is also one of the main ingredients in the $\frac{1}{2}$-gain estimate $[12,14]$ for a homotopy operator on $a_{q}$ domains. In the above-mentioned papers, the Seeley or Stein extension operators are used. Recently, the Rychkov extension operator to the study of $\bar{\partial}$ problem was introduced by Shi-Yao [53,54]. We also use the Rychkov extension to improve some results in [14].

# 5.1. Existence of local homotopy formulas. 

Definition 5.1. Let $k \geq 1$ and $r>1$. A relatively compact domain $M$ in a $C^{k}$ manifold $X$ is piecewise smooth of class $C^{k}$ (resp. $\Lambda^{r}$ ), if for each $\zeta \in b M$, there are $C^{k}$ (resp. $\Lambda^{r}$ ) functions $\rho_{1}, \ldots, \rho_{\ell}$ defined on a neighborhood $U$ of $\zeta$ such that $M \cap U=\left\{z \in U: \rho_{j}(z)<0, j=1, \ldots, \ell\right\}, \rho_{j}(\zeta)=0$ for all $j$, and

$$
d \rho_{1} \wedge \cdots \wedge d \rho_{\ell} \neq 0
$$

The main purpose of this section is to construct an approximate homotopy formula on a subdomain $M^{\prime}$ of $M$, where $b M^{\prime}$ and $b M$ share a piece of boundary containing a given point $\zeta_{0} \in b M$. The construction will be achieved in local coordinates. The following is proved in [14] when $\mathcal{M}$ is $\mathbb{C}^{n}$. The same proof is valid for the general case, since the result is local.

Lemma 5.2 ([14, Lemma 3.1]). Let $M \Subset \mathcal{M}$ be a domain defined by a $C^{2}$ function $\rho^{0}<0$ satisfying $\nabla \rho^{0} \neq 0$ at each point of $U \cap b M$. Suppose that $b M$ is $(n-q)$ convex at $\zeta \in U$.
(a) There is a local biholomorphic mapping $\psi$ defined on an open set $U$ containing $\zeta$ such that $\psi(\zeta)=0$ while $D^{1}:=\psi(U \cap M)$ is defined by
(5.1) $\rho^{1}(z)=-y_{n}+\lambda_{1}\left|z_{1}\right|^{2}+\cdots+\lambda_{q-1}\left|z_{q-1}\right|^{2}+\left|z_{q}\right|^{2}+\cdots+\left|z_{n}\right|^{2}+R(z)<0$, where $\left|\lambda_{j}\right| \leq 1 / 4$ and $R(z)=o\left(|z|^{2}\right)$. There exists $r_{1}>0$ such that the boundary $\partial \psi(U \cap M)$ intersects the sphere $\partial B_{r}$ transversally when $0<r<$ $r_{1}$. Furthermore, the function $R$ in (5.1) is in $C^{a}\left(B_{r_{1}}\right)$ (resp. $\left.\Lambda^{a}\left(B_{r_{1}}\right)\right)$, when $\rho^{0} \in C^{a}(U)$ with $a \geq 2$ (resp. $\Lambda^{a}(U)$ with $a>2$ ).
(b) Let $\psi$ be as above. There exists $\delta(M)>0$ such that if $\widetilde{M}$ is defined by $\tilde{\rho}^{0}<0$ and $\left\|\tilde{\rho}^{0}-\rho^{0}\right\|_{2}<\delta(M)$, then $\psi(U \cap \widetilde{M})$ is given by
(5.2) $\tilde{\rho}^{1}(z)=-y_{n}+\lambda_{1}\left|z_{1}\right|^{2}+\cdots+\lambda_{q-1}\left|z_{q-1}\right|^{2}+\left|z_{q}\right|^{2}+\cdots+\left|z_{n}\right|^{2}+\tilde{R}(z)<0$ with $\left|\tilde{R}-R\right|_{B_{r_{1}}, a} \leq C_{a}\left|\tilde{\rho}^{0}-\rho^{0}\right|_{U, a}$ for $a>2$ and $\|\tilde{R}-R\|_{B_{r_{1}}, a} \leq C_{a}\left\|\tilde{\rho}^{0}-\right.$ $\rho^{0} \|_{U, a}$ for $a \geq 2$. There exists $r_{1}>0$ such that the boundary $\partial \psi(U \cap \widetilde{M})$ intersects the sphere $\partial B_{r_{2}}$ transversally when $r_{1} / 2<r_{2}<r_{1}$.
Here $\delta(M)$ depends on the modulus of continuity of $\partial^{2} \rho^{0}$.
We now fix notation. Let $\left(D^{1}, U, \phi, \rho^{1}\right)$ be as in Lemma 5.2. Thus, $\rho^{1}$ is given by (5.1) (or (5.2)). Set

$$
\rho^{2}=|z|^{2}-r_{2}^{2}
$$

where $0<r_{2}<r_{1}$ and $r_{1} / 2<r_{2}<r_{1}$ for Lemma 5.2 (a), (b). Let us define

$$
D^{1}: \rho^{1}<0, \quad D_{r_{2}}^{2}: \rho^{2}<0, \quad D_{r_{2}}^{12}=D^{1} \cap D_{r_{2}}^{2}
$$

As in [14, Def. 3.4], we call $\left(D^{1}, D_{r_{2}}^{2}, \rho^{1}, \rho^{2}\right)$ a $(n-q)$ convex configuration for which we take Leray maps Leray maps

$$
\begin{gathered}
g^{0}(z, \zeta)=\bar{\zeta}-\bar{z}, \quad g^{2}(z, \zeta)=\left(\frac{\partial \rho^{2}}{\partial \zeta_{1}}, \ldots, \frac{\partial \rho^{2}}{\partial \zeta_{n}}\right)=\bar{\zeta} \\
g_{j}^{1}(z, \zeta)= \begin{cases}\frac{\partial \rho^{1}}{\partial \zeta_{1}}, & 1 \leq j \leq q+2 \\
\frac{\partial \rho^{1}}{\partial \zeta_{j}}+\bar{z}_{j}-\bar{\zeta}_{j}, & q+3 \leq j \leq n\end{cases}
\end{gathered}
$$

Let $g^{j}: D \times S^{j} \rightarrow \mathbb{C}^{n}$ be $C^{1}$ Leray mappings for $j=1, \ldots, \ell$. Let $w=\zeta-z$. Define

$$
\begin{aligned}
\omega^{i} & =\frac{1}{2 \pi i} \frac{g^{i} \cdot d w}{g^{i} \cdot w}, \quad \Omega^{i}=\omega^{i} \wedge\left(\bar{\partial} \omega^{i}\right)^{n-1} \\
\Omega^{01} & =\omega^{0} \wedge \omega^{1} \wedge \sum_{\alpha+\beta=n-2}\left(\bar{\partial} \omega^{0}\right)^{\alpha} \wedge\left(\bar{\partial} \omega^{1}\right)^{\beta}
\end{aligned}
$$

Here both differentials $d$ and $\bar{\partial}$ are in $z, \zeta$ variables. In general, define

$$
\Omega^{1 \cdots \ell}=\omega^{g_{1}} \wedge \cdots \wedge \omega^{g_{\ell}} \wedge \sum_{\alpha_{1}+\cdots+\alpha_{\ell}=n-\ell}\left(\bar{\partial} \omega^{g_{1}}\right)^{\alpha_{1}} \wedge \cdots\left(\bar{\partial} \omega^{g_{\ell}}\right)^{\alpha_{\ell}}
$$

Decompose $\Omega^{\bullet}=\sum \Omega_{(0, q)}^{\bullet}$, where $\Omega_{(0, q)}^{\bullet}$ has type $(0, q)$ in $z$. Hence, $\Omega_{(0, q)}^{i_{1}, \ldots, i_{\ell}}$ has type $(n, n-\ell-q)$ in $\zeta$. Set $\Omega_{0,-1}^{\bullet}=0$ and $\Omega_{0, n+1}^{\bullet}=0$.

Note that when $M \Subset \mathcal{M}$ is strictly $(q+2)$ concave at $\zeta, \mathcal{M} \backslash \bar{M}$ is strictly $(n-q-3)$ convex at $\zeta$. Thus, there exists a biholomorphic change of coordinates $\psi$ such that $D^{1}=\psi(M \cap U)$ is defined by

$$
\rho^{1}(z)=-y_{q+3}-\left|z_{1}\right|^{2}-\cdots-\left|z_{q+3}\right|^{2}+\lambda_{q+4}\left|z_{q+4}\right|^{2}+\cdots+\lambda_{n}\left|z_{n}\right|^{2}+R(z)
$$

We can intersect $D^{1} \cap D^{2}$ with a third domain

$$
D^{3}: \rho^{3}<0, \quad 0 \in D^{3}
$$

where

$$
\rho^{3}(z):=-y_{q+2}+\sum_{j=q+3}^{n} 3\left|z_{j}\right|^{2}-r_{3}^{2}
$$

with $0<r_{3}<r_{2} / C_{n}$. As in [22, p. 120] define

$$
g_{j}^{3}(z, \zeta)= \begin{cases}0, & 1 \leq j<q+2 \\ i, & j=q+2 \\ 3\left(\bar{\zeta}_{j}+\bar{z}_{j}\right), & q+3 \leq j \leq n\end{cases}
$$

As in [14, Def. 4.3], we call $\left(D^{1}, D_{r_{2}}^{2}, D_{r_{3}}^{3}\right)$ a $(q+2)$ concave configuration.
Set

$$
U^{1}=D^{2} \backslash \overline{D^{1}}, \quad S^{1}=\partial D^{1} \cap D^{2}, \quad S_{+}^{1}=\partial U^{1} \backslash S^{1}, \quad S^{2}=\partial D^{12} \backslash S^{1}
$$

Next, we introduce integrals on domains and lower-dimensional sets:

$$
R_{D ; q}^{i_{1} \cdots i_{\ell}} f(z):=\int_{D} \Omega_{\{0, q\}}^{i_{1} \cdots i_{\ell}}(z, \zeta) \wedge f(\zeta), \quad L_{i_{1} \cdots i_{\mu}}^{j_{1} \cdots j_{\nu}} f:=\int_{S^{i_{1} \cdots i_{\mu}}} \Omega_{\{0, q\}}^{i_{1} \cdots j_{\nu}} \wedge f
$$

Let $D$ be a bounded Lipschitz domain in $\mathbb{C}^{n}$. We now recall an important estimate on the commutator $[X, \mathcal{E}]$ where $\mathcal{E}$ is the Rychkov extension operator [49] satisfying

$$
\mathcal{E}: \Lambda^{r}(D) \rightarrow \Lambda^{r}\left(\mathbb{C}^{n}\right), \quad r>0
$$

Proposition 5.3 ([54]). Let $D$ be a bounded Lipschitz domain in $\mathbb{C}^{n}$. Then the Rychkov extension operator $\mathcal{E}: \Lambda^{r}(D) \rightarrow \Lambda^{r}\left(\mathbb{C}^{n}\right) \cap C^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{C}^{n} \backslash \bar{D}\right)$ satisfies

$$
\left|[\nabla, \mathcal{E}] u(x)\right| \leq C_{r}(D)\left|u\right|_{\Lambda^{r}(D)} \operatorname{dist}(x, D)^{r-1}, \quad r>0
$$

Note that as used in [14], (5.3) holds for $r \geq 1$ when $\mathcal{E}$ is replaced by the Stein extension, provided $r>1$. The above version for $0<r \leq 1$ plays an important role in [52] to obtain our sharp regularity results to avoid a loss of derivatives which occurs in [11].

Using the Rychkov extension operator for $\mathcal{E}_{D^{12}}$, define

$$
\begin{aligned}
H_{s}^{(1)} f & :=R_{U^{1} \cup D^{12} ; s-1}^{0} \mathcal{E}_{D^{12}} f+R_{U^{1} ; s-1}^{01}\left[\bar{\partial}, \mathcal{E}_{D^{12}}\right] f \\
H_{s}^{(2)} f & :=-R_{U^{1} ; s-1}^{1} \mathcal{E}_{D^{12}} f+L_{1^{+} ; s-1}^{01} \mathcal{E}_{D^{12}} f+L_{2 ; s-1}^{02} f+L_{12 ; s-1}^{012} f \\
L_{1^{+} ; s-1}^{01} f & :=\int_{S_{+}^{1}} \Omega_{0, s-1}^{01} \wedge \mathcal{E}_{D^{12}} f
\end{aligned}
$$

Proposition 5.4. Let $r \in(1, \infty)$ and $1 \leq q \leq n-1$. Let $\left(D^{1}, D^{2}\right)$ be an $(n-q)$ convex configuration. There exists a homotopy formula $\varphi=\bar{\partial} H_{q} \varphi+H_{q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi$ for $\varphi \in \Lambda_{(0, q)}^{r}\left(D_{r_{2}}^{12}, V\right)$ with $\bar{\partial} \varphi \in \Lambda_{(0, q)}^{r}\left(D_{r_{2}}^{12}, V\right)$. Here $H_{s}=H_{s}^{(1)}+H_{s}^{(2)}$ with $H_{s}^{(1)}$ and $H_{s}^{(2)}$ being defined by (5.4)-(5.6).
Theorem 5.5. Let $r \in(0, \infty)$. For $j=q, q+1$, the homotopy operator $H_{j}$ in Proposition 5.4 satisfies

$$
\left\|H_{j} \varphi\right\|_{\Lambda^{r+1 / 2}\left(D^{1} \cap D_{r_{2}}^{2}\right)} \leq C_{r}\left(\nabla \rho^{1}, \nabla^{2} \rho^{1}\right)\|\varphi\|_{\Lambda^{r}\left(D^{12}\right)}, \quad r_{1} / 2<r_{3}<3 r_{2} / 4
$$

Moreover, $C_{r}\left(\nabla \rho^{1}, \nabla^{2} \rho^{1}\right)$ is stable under small $C^{2}$ perturbations of $\rho^{1}$. Consequently, the homotopy formula in Proposition 5.4 can be extended uniquely to the case $r \in(0, \infty)$ so that (5.7) still holds.
5.2. Estimates of homotopy operators. The proof of Theorem 5.5 can be derived by the following.

Lemma 5.6. Let $r=k+\alpha$ with $k \geq 0$ be an integer and $0<\alpha \leq 1$. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{[0,1]^{2}} \frac{s_{1}^{r-1} t^{2 n-3} d s_{1} d s_{2} d t}{\left(\delta+s_{1}+s_{2}+t^{2}\right)^{k+2}\left(s_{1}+s_{2}+t\right)^{2 n-3}} \leq C_{r} \delta^{\alpha-1 / 2}, \quad 0<\alpha<1 / 2 \\
& \int_{[0,1]^{2}} \frac{s_{1}^{r-1} t^{2 n-3} d s_{1} d s_{2} d t}{\left(\delta+s_{1}+s_{2}+t^{2}\right)^{k+3}\left(s_{1}+s_{2}+t\right)^{2 n-3}} \leq C_{r} \delta^{\alpha-3 / 2}, \quad 1 / 2 \leq \alpha \leq 1
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. See the estimates for $I_{1}, I_{2}, I_{3}$ in the proof of Theorem 6.1 in [14].
As in [54], the last assertion of Theorem 5.5 follows via a smooth approximation.
Lemma 5.7. Let $M$ be a relatively compact Lipschitz domain in $\mathcal{M}$. Let $\varphi \in$ $\Lambda^{a}(M)$ with $a>0$. Suppose that $\bar{\partial} \varphi \in \Lambda^{b}(M)$ with $a \geq b>0$. There exist $\varphi_{\varepsilon} \in C^{\infty}(\bar{M})$ such that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0}\left\|\varphi_{\varepsilon}-\varphi\right\|_{\Lambda^{a^{\prime}}(M)} & =0, \quad \forall a^{\prime}<a ; & \left\|\varphi_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{\Lambda^{a}} \leq C_{r}(M)\|\varphi\|_{\Lambda^{a}} \\
\lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0}\left\|\bar{\partial} \varphi_{\varepsilon}-\bar{\partial} \varphi\right\|_{\Lambda^{b^{\prime}}(M)} & =0, \quad \forall b^{\prime}<b ; & \left\|\bar{\partial} \varphi_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{\Lambda^{b}} \leq C_{r}(M)\|\bar{\partial} \varphi\|_{\Lambda^{b}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. We consider a partition of unity $\varphi=\sum \varphi_{k}$ where $\varphi_{k}=\chi_{k} \varphi$ and $\sum \chi_{k}=1$. Consider $\varphi_{k, \varepsilon}=\varphi_{k} * \bar{\chi}_{\varepsilon}$. We have $\bar{\partial} \varphi_{k, \varepsilon}=\left(\bar{\partial} \varphi_{k}\right) * \bar{\chi}_{\varepsilon}=\left(\bar{\partial} \chi_{k} \wedge \varphi+\chi_{k} \bar{\partial} \varphi\right) * \bar{\chi}_{\varepsilon}$. Thus, as $\varepsilon \rightarrow 0, \varphi_{\varepsilon}:=\sum \varphi_{k, \varepsilon}$ tends to $\varphi$ in $\Lambda^{a^{\prime}}(M)$ and $\varphi_{\varepsilon}$ tends to $\bar{\partial} \varphi$ in $\Lambda^{b^{\prime}}(M)$.

Let us first derive a corollary as in [54]
Corollary 5.8. Proposition 5.4 and Theorem 5.5 still hold for $r \in(0,1]$.
Proof. We can define $H_{q} \varphi=H_{q} \varphi_{\varepsilon}$ and $H_{q+1}(\bar{\partial} \varphi)=\lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0} H_{q+1}\left(\bar{\partial} \varphi_{\varepsilon}\right)$. Then the estimates in Theorem 5.5 imply that the homotopy formula holds for $\varphi$; see the end of proof of Lemma 3.6 for more details.

Proposition 5.9. Let $r \in(1, \infty)$ and $1 \leq q \leq n-3$. Let $\left(D^{1}, D^{2}, D^{3}\right)$ be a $(q+2)$-concave configuration. Assume that $r_{4}<r_{3} / C_{n}$. For $\varphi \in \Lambda_{(0, q)}^{r}\left(D^{12}, V\right)$ with $\bar{\partial} \varphi \in \Lambda_{(0, q+1)}^{r}\left(D^{12}\right)$, we have

$$
\varphi=\bar{\partial} H_{q} \varphi+H_{q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi \quad \text { on } D^{1} \cap B_{r_{4}}
$$

where for $j=q, q+1, H_{j}=H_{j}^{(1)}+H_{j}^{(2)}+H_{j}^{(3)}$ with $H_{j}^{(1)}, H_{j}^{(2)}$ being given by $(5.4)-(5.6)$ and

$$
H_{j}^{(3)} f=L_{12 ; j}^{123} f-T_{B_{r_{4}} ; j} L_{12 ; j}^{23} f
$$

To derive our main estimates, we use the following.
Lemma 5.10 ([14]). Let $0<\beta \leq 1$. Let $D \subset \mathbb{R}^{n}$ be a bounded and connected Lipschitz domain. Suppose that $f$ is in $C_{l o c}^{[\beta]+1}(D)$ and

$$
\left|\nabla^{1+[\beta]} f(x)\right| \leq A \operatorname{dist}(x, \partial D)^{\beta-1-[\beta]}
$$

Fix $x_{0} \in D$. Then $\|f\|_{\Lambda^{n}(D)}^{m} \leq\|f\|_{C^{0}(D)}+C_{\beta} A$, where constants $C_{0}, C_{\beta}$ are stable under small perturbations of $D$.

Lemma 5.11. Let $\beta \in(-1, \infty), \mu_{1} \in[0, \infty), 0 \leq \lambda \leq \mu_{1}$, and $0<\delta<1$. Set

$$
\beta^{\prime}:=\beta-\frac{\mu_{1}+\lambda-3}{2}
$$

Then for $m \geq 0$,

$$
\int_{[0,1]^{3}} \frac{s_{1}^{\beta}\left(\delta+s_{1}+s_{2}+t^{2}\right)^{-1-\mu_{1}} t^{m}}{\left(\delta+s_{1}+s_{2}+t\right)^{m+\lambda-\mu_{1}}} d s_{1} d s_{2} d t< \begin{cases}C \delta^{\beta^{\prime}}, & \beta^{\prime}<0 \\ C, & \beta^{\prime}>0\end{cases}
$$

Proof. The lemma is proved in [14, Lem. 6.2] for $\beta \geq 0$. The same proof without any changes is valid for $\beta>-1$.

Theorem 5.12. Let $r \in(0, \infty), \varepsilon>0$ and $0 \leq \delta \leq 1 / 2$, and let $1 \leq q \leq n-2$. Let $\left(D^{1}, D^{2}, D^{3}\right)$ be a $(q+2)$-concave configuration. Assume that $\varphi \in \Lambda^{r}\left(\overline{D^{12}}\right)$ and $\varepsilon>0$. Then the homotopy operators in Proposition 5.9 satisfy

$$
\left\|H_{q} \varphi\right\|_{\Lambda^{r+\delta}\left(D_{r_{4} ; 2}^{12}\right)} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon, \delta}\left(\left|\rho^{1}\right|_{\Lambda^{r+2+\delta}}\|\varphi\|_{\Lambda^{r}\left(\overline{D^{12}}\right)}+\|\varphi\|_{\Lambda^{r}\left(D^{12}\right)}\right)
$$

Moreover, $C_{r, \varepsilon, \delta}$, which is independent of $\varphi$, stable under small $C^{2}$ perturbations of $\rho^{1}$. Consequently, the homotopy formula in Proposition 5.9 can be extended uniquely to the case $r \in(0, \infty)$ so that $(5.8)$ still holds.

Proof. The last assertion follows from estimates (5.8) by a smooth approximation as Corollary 5.8.

We now derive the estimate. To ease notation, write

$$
\|\varphi\|_{\Lambda^{a}\left(D^{12}\right)}, \quad\|\varphi\|_{C^{a}\left(D^{12}\right)}, \quad\left\|H_{q} \varphi\right\|_{\Lambda^{a}\left(D_{14 / 2}^{12}\right)}, \quad\left\|H_{q} \varphi\right\|_{C^{a}\left(D_{14 / 2}^{12}\right)}
$$

as $|\varphi|_{a},\|\varphi\|_{a},\left|H_{q} \varphi\right|_{a},\left\|H_{q} \varphi\right\|_{a}$, respectively. We also write $\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{\Lambda^{a}\left(U^{1}\right)},\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{C^{a}\left(U^{1}\right)}$ as $\left|\rho^{1}\right|_{a},\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{a}$. Recall the homotopy operator

$$
H_{q} \varphi=\left(H_{q}^{(1)}+H_{q}^{(2)}+H_{q}^{(3)}\right) \varphi
$$

where $\varphi$ has type $(0, q)$ and

$$
H_{q}^{(1)} \varphi=R_{U^{1} \cup D^{12}}^{0} E \varphi+R_{U^{1}}^{[0]}(\bar{\partial}, E] \varphi
$$

Near the origin, each term in $H_{q}^{(3)} \varphi$ is a linear combination of integrals of $K_{0} f_{0}$, where $f_{0}$ is a coefficient of $\varphi$. The $K_{0} f_{0}$ is expressed as

$$
K_{0} f_{0}(z):=A\left(z, \nabla_{z} \rho^{1}, \nabla_{z}^{2} \rho^{1}\right) \tilde{K}_{0} f_{0}(z)
$$

where $\tilde{K}_{0}$, which involves only $\nabla \rho^{1}$, is defined by

$$
\tilde{K}_{0} f_{0}(z):=\int_{S^{I}} \frac{f_{0}(\zeta)(\zeta, \bar{\zeta})^{e} d V(\zeta)}{\left(g^{1}(z, \zeta) \cdot(\zeta-z)\right)^{a}\left(g^{2}(z, \zeta) \cdot(\zeta-z)\right)^{b}\left(g^{3}(z, \zeta) \cdot(\zeta-z)\right)^{c}|\zeta-z|^{2 d}}
$$

Here $a, b, c, d$ are non-negative integers, $e \in \mathbb{N}^{2 n}$, and $S^{I}$ is actually $S_{12}$. Therefore, for the $g^{1}, g^{2}, g^{3}$ that appears in the kernel, we have

$$
\left|g^{i}(z, \zeta) \cdot(\zeta-z)\right| \geq c_{0}
$$

when $z \in D_{r_{4} / 2}^{12}$ and $\zeta \in S^{I}$; see [14] for instance. Then, we have $\left|\tilde{K}_{0} f_{0}\right|_{r+\delta} \leq$ $C_{r}\left|\rho^{1}\right|_{r+1+\delta}\left\|f_{0}\right\|_{0}$ and

$$
\left|K_{0} f_{0}\right|_{r+\delta} \leq C_{r}\left|\rho^{1}\right|_{r+2+\delta}\left\|\tilde{K}_{0} f_{0}\right\|_{0}+C_{r}\left|\tilde{K}_{0} f_{0}\right|_{r+\delta}
$$
