Here and in what follows $C_{r}$ denotes a constant depending on $\nabla \rho, \nabla^{2} \rho$. Therefore, we have

$$
\left|K_{0} f_{0}\right|_{a} \leq C_{r}\left|\rho^{1}\right|_{2+a}\|f\|_{0}, \quad a>0
$$

Each term in $H_{q}^{(2)} \varphi$ is a linear combination of integrals of $K_{0} f_{0}$ which have been estimated or integrals over $S^{I}$ being one of $S^{12}, S^{2}, S_{1}^{+}$or over $U^{1}$, whose kernels do not have singularity for $z \in D_{r_{4} / 2}^{12}$. The only difference is that we need to use $\mathcal{E} \varphi$ instead of $\varphi$. Thus we need to replace $\|f\|_{0}$ by $|\mathcal{E} f|_{z}$. This shows that

$$
\left\|\left(H_{q}^{(2)}, H_{q}^{(3)}\right) \varphi\right\|_{\Lambda^{r+\delta}\left(D_{r_{4} / 2}^{12}\right)} \leq C_{r, \bar{\varepsilon}}\left|\rho^{1}\right|_{\Lambda^{r+2+\delta}}\|\varphi\|_{C^{a}\left(\overline{D^{12}}\right)}
$$

We now estimate the main term $H^{(1)} \varphi$, which is decomposed as

$$
H^{(1)} \varphi(z)=\int_{D^{12} \cup U^{1}} \Omega_{(0, q)}^{0}(z, \zeta) \wedge E \varphi(\zeta)+\int_{U^{1}} \Omega_{(0, q)}^{01}(z, \zeta) \wedge[\bar{\partial}, E] \varphi(\zeta)
$$

Denote the first integral by $K_{1} \varphi$. By an estimate on Newtonian potential [58, p. 316] (see Lemma 6.5), we have

$$
\left|K_{1} \varphi\right|_{r+1} \leq C_{r}|\varphi|_{r}, \quad r>0
$$

The last integral in (5.9) can be written as a linear combination of

$$
K_{2} f(z):=A\left(z, \nabla_{z} \rho^{1}, \nabla_{z}^{2} \rho^{1}\right) \tilde{K}_{2} f(z)
$$

where $f$ is a coefficient of the form $[\bar{\partial}, \mathcal{E}] \varphi$. By Proposition 5.3, we have

$$
|f(\zeta)| \leq C_{r}\left(D^{1}\right)|\varphi|_{r} \operatorname{dist}\left(\zeta, D^{1}\right)^{r-1}, \quad r>0
$$

Note that $f$ vanishes on $\overline{D^{12}}$. Further

$$
\begin{gathered}
\tilde{K}_{2} f(z):=\int_{U^{1}} f(\zeta) \frac{N_{1}(\zeta-z)}{\Phi^{n-j}(z, \zeta)|\zeta-z|^{2 j}} d V(\zeta), \quad 1 \leq j<n \\
\Phi(z, \zeta)=g^{1}(z, \zeta) \cdot(\zeta-z)
\end{gathered}
$$

Fix $\zeta_{0} \in \partial D^{1}$. We first choose local coordinates such that $s_{1}(\zeta), S^{t}(\zeta)$ and $t(\zeta)=\left(t_{3}, \ldots, t_{2 n}\right)(\zeta)$ vanish at $\zeta_{0}, D^{1}$ is defined by $s_{1}<0$, and

$$
\begin{gathered}
|\Phi(z, \zeta)| \geq c_{*}\left(\operatorname{dist}\left(z, \partial D^{1}\right)+s_{1}(\zeta)+\left|s_{2}(\zeta)\right|+|t(\zeta)|^{2}\right) \\
C|\zeta-z| \geq|\Phi(z, \zeta)| \geq c_{*}|\zeta-z|^{2} \\
|\zeta-z| \geq c_{*}\left(\operatorname{dist}\left(z, \partial D^{1}\right)+s_{1}(\zeta)+\left|s_{2}(\zeta)\right|+|t(\zeta)|\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

for $z \in D^{1}, \zeta \notin D^{1}$.
We have

$$
\left|K_{2} f\right|_{r+\delta} \leq C_{r}\left(\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{2}\right)\left(\left|\rho^{1}\right|_{r+2+\delta}\left\|\tilde{K}_{2} f\right\|_{0}+\left|\tilde{K}_{2} f\right|_{r+\delta}\right), \quad r>0
$$

The rest of the proof is devoted to the proof of

$$
\left|\tilde{K}_{2} f\right|_{r+\delta} \leq C_{r, \delta, \varepsilon}\left(\left|\rho^{1}\right|_{r+2}|\varphi|_{z}+|\varphi|_{r}\right), \quad r>0,0 \leq \delta \leq 1 / 2
$$

Then combining above estimates yields the proof for (5.8).
Recall that $0 \leq \delta \leq 1 / 2$. Let $r=k+\alpha$ with integer $k \geq 0$ and $0<\alpha \leq 1$. In the following cases, we will apply Lemma 5.11 several times. For clarity, we will specify values $\left(\beta, \beta^{\prime}\right)$ in Lemma 5.11 via $\left(\beta_{i}, \beta_{i}^{\prime}\right)$ when we use the lemma.
(i) $0<\alpha+\delta<1$. Recall that the kernel of $\tilde{K}_{2}$ involves only first-order derivatives of $\rho^{1}$ in $z$-variables, and it does not involve $\zeta$-derivatives of $\rho^{1}$. Further, $\Phi$ is a linear combination of $\zeta_{j}-z_{j}$. Let $\nabla^{\ell} \rho^{1}$ denote a partial derivative of $\rho^{1}(z)$ in $z, \bar{z}$ of order $\ell$. Since $\rho^{1} \in \Lambda^{k+\alpha+2+\delta} \subset C^{k+2}$, via the product and chain rules we can express $\nabla^{k+1} \tilde{K}_{2} f$ as a sum of

$$
K_{\mu, \nu}^{(k+1)} f:=\nabla^{1+\nu_{1}^{\prime}} \rho^{1} \cdots \nabla^{1+\nu_{\mu_{1}}^{\prime}} \rho^{1} K_{\mu} f
$$

Here $\mu_{1}$ is the number of times that we differentiate $\Phi(z, \zeta)$ in the numerator of the kernel of $\tilde{K}_{2} f$. Also,

$$
K_{\mu} f(z):=\int_{U^{1}} \frac{f(\zeta) N_{1-\mu_{0}+\mu_{1}-\nu_{1}^{\prime \prime}-\cdots-\nu_{\mu_{1}}^{\prime \prime}+\mu_{2}}(\zeta-z)}{(\Phi(z, \zeta))^{n-j+\mu_{1}}|\zeta-z|^{2 j+2 \mu_{2}}} d V
$$

Note that $1 \leq j<n, \nu_{i}^{\prime \prime}=0,1$, and

$$
\mu_{0}+\mu_{2}+\sum\left(\nu_{i}^{\prime}+\nu_{i}^{\prime \prime}\right) \leq k+1, \quad \nu_{i}^{\prime}+\nu_{i}^{\prime \prime} \geq 1
$$

To estimate (5.15), we use (5.11)-(5.13): For $z \in D^{1}, \zeta \in U \backslash D^{1}$ and $D^{1}$ defined by $s_{1}<0$, we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
|\Phi(z, \zeta)| \geq c_{*}\left(\operatorname{dist}\left(z, \partial D^{1}\right)+s_{1}(\zeta)+\left|s_{2}(\zeta)\right|+|t(\zeta)|^{2}\right) \\
C|\zeta-z| \geq|\Phi(z, \zeta)| \geq c_{*}|\zeta-z|^{2} \\
|\zeta-z| \geq c_{*}\left(\operatorname{dist}\left(z, \partial D^{1}\right)+s_{1}(\zeta)+\left|s_{2}(\zeta)\right|+|t(\zeta)|\right.
\end{gathered}
$$

Consequently, the worst term for $K_{\mu} f$ occurs when $j=n-1$. Note that we use $\left|\nabla \rho^{1}(z)\right| \geq c$ in (5.15). Thus, the worst term for $K_{\mu, \nu}^{(k+1)} f$ also occurs when $\mu_{0}+\mu_{2}$ is absorbed into $\sum \nu_{i}^{\prime \prime}$. Therefore, it suffices to estimate terms with $\mu_{0}=\mu_{2}=0$ and $j=n-1$, which are assumed now.

Throughout the proof, we assume that $\nu_{i}^{\prime \prime}=0$ and hence $\nu_{i}^{\prime} \geq 1$ for $i \leq \mu_{1}^{\prime}$ and $\nu_{i}^{\prime \prime}=1$ for $i>\mu_{1}^{\prime}$. Thus

$$
\mu_{1}^{\prime}+\mu_{1}^{\prime \prime}=\mu_{1}, \quad \sum_{i \leq \mu_{1}^{\prime}} \nu_{i}^{\prime}=\sum_{i \leq \mu_{1}} \nu_{i}^{\prime}
$$

Thus (5.16) is simplified in the form

$$
\begin{gathered}
K_{\mu} f(z):=\int_{G^{1}} \frac{f(\zeta) N_{1+\mu_{1}^{\prime}}(\zeta-z)}{(\Phi(z, \zeta))^{1+\mu_{1}}|\zeta-z|^{2(n-1)}} d V \\
\mu_{1} \leq \mu_{1}^{\prime \prime}+\sum_{i=1}^{\mu_{1}} \nu_{i}^{\prime} \leq \sum\left(\nu_{i}^{\prime}+\nu_{i}^{\prime \prime}\right) \leq k+1
\end{gathered}
$$

When applying Lemma 5.11, we always take

$$
\lambda:=\mu_{1}-\mu_{1}^{\prime}, \quad m=2 n-3
$$

We need $\beta_{1}>-1$ and $\beta_{1}^{\prime} \leq \beta_{1}-\frac{\mu_{1}+\lambda-3}{2}$ which are satisfied by

$$
\beta_{1}^{\prime}=\alpha+\delta-1<0, \quad \beta_{1}=\max \left\{-1+\varepsilon, \alpha+\delta-1+\frac{\mu_{1}+\lambda-3}{2}\right\}
$$

Assume that $0<\varepsilon<r$. Clearly, $\beta_{1}>-1$. Using $\lambda=\mu_{1}-\mu_{1}^{\prime}$ and (5.18), we can verify that $\beta_{1} \leq k+\alpha+\delta-3 / 2 \leq r-1$. By Lemma 5.11, we obtain for $z \in D_{r_{4} / 2}^{12}$,

$$
\left|K_{\mu} f(z)\right| \leq|\varphi|_{\beta_{1}+1} \operatorname{dist}\left(z, \partial D^{1}\right)^{\beta_{1}^{\prime}}
$$

Thus,

$$
\left|K_{\mu, \nu}^{(k+1)} f(z)\right| \leq C\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{1+\nu_{1}^{\prime}} \cdots\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{1+\nu_{\mu_{1}}^{\prime}}|\varphi|_{\beta_{1}+1} \operatorname{dist}\left(z, \partial D^{1}\right)^{\alpha+\delta-1}
$$

When $\beta_{1}=\varepsilon-1$ or all $\nu_{i}^{\prime} \leq 1$, we obtain (5.14) from

$$
\left|K_{\mu, \nu}^{(k+1)} f(z)\right| \leq C \max \left\{\left|\rho^{1}\right|_{k+2}|\varphi|_{\varepsilon},|\varphi|_{r}\right\} \operatorname{dist}\left(z, D^{1}\right)^{\alpha+\delta-1}
$$

Assume now that $\beta_{1}>\varepsilon-1$ and $\nu_{1}^{\prime} \geq 2$. Thus $\mu_{1}^{\prime} \geq 1$. Let $x_{+}=\max \{0, x\}$ and

$$
\gamma:=\sum\left(\nu_{i}^{\prime}-1\right)_{+}=-\mu_{1}^{\prime}+\sum \nu_{i}^{\prime}
$$

Then $\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{1+\nu_{1}^{\prime}} \cdots\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{1+\nu_{\mu_{1}}^{\prime}} \leq\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{2+\gamma}$. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\beta_{1}+1\right)+\gamma & \leq\left[\alpha+\delta+\frac{\mu_{1}+\lambda-3}{2}\right]-\mu_{1}^{\prime}+\sum \nu_{i}^{\prime}=\alpha+\delta-\frac{\mu_{1}^{\prime}+1}{2}+\mu_{1}^{\prime \prime}+\sum \nu_{i}^{\prime} \\
& \leq \alpha+\delta-\frac{\mu_{1}^{\prime}+3}{2}+k \leq r-\frac{1}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

where the second inequality is obtained by (5.18) and $\mu_{1}^{\prime} \geq 1$. Therefore, (5.14) follows from

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{1+\nu_{1}^{\prime}} \cdots\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{1+\nu_{\mu_{1}}^{\prime}}|\varphi|_{\beta_{1}+1} \leq C_{r}\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{2+\gamma}\|\varphi\|_{\beta_{1}+1} \\
& \quad \leq C_{r}^{\prime}\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{2}\|\varphi\|_{1+\beta_{1}+\gamma}+C_{r}^{\prime}\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{3+\gamma+\beta_{1}}\|\varphi\|_{0} \leq C_{r}^{\prime \prime}|\varphi|_{r}+C_{r}^{\prime \prime}\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{r+3 / 2}\|\varphi\|_{0}
\end{aligned}
$$

(ii) $1<\alpha+\delta \leq 3 / 2$. In this case we can take an extra derivative since $\rho^{1} \in$ $\Lambda^{k+\alpha+2+\delta} \subset C^{k+3}$. Write $\nabla^{k+2} \tilde{K}_{2} f$ as a sum of

$$
K_{\mu, \nu}^{(k+2)} f:=\nabla^{1+\nu_{1}^{\prime}} \rho^{1} \cdots \nabla^{1+\nu_{\mu_{1}}^{\prime}} \rho^{1} K_{\mu} f
$$

where $K_{\mu} f$ is defined by (5.16). As before, the worst term occurs for $j=n-1$ and $\mu_{0}=\mu_{2}=0$ in $K_{\mu}$, which are assumed now. Then (5.18) in which $k$ is replaced by $k+1$ becomes

$$
\mu_{1} \leq \mu_{1}^{\prime \prime}+\sum_{i=1}^{\mu_{1}} \nu_{i}^{\prime} \leq k+2
$$

To apply Lemma 5.11, we need to $\beta_{2}>-1$ and $\beta_{2}^{\prime} \leq \beta_{2}-\left(\mu_{1}+\lambda-3\right) / 2$. Thus, we take

$$
\beta_{2}^{\prime}=\alpha+\delta-2<0, \quad \beta_{2}=\max \left\{\varepsilon-1, \alpha+\delta-2+\frac{\mu_{1}+\lambda-3}{2}\right\}
$$

Recall $\lambda=\mu_{1}-\mu_{1}^{\prime}$. We can verify that $\beta_{2} \leq r-1$. We obtain for $z \in D_{r_{2}}^{12}$

$$
\left|K_{\mu, \nu}^{(k+2)} f(z)\right| \leq C_{r}\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{1+\nu_{1}^{\prime}} \cdots\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{1+\nu_{\mu_{1}}^{\prime}}|\varphi|_{\beta_{2}+1} \operatorname{dist}\left(z, \partial D^{1}\right)^{\alpha+\delta-1}
$$

When $\beta_{2}=\varepsilon-1$ or all $\nu_{i}^{\prime} \leq 1$, we have (5.19)-(5.20) in which $\beta_{1}^{\prime}, \beta_{1}$ are replaced by $\beta_{2}^{\prime}, \beta_{2}$ respectively. Thus, we get

$$
\left|K_{\mu}(z)\right| \leq C_{r}|\varphi|_{r} \operatorname{dist}\left(z, D^{1}\right)^{\alpha+\delta-1}
$$

Assume now $\beta_{2}>\varepsilon-1$ and $\nu_{1}^{\prime} \geq 2$. Thus $\mu_{1}^{\prime} \geq 1$. Let $\gamma$ be given by (5.21). Then we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\beta_{2}+1\right)+\gamma & \leq\left[\alpha+\delta+\frac{\mu_{1}+\lambda-5}{2}\right]-\mu_{1}^{\prime}+\sum \nu_{i}^{\prime} \\
& =\alpha+\delta-\frac{\mu_{1}^{\prime}+5}{2}+\mu_{1}^{\prime \prime}+\sum \nu_{i}^{\prime} \leq \alpha+\delta-\frac{\mu_{1}^{\prime}+1}{2}+k \leq r-\frac{1}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

As in previous case, we get

$$
\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{1+\nu_{1}^{\prime}} \cdots\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{1+\nu_{\mu_{1}}^{\prime}}|\varphi|_{\beta_{2}+1} \leq C_{r}\left(|\varphi|_{r}+\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{r+3 / 2}\|\varphi\|_{\varepsilon}\right)
$$

(iii) $\alpha+\delta=1$. Thus $\alpha \geq 1 / 2$. We need to estimate $\left|\tilde{K}_{2} f\right|_{r+\delta}$ with $r+\delta=k+1$. Recall that $\rho^{1} \in \Lambda^{k+3}$. On $D_{r_{3} / 2}^{12}$, we write $\nabla^{k} \tilde{K}_{2} f$ as a sum of

$$
K_{\mu, \nu}^{(k)} f:=\nabla^{1+\nu_{1}^{\prime}} \rho^{1} \cdots \nabla^{1+\nu_{\mu_{1}}^{\prime}} \rho^{1} K_{\mu} f
$$

To estimate $\left|K_{\mu, \nu}^{(k)} f\right|_{1}$, we will use Lemmas 5.10 and 5.11 to estimate $\left|K_{\mu} f\right|_{1}$.
As before, the worst term occurs for $j=n-1$ and $\mu_{0}=\mu_{2}=0$ in $K_{\mu}$, which are assumed now. Then $K_{\mu} f$ has the form (5.17), while (5.18) has the form

$$
\mu_{1} \leq \mu_{1}^{\prime \prime}+\sum_{i=1}^{\mu_{1}} \nu_{i}^{\prime} \leq k
$$

By (3.2), we have up to a constant factor

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|K_{\mu, \nu}^{(k)} f\right|_{1} \leq & \left|\nabla^{1+\nu_{1}^{\prime}} \rho^{1} \cdots \nabla^{1+\nu_{\mu_{1}}^{\prime}} \rho^{1}\right|_{1}\left\|K_{\mu} f\right\|_{0} \\
& +\left\|\nabla^{1+\nu_{1}^{\prime}} \rho^{1} \cdots \nabla^{1+\nu_{\mu_{1}}^{\prime}} \rho^{1}\right\|_{0}\left|K_{\mu} f\right|_{1}=: \mathrm{I}+\mathrm{II}
\end{aligned}
$$

We first estimate I. We set

$$
\beta_{3}^{\prime}=\varepsilon, \quad \beta_{3}=\max \left\{\varepsilon-1, \beta_{3}^{\prime}+\frac{\mu_{1}+\lambda-3}{2}\right\}
$$

Then we use Lemma 5.11 for $\beta_{3}^{\prime}>0$, which yields

$$
\left\|K_{\mu} f\right\|_{0} \leq|\varphi|_{\beta_{3}+1}
$$

Here we take $0<\varepsilon<r$ and recall $\lambda=\mu_{1}-\mu_{1}^{\prime}$. Then we have $\beta_{3} \leq r-1$. Also,

$$
\left\|\nabla^{1+\nu_{1}^{\prime}} \rho^{1} \cdots \nabla^{1+\nu_{r_{1}}^{\prime}} \rho^{1}\right\|_{1} \leq C_{r} \sum\left\|\nabla^{2+\nu_{i}^{\prime}} \rho^{1}\right\|_{0} \prod_{j \neq i}\left\|\nabla^{1+\nu_{j}^{\prime}} \rho^{1}\right\|_{0} \leq C_{r}^{\prime}\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{2+\tilde{\gamma}}
$$

with $\tilde{\gamma}=\sum \nu_{i}^{\prime}$. When $\beta_{3}=\varepsilon-1$ or all $\nu_{i}^{\prime} \leq 1$, we get (5.19)-(5.20) in which $\beta_{1}^{\prime}, \beta_{1}$ are replaced by $\beta_{3}^{\prime}, \beta_{3}$ respectively. Thus, we get

$$
\mathrm{I} \leq C_{r} \max \left\{\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{r+2}\|\varphi\|_{\varepsilon},|\varphi|_{r}\right\}
$$

Assume that $\beta_{3}>\varepsilon-1$ and some $\nu_{i}^{\prime} \geq 2$. Then $\mu_{1}^{\prime} \geq 1$ and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\beta_{3}+1\right)+\tilde{\gamma} & \leq \frac{\mu_{1}+\lambda-1}{2}+\varepsilon+\sum \nu_{i}^{\prime} \\
& =\varepsilon-\frac{\mu_{1}^{\prime}}{2}-\frac{1}{2}+\mu_{1}^{\prime \prime}+\sum \nu_{i}^{\prime} \leq \varepsilon-\frac{\mu_{1}^{\prime}}{2}-\frac{1}{2}+k \leq r-1+\varepsilon
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, we get

$$
\mathrm{I} \leq C_{r}\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{2+\tilde{\gamma}}\|\varphi\|_{1+\beta_{3}} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}^{\prime}\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{2}\|\varphi\|_{r-1+\varepsilon}+C_{r, \varepsilon}^{\prime}\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{r+1+\varepsilon}\|\varphi\|_{0}
$$

Finally, we estimate II in (5.23). Lemma 5.10 says that we can estimate $\left|K_{\mu} f\right|_{1}$ via the pointwise estimate of $\nabla^{2} K_{\mu} f$. Write $\nabla^{2} K_{\mu} f$ as a sum of

$$
K_{\tilde{\mu}, \tilde{\nu}}^{(k)} f:=\nabla^{1+\tilde{\nu}_{1}^{\prime}} \rho^{1} \cdots \nabla^{1+\tilde{\nu}_{p_{1}}^{\prime}} \rho^{1} K_{\mu+\tilde{\mu}} f
$$

with

$$
\tilde{\mu}_{1} \leq \tilde{\mu}_{1}^{\prime \prime}+\sum \tilde{\nu}_{i}^{\prime} \leq 2
$$

The worst terms occur in the forms

$$
\mathrm{II}^{\prime}:=\nabla^{3} \rho^{1} K_{\mu+\tilde{\mu}} f, \quad \mathrm{II}^{\prime \prime}:=\nabla \rho^{1} \nabla^{2} \rho^{1} K_{\mu+\tilde{\mu}} f
$$

for $\tilde{\mu}=1$ and $\tilde{\tilde{\mu}}=2$, respectively.
We first estimate $\mathrm{II}^{\prime}$ where $\tilde{\mu}=1$. We have

$$
K_{\mu+\tilde{\mu}} f(z):=\int_{U^{1}} \frac{f(\zeta) N_{1+\mu_{1}^{\prime}+\tilde{\mu}_{1}^{\prime}}(\zeta-z)}{\left(\Phi(z, \zeta)\right)^{1+\mu_{1}+\tilde{\mu}_{1}}|\zeta-z|^{2(n-1)}} d V(\zeta)
$$

Note that the worst term occurs when $\tilde{\mu}_{1}=\tilde{\mu}=1$. Let us combine the indices as follows. Set $\hat{\mu}=\mu+\tilde{\mu}=\mu+1, \hat{\mu}_{1}=\mu_{1}+\tilde{\mu}_{1}=\mu_{1}+1$. Set $\hat{\nu}_{i}^{\prime}=\nu_{i}^{\prime}$ for $i \leq \mu_{1}$, $\hat{\nu}_{\hat{\mu}_{1}}^{\prime}=2$. The latter implies

$$
\hat{\mu}_{1}^{\prime}=\mu_{1}^{\prime}+1 \geq 1
$$

Set $\hat{\lambda}=\hat{\mu}_{1}^{\prime \prime}=\hat{\mu}_{1}-\hat{\mu}_{1}^{\prime}$. Then $\hat{\mu}_{1}^{\prime \prime}=\mu_{1}^{\prime \prime}$. We get

$$
\hat{\mu}_{1} \leq \hat{\mu}_{1}^{\prime \prime}+\sum \hat{\nu}_{i}^{\prime}=\mu_{1}^{\prime \prime}+2+\sum \nu_{i}^{\prime} \leq k+2
$$

Thus, we set

$$
\beta_{4}^{\prime}=\varepsilon-1, \quad \beta_{4}=\max \left\{\varepsilon-1, \beta_{4}^{\prime}+\frac{\hat{\mu}_{1}+\hat{\lambda}-3}{2}\right\}
$$

Then

$$
\left|\mathrm{II}^{\prime}(z)\right| \leq C_{r}\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{1+\tilde{\nu}_{1}^{\prime}}|\varphi|_{\beta_{4}+1} \operatorname{dist}\left(z, \partial D^{1}\right)^{\beta_{4}^{\prime}}, \quad \tilde{\nu}_{1}^{\prime}=2
$$

For the new indices, let $\tilde{\gamma}=\sum\left(\hat{\nu}_{i}^{\prime}-1\right)_{+}$. We have

$$
\left\|\nabla^{1+\tilde{\nu}_{1}^{\prime}} \rho^{1} \cdots \nabla^{1+\tilde{\nu}_{p_{1}}^{\prime}} \rho^{1}\right\|_{0} \leq C_{r}\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{2+\tilde{\gamma}}
$$

Assume first that $\beta_{4}>\varepsilon-1$. Then by $\hat{\mu}_{1}^{\prime} \geq 1$, we get
$\left(\beta_{4}+1\right)+\hat{\gamma} \leq\left[\varepsilon-\frac{3}{2}+\frac{\hat{\mu}_{1}+\hat{\lambda}}{2}\right]-\hat{\mu}_{1}^{\prime}+\sum \hat{\nu}_{i}^{\prime}=\varepsilon-\frac{\hat{\mu}_{1}^{\prime}}{2}-\frac{3}{2}+(k+2) \leq r-\alpha+\varepsilon$.
Since $\alpha=1-\delta \geq 1 / 2$, we obtain the desired estimate for $\left|\mathrm{II}^{\prime}(z)\right|$ from

$$
\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{2+\hat{\gamma}}|\varphi|_{1+\beta_{4}} \leq C_{r}^{\prime}\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{r+1 / 2}\|\varphi\|_{1}+C_{r}^{\prime}\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{2}\|\varphi\|_{r-1 / 2+\varepsilon}
$$

When $\beta_{4}=\varepsilon-1$, with $k \geq 0$ and (5.22) we simply use $\hat{\gamma}=1+\sum\left(\nu_{i}^{\prime}-1\right)_{+} \leq$ $k \leq r-1 / 2$. Thus $\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{2+\hat{\gamma}}\|\varphi\|_{1+\beta_{4}} \leq C_{r}\left\|\rho^{1}\right\|_{r+3 / 2}\|\varphi\|_{\varepsilon}$, which gives us the desired estimate.

We now estimate $\mathrm{II}^{\prime \prime}$. Then we have $\tilde{\tilde{\mu}}=2$, and hence $K_{\mu+\tilde{\tilde{\mu}}} f(z)$ has the form (5.24) in which $\tilde{\mu}, \tilde{\mu}_{1}^{\prime}, \tilde{\mu}_{1}$ are replaced by $\tilde{\tilde{\mu}}, \tilde{\tilde{\mu}}_{1}^{\prime}, \tilde{\tilde{\mu}}_{1}$ respectively with

$$
\tilde{\tilde{\mu}}_{1} \leq \tilde{\tilde{\mu}}_{1}^{\prime \prime}+\sum \tilde{\tilde{\nu}}_{i}^{\prime} \leq 2
$$

The worst term occurs when $\tilde{\tilde{\mu}}_{1}=2$. Let us combine the indices as before. Set $\hat{\mu}=\mu+2, \hat{\mu}_{1}=\mu_{1}+\tilde{\tilde{\mu}}_{1}, \hat{\mu}_{1}^{\prime}=\mu_{1}^{\prime}+\tilde{\tilde{\mu}}^{\prime}$, and $\hat{\lambda}=\hat{\mu}_{1}^{\prime \prime}=\mu_{1}^{\prime \prime}+\tilde{\tilde{\mu}}^{\prime \prime}$. Let $\hat{\nu}_{i}^{\prime}=\nu_{i}^{\prime}$ for $i \leq \mu_{1}$ and $\hat{\nu}_{\hat{\mu}_{1}}^{\prime}=2$. The latter implies $\hat{\mu}_{1}^{\prime}=\mu_{1}^{\prime}+1 \geq 1$. Then

$$
\hat{\mu}_{1}^{\prime \prime}+\sum \hat{\nu}_{i}^{\prime} \leq k+2
$$

Thus, we set

$$
\beta_{5}^{\prime}=\varepsilon-1, \quad \beta_{5}=\max \left\{\varepsilon-1, \beta_{5}^{\prime}+\frac{\hat{\mu}_{1}+\hat{\lambda}-3}{2}\right\}
$$

Then $\left|K_{\mu+\tilde{\tilde{\mu}}} f(z)\right| \leq C_{r}|\varphi|_{\beta_{5}+1} \operatorname{dist}\left(z, \partial D^{1}\right)^{\beta_{5}^{\prime}}$. The values of $\beta_{5}, \beta_{5}^{\prime}, \hat{\mu}_{1}^{\prime}$, and condition (5.25) are the same as in the previous case. The same computation yields the desired estimate for $\mathrm{II}^{\prime}$.

# 6. Globalizing local homotopy formulas via $\bar{\partial}$-Neumann operators 

In this section, we will apply the $C^{\infty}$ regularity of the $\bar{\partial}$-Neumann operators $N_{q}, N_{q+1}$ for $a_{q}^{+}$domains. We will need only the interior regularity of $N_{q}, N_{q+1}$ and their boundedness in $L^{2}$ spaces.
6.1. Grauert bumping. We start with the following.

Lemma 6.1 ([14, Lem. 8.1]). Let $M \subset \mathcal{M}$ be a domain defined by a $C^{2}$ function $\rho<0$ and let $M^{a}$ be defined by $\rho<a$. Let $\rho_{t}=S^{t} \rho$, where $S^{t}$ is the Moser smoothing operator. Suppose that $M$ is an $a_{q}$ domain. Let $\left(M_{t}\right)^{a}$ be defined by $\rho_{t}<a$. There exist $t_{0}=t_{0}\left(\nabla^{2} \rho\right)>0$ and $C>1>c>0$ such that if $0 \leq t<t_{0}$, then

$$
\partial\left(M_{t}\right)^{-t} \subset M^{-c t} \backslash M^{-C t}, \quad \partial\left(M_{t}\right)^{t} \subset M^{C t} \backslash M^{c t}
$$

while $M^{b}$ and $\left(M_{t}\right)^{b}$ still satisfy the condition $a_{q}$ for $b \in\left(-t_{0}, t_{0}\right)$.
We also need the following family of smooth subdomains that touch given boundary points of a $C^{2}$ domain. This special smoothing will be used in Subsection 8.4.

Lemma 6.2. Let $M, \rho$ be as above. Let $\zeta \in b M$ and $\varepsilon>0$. There exists a real function $\hat{\rho} \in C^{\infty}(\mathcal{M})$ satisfying $\hat{\rho}(\zeta)=0, \widetilde{M}:=\{\hat{\rho}<0\}$ is contained in $M$, and $\|\hat{\rho}-\hat{\rho}\|_{C^{2}(\mathcal{M})}<\varepsilon$, where $\hat{\rho}$ is a suitable $C^{2}$ defining function of $M$.

Proof. We will use a smooth coordinate map $\psi: U \subset \mathcal{M} \rightarrow(-1,1)^{2 n}$ such that $\psi(\zeta)=0$ and $\rho_{1}=\rho \circ \psi^{-1}=u \hat{\rho}$ with

$$
\hat{\rho}(x)=-x_{1}+Q(x)+R(x)
$$

where $Q$ is a quadratic polynomial, $|R(x)| \leq \varepsilon \varepsilon_{1}^{2}$ when $|x|<\varepsilon_{1}$, and $u>0$. Here $\varepsilon_{1}$ and $\varepsilon_{2}, \varepsilon_{3}$ below are to be determined. Note that $R \in C^{2}$. Set

$$
\hat{\rho}_{\varepsilon}(x):=-x_{1}+Q(x)+\varepsilon|x|^{2}
$$

Let $\chi: \mathbb{E}^{2 n} \rightarrow[0,1]$ be a smooth function having compact support in the unit ball $B_{1}$ and value 1 on $B_{1 / 2}$. Let $\chi_{\varepsilon}$ be the trivial extension of $\chi\left(\varepsilon^{-1} \psi\right)$ being 0 on $M \backslash U$. Define

$$
\rho_{\varepsilon}=\left(1-\chi_{\varepsilon_{1}}\right)\left(S^{t} \rho+\varepsilon_{2}\right)+\chi_{\varepsilon_{1}} \hat{\rho}_{\varepsilon_{3}} \circ \psi, \quad \rho_{2}:=\left(1-\chi_{\varepsilon_{1}}\right) \rho+\chi_{\varepsilon_{1}} \hat{\rho} \circ \psi
$$

Then $\rho_{\varepsilon}-\rho_{2}=\left(\varepsilon_{2}+S^{t} \rho-\rho\right)\left(1-\chi_{\varepsilon_{1}}\right)+\chi_{\varepsilon_{1}}\left(\hat{\rho}_{\varepsilon_{3}}-\hat{\rho}\right) \circ \psi$. Thus, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\rho_{\varepsilon}-\rho_{2}\right\|_{C^{2}} \leq & \varepsilon_{2}\left\|1-\chi_{\varepsilon_{1}}\right\|_{2}+C\left\|S^{t} \rho-\rho\right\|_{0}\left\|1-\chi_{\varepsilon_{1}}\right\|_{2} \\
& +C\left\|S^{t} \rho-\rho\right\|_{C^{2}}+\left\|\chi_{\varepsilon_{1}}\left(\hat{\rho}_{\varepsilon_{3}}-\hat{\rho}\right) \circ \psi\right\|_{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

The first two terms are less than $\varepsilon$, provided

$$
\varepsilon_{2} \varepsilon_{1}^{-2}<\varepsilon / C, \quad t^{2}\|\rho\|_{2} \varepsilon_{1}^{-2}<\varepsilon / C
$$

When $t<t_{0}$ for $t_{0}$ depending on the module of continuity of $\nabla^{2} \rho$, we have $\| S^{t} \rho-$ $\rho \|_{C^{2}}<\varepsilon$. We have by a direct computation via the product rule

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\chi_{\varepsilon_{1}}\left(\hat{\rho}_{\varepsilon_{3}}-\hat{\rho}\right) \circ \psi\right\|_{C^{2}} \leq & C\left(\varepsilon_{1}^{-2} \varepsilon_{3}+\varepsilon_{1}^{-2}\|R\|_{C^{0}\left(B_{\varepsilon_{1}}\right)}\right. \\
& \left.+\varepsilon_{1}^{-1}\|\nabla R\|_{C^{0}\left(B_{\varepsilon_{1}}\right)}+\left\|\nabla^{2} R\right\|_{C^{0}\left(B_{\varepsilon_{1}}\right)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We assume $\varepsilon_{1}^{-2} \varepsilon_{3}<\varepsilon / C$. We also choose $\delta\left(\nabla^{2} R\right)>0$ so that $\varepsilon_{1}<\delta\left(\nabla^{2} R\right)$ implies that the last three term in (6.1) are less than $\varepsilon / C$.

On the support of $\chi_{\varepsilon_{1}}$ except at $x_{0}$, we have $\hat{\rho}_{\varepsilon}-\hat{\rho}>0$ for small $\varepsilon_{1}$. On $\bar{M}$, we have $S^{t} \rho+\varepsilon_{2}-\rho>\varepsilon_{2}-C_{2}\|\rho\|_{2} t^{2}>0$. Therefore, $\left\{\rho_{\varepsilon}<0\right\}$ is contained in $M$.

Lemma 6.3. Let $q>0, r \in(0, \infty), \varepsilon>0$ and $0 \leq \delta \leq 1 / 2$. Let $M \Subset \mathcal{M}$ be an $a_{q}^{+}$domain with a $C^{2}$ defining function $\rho$. For each $p \in b M$ and any open set $U_{0}$ containing $p$, there are open sets $U_{1}, U_{2}$ such that $p \in U_{2} \Subset U_{1} \Subset U_{0}$ and on $U_{2} \cap M$

$$
\varphi=\bar{\partial} T_{U_{1}, \rho ; q} \varphi+T_{U_{1}, \rho ; q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi
$$

where $\varphi \in \Lambda_{(0, q)}^{r}\left(U_{1} \cap M, V\right)$ and $\bar{\partial} \varphi \in \Lambda_{(0, q+1)}^{r}\left(U_{1} \cap M, V\right)$. Furthermore, There exists $M_{1}$ that is defined by $\rho_{1}<0$ with $\left|\rho_{1}-\rho\right|_{a}<C_{a} \varepsilon$ for all $a>0$ satisfies the following:
(a) The domain $M_{1}$ satisfies the $a_{q}^{+}$condition, $M \cup \omega \subset M_{1} \subset M \cup U_{0}$ and $\omega \cap b M$ is independent of $\varepsilon$.
(b) Let $\tilde{\varphi}=0$ on $\overline{M_{1} \backslash M}$ and $\tilde{\varphi}=\varphi-\bar{\partial}\left(\chi T_{q} \varphi\right)-\chi T_{q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi$ on $\bar{M}$. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
|\tilde{\varphi}|_{M_{1}, r} & \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}\left(\nabla \rho^{1}, \nabla^{2} \rho^{1}\right)\left(\left|\rho^{1}\right|_{r+2}^{*}|\varphi|_{M^{12}, \varepsilon}+|\varphi|_{r}\right) \\
\left.|\tilde{\varphi}\right|_{M_{1}, r+\delta} & \leq C_{r, \delta, \varepsilon}\left(\nabla \rho^{1}, \nabla^{2} \rho^{1}\right)\left(\left|\rho^{1}\right|_{r+2+\delta}^{*}|\varphi|_{M, \varepsilon}+|\varphi|_{r}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The same estimates hold if $\varphi, \tilde{\varphi}$ are replaced by $\bar{\partial} \varphi, \bar{\partial} \tilde{\varphi}$, respectively. Moreover, $C_{r, \delta, \varepsilon}\left(\nabla \rho^{1}, \nabla^{2} \rho^{1}\right), C_{r, \varepsilon}\left(\nabla \rho^{1}, \nabla^{2} \rho^{1}\right)$ are stable under $C^{2}$ perturbation of $\rho$.

Proof. By a straightforward computation, we have

$$
\tilde{\varphi}=(1-\chi) \varphi-\bar{\partial}_{\chi} \wedge T_{q} \varphi \quad \text { on } M, \quad \tilde{\varphi}=0 \quad \text { on } U_{2}
$$

Then $\bar{\partial} \tilde{\varphi}=(1-\chi) \bar{\partial} \varphi-\bar{\partial}_{\chi} \wedge \varphi+\bar{\partial}_{\chi} \wedge \bar{\partial} T_{q} \varphi$ on $M$. Thus

$$
\bar{\partial} \tilde{\varphi}=(1-\chi) \bar{\partial} \varphi-\bar{\partial}_{\chi} \wedge T_{q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi \quad \text { on } M
$$

Thus, $\tilde{\varphi}, \bar{\partial} \tilde{\varphi}$ satisfy the same kind of relations. It suffices to estimate $\tilde{\varphi}$.
Choose a nonnegative $\tilde{\chi} \in C_{0}^{\infty}\left(U_{2}\right)$ such that $\tilde{\chi} \geq 0$ and $\tilde{\chi}=1$ on an open set $U_{3}$ with $p \in U_{3} \Subset U_{2}$. Let $\rho_{1}=\rho-\varepsilon \tilde{\chi}$.

For any $\varepsilon>0$, it is clearly that $M_{1}: \rho_{1}<0$ contains $U_{3} \cap b M$ and the latter is independent of $\varepsilon$. Hence, we can find an open neighborhood $\omega$ of $p$ such that $M \cup \omega \subset M_{1}$ and $\omega \cap b M$ is independent of $\varepsilon$ and contains $U_{3} \cap b M$.

Proposition 6.4. Let $M, \rho$ be as in Lemma 6.3. Let $r \in(0, \infty), \varepsilon>0$ and $0 \leq \delta \leq 1 / 2$. Then there exists an approximate homotopy formula

$$
\varphi=\bar{\partial} T_{q} \varphi+T_{q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi+K_{q}^{0} \varphi \quad \text { on } M
$$

where the operators $K_{q}^{0}, T_{q}, T_{q+1}$ satisfy

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left|K^{0} \varphi\right|_{\widetilde{M}, r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}\left(\nabla \rho^{1}, \nabla^{2} \rho^{1}\right)|\rho|_{2+\varepsilon}^{* b}|\varphi|_{M, r} \\
\left|\bar{\partial} K^{0} \varphi\right|_{\widetilde{M}, r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}\left(\nabla \rho^{1}, \nabla^{2} \rho^{1}\right)|\rho|_{2+\varepsilon}^{* b}|\bar{\partial} \varphi|_{M, r}
\end{gathered}
$$

$$
\left|T_{j} \psi\right|_{M, r+\delta} \leq C_{r, \delta, \varepsilon}\left(\nabla \rho^{1}, \nabla^{2} \rho^{1}\right)\left(|\rho|_{r+2+\delta}^{* b}|\rho|_{2+\varepsilon}^{* b}|\psi|_{D, \varepsilon}+|\psi|_{M, r}\right)
$$

Here, $\widetilde{M} \otimes M$, and constants $b \geq 1, C_{r, \varepsilon}\left(\nabla \rho^{1}, \nabla^{2} \rho^{1}\right)$, and $C_{r, \delta, \varepsilon}\left(\nabla \rho^{1}, \nabla^{2} \rho^{1}\right)$ are stable under small $C^{2}$ perturbations of $\rho$.

Proof. Denote the $U_{i}, \omega, \rho_{1}, \chi, \tilde{\chi}$ in Lemma 6.3 by $U_{i}(p), \omega_{p}, \rho_{1, p}, \chi_{p}, \tilde{\chi}_{p}$ as they depend on $p$. By Lemma 6.3, we can find finitely many points $p_{1}, \ldots, p_{N}$ in $b M$ that are independent of $\varepsilon$ and open sets $\omega_{p_{1}}, \ldots, \omega_{p_{N}}$ such that $b M \subset \cup \omega_{p_{j}}$. Let $\varphi_{0}=\varphi$ and $\rho_{0}=\rho$. Let $\rho_{j}=\rho_{j-1}-\varepsilon \tilde{\chi}_{p_{j}}$.

Now, $M^{j}$ is a small perturbation of $M$, so there exist operators $T_{j, q}, T_{j, q+1}$ with $\varphi=\bar{\partial} T_{j, q} \varphi+T_{j, q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi$ on $U_{1}\left(p_{j}\right) \cap M^{j}$. For simplicity, we have written $T_{j, q}:=T_{U_{1}\left(p_{j}\right), \rho_{j-1} ; q}$ and $T_{j, q+1}:=T_{U_{1}\left(p_{j}\right), \rho_{j-1} ; q+1}$. We now copy the definition of $\tilde{\varphi}$ via $\varphi$ in Lemma $6.3(b)$. For $j \geq 0$, we thus define

$$
\varphi_{j+1}= \begin{cases}\varphi_{j}-\bar{\partial}\left(\chi_{p_{j+1}} T_{j+1, q} \varphi_{j}\right)-\chi_{p_{j+1}} T_{j+1 ; q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi_{j}, & \text { on } M^{j} \\ =0, & \text { on } M^{j+1} \backslash M^{j}\end{cases}
$$

Then $K_{q}^{0} \varphi:=\varphi_{N}$ and

$$
T_{q} \varphi:=\sum_{j=1}^{N} \chi_{p_{j}} T_{j, q} \varphi_{j-1}, \quad T_{q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi:=\sum_{j=1}^{N} \chi_{p_{j}} T_{j, q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi_{j-1}
$$

have the desired estimates by applying the estimates in Lemma 6.3 inductively and taking $\widetilde{M}=M_{N}$.

Note that the $b \leq C N$ is determined by the number of bumps that are used. Thus, $b$ is stable under $C^{2}$ perturbations of $\rho$.

Next, we want to achieve interior $C^{\infty}$ smoothing via the homotopy formula on the coordinate balls. We need the an interior estimate which follows easily from [58].

Lemma 6.5. Let $U_{r}:=\left\{z \in \mathbb{C}^{n}:\|z\|<r\right\}$. Then for any $C^{1}(0, q)$ form $\varphi$ on $U_{1}$ with $q>0$, we have $\varphi=\bar{\partial} B_{q} \varphi+B_{q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi$. Furthermore, for $i=q, q+1$ and $s>0$ we have for $0<r_{1}<r_{2}<1$

$$
\left|B_{i} \psi\right|_{U_{r_{1}}, s+1} \leq \frac{C_{r}}{\left(\min \left(1-r_{2}, r_{2}-r_{1}\right)\right)^{s+C_{n}}}\left(\left|\psi\right|_{U_{r_{2}}, s}+\|\psi\|_{U_{1}, 0}\right)
$$

Note that by a partition of unity, we obtain for open sets $U^{\prime} \Subset U^{\prime \prime} \Subset U_{1}$,

$$
\left|B_{i} \psi\right|_{U^{\prime}, s+1} \leq \frac{C_{r}}{\left(\min \left(\operatorname{dist}\left(U^{\prime}, \partial U^{\prime \prime}\right), \operatorname{dist}\left(U^{\prime \prime}, \partial U_{1}\right)\right)\right)^{s+C_{n}}}\left(\left|\psi\right|_{U^{\prime \prime}, s}+\|\psi\|_{U_{1}, 0}\right)
$$

Proposition 6.6. Let $M$ be a domain in a complex manifold $\mathcal{M}$ and let $\varphi$ be a $(0, q)$ form defined on $\widetilde{M}$ with $q>0$. Suppose that $M$ is relatively compact in $\widetilde{M}$. Then there exist linear operators $B_{j}$ such that $K_{q}^{1} \varphi:=\varphi-\bar{\partial} B_{q} \varphi-B_{q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi$ satisfies

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left|K_{q}^{1} \varphi\right|_{\widetilde{M}, r} \leq C_{r}\|\varphi\|_{\Lambda^{r}(\widetilde{M})}, \quad\left\|K_{q}^{1} \varphi\right\|_{M, r} \leq C_{r}\|\varphi\|_{\widetilde{M}, 0} \\
\left|\bar{\partial} K_{q}^{1} \varphi\right|_{\widetilde{M}, r} \leq C_{r}\|\bar{\partial} \varphi\|_{\widetilde{M}, r}, \quad\left\|\bar{\partial} K_{q}^{1} \varphi\right\|_{M, r} \leq C_{r}\|\bar{\partial} \varphi\|_{\widetilde{M}, 0} \\
\left\|B_{j} \psi\right\|_{\Lambda^{r+1}(M)} \leq C_{r}|\psi|_{\Lambda^{r}(\widetilde{M})}, j=q, q+1, \quad \forall r>0
\end{gathered}
$$

In particular, $K_{q}^{1} \varphi \in C^{\infty}(M)$ for $\varphi \in C^{0}(\widetilde{M})$.
Proof. We first find $p_{1}, \ldots, p_{N} \in \bar{M}$ and coordinate balls $\omega_{j}, \omega_{j}^{\prime}, U_{j}$ such that $p_{j} \in$ $\omega_{j} \Subset \omega_{j}^{\prime} \Subset U_{j}$ and $\bar{M} \subset \cup_{j=1}^{N} \omega_{j} \Subset \widetilde{M}$. We may assume that $U_{j} \Subset \widetilde{M}$ are coordinate balls centered at $p_{j}$. We also have a homotopy formula $\psi=\bar{\partial} B_{U_{j}, q}+B_{U_{j}, q+1} \bar{\partial} \psi$ on $U_{j}$. Choose $\chi_{j} \in C_{0}^{\infty}\left(\omega_{j}^{\prime}\right)$ with $\chi_{j}=1$ in a neighborhood of $\overline{\omega_{j}^{\prime}}$.

Let $\varphi_{0}:=\varphi$ be a $(0, q)$ form on $\widetilde{M}$. We first define $\varphi_{1}, \ldots, \varphi_{N}$ inductively by

$$
\varphi_{j}=\varphi_{j-1}-\bar{\partial}\left(\chi_{j} B_{U_{j}, q} \varphi_{j-1}\right)-\chi_{j} B_{U_{j}, q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi_{j-1} \quad \text { on } \widetilde{M}
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\varphi_{j} & =\left(1-\chi_{j}\right) \varphi_{j-1}-\bar{\partial} \chi_{j} \wedge B_{U_{j}, q} \varphi_{j-1} \\
\bar{\partial} \varphi_{j} & =\left(1-\chi_{j}\right) \bar{\partial} \varphi_{j-1}-\bar{\partial} \chi_{j} \wedge B_{U_{j}, q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi_{j-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $\operatorname{supp} \bar{\partial} \chi_{j} \Subset U_{j}$, by (6.6) the two formulas immediately yield

$$
\left|\varphi_{j}\right|_{\widetilde{M}, r} \leq C_{r}\left|\varphi_{j-1}\right|_{\widetilde{M}, r} \leq C_{r}^{j}\left|\varphi_{0}\right|_{\widetilde{M}, r},\left.\quad \mid \bar{\partial} \varphi_{j}\right|_{\widetilde{M}, r} \leq C_{r}^{j}\left|\bar{\partial} \varphi_{0}\right|_{\widetilde{M}, r}
$$

Let us show that with $\hat{\omega}_{j}:=\omega_{1} \cup \cdots \cup \omega_{j}$, we have

$$
\left\|\varphi_{j}\right\|_{\mathcal{N}_{\delta_{j}}\left(\bar{\omega}_{j}\right), r} \leq C_{r, \delta_{j}}\left\|\varphi_{0}\right\|_{\widetilde{M}, 0}, \quad\left\|\bar{\partial} \varphi_{j}\right\|_{\mathcal{N}_{\delta_{j}}\left(\bar{\omega}_{j}\right), r} \leq C_{r, \delta_{j}}\left\|\bar{\partial} \varphi_{0}\right\|_{\widetilde{M}, 0}
$$

where $\delta_{j}>0$ will be chosen. In fact, $\varphi_{1}=0$ on $\mathcal{N}_{\delta_{1}}\left(\omega_{1}\right)$ if $\chi_{1}=1$ on $\mathcal{N}_{\delta_{1}}\left(\omega_{1}\right)$ and hence the inequality holds trivially for $j=1$; for the induction step, we can only prove the above weaker form.

Suppose that (6.14) holds and we want to verify it when $j$ is replaced by $j+1$. We observe that $\chi_{j+1} \equiv 1$ on $\mathcal{N}_{\delta_{j+1}}\left(\omega_{j+1}\right)$ when $\delta_{j+1}$ is sufficiently small and $0<\delta_{j+1}<\delta_{j} / 2$. Suppose $\delta \in\left(0, \delta_{j}\right)$. Then by (6.14)

$$
\left\|\left(1-\chi_{j+1}\right) \varphi_{j}\right\|_{\mathcal{N}_{\delta_{j+1}}\left(\bar{\omega}_{j+1}\right), r}=\left\|\left(1-\chi_{j+1}\right) \varphi_{j}\right\|_{\mathcal{N}_{\delta_{j+1}}\left(\bar{\omega}_{j}\right), r} \leq C_{r, \delta_{j}}^{\prime}\left\|\varphi_{0}\right\|_{\widetilde{M}, 0}
$$

Since $\operatorname{supp} \bar{\partial} \chi_{j+1} \subset \omega_{j+1}^{\prime}$ and latter contains $\mathcal{N}_{\delta_{j+1}}\left(\omega_{j+1}\right)$ for small $\delta_{j+2}$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\bar{\partial} \chi_{j+1} \wedge B_{U_{j+1}, q} \varphi_{j}\right\|_{\mathcal{N}_{\delta_{j+1}}\left(\bar{\omega}_{j+1}\right), r} \leq\left\|\bar{\partial} \chi_{j+1} \wedge B_{U_{j+1}, q} \varphi_{j}\right\|_{\mathcal{N}_{\delta_{j+1}}\left(\bar{\omega}_{j}\right) \cup \mathcal{N}_{\delta_{j+1}}\left(\omega_{j+1}\right), r} \\
\quad \leq\left\|\bar{\partial} \chi_{j+1} \wedge B_{U_{j+1}, q} \varphi_{j}\right\|_{\mathcal{N}_{\delta_{j+1}}\left(\bar{\omega}_{j}\right) \cap \omega_{j+1}^{\prime}, r} \leq C_{r}\left\|B_{U_{j+1}, q} \varphi_{j}\right\|_{\mathcal{N}_{\delta_{j+1}}\left(\bar{\omega}_{j}\right) \cap \omega_{j+1}^{\prime}, r}
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that $\mathcal{N}_{\delta_{j+1}}\left(\hat{\omega}_{j}\right) \cap \omega_{j+1}^{\prime} \Subset \mathcal{N}_{\delta_{j}}\left(\hat{\omega}_{j}\right) \cap \mathcal{N}_{\delta_{j+1}}\left(\omega_{j+1}^{\prime}\right) \Subset U_{j+1}$. By (6.6), we obtain $\left\|B_{U_{j+1}, q} \varphi_{j}\right\|_{\mathcal{N}_{\delta_{j+1}}\left(\hat{\omega}_{j}\right) \cap \omega_{j+1}^{\prime}, r} \leq C_{r}\left(\left|\varphi_{j}\right|_{\mathcal{N}_{\delta_{j}}\left(\hat{\omega}_{j}\right) \cap \mathcal{N}_{\delta_{j+1}}\left(\omega_{j+1}^{\prime}\right), r}+\|\varphi\|_{\bar{M}, 0}\right) \leq C_{r}^{\prime}\|\varphi\|_{\bar{M}, 0}$. Combining the last three displayed estimates and using formulas (6.11), we see that (6.14) holds for $\varphi_{j+1}$. The estimate for $\bar{\partial} \varphi_{j+1}$ can be obtained by the same argument via formula (6.12).

Finally, as in Proposition 6.4 we have the desired estimates for $K_{q}^{1} \varphi:=\varphi_{N}$ and

$$
B_{q} \varphi:=\sum_{j=1}^{N} \chi_{j} B_{U_{j}, q} \varphi_{j-1}, \quad B_{q+1} \psi:=\sum_{j=1}^{N} \chi_{j} B_{U_{j}, q+1} \psi_{j-1}
$$

where $\varphi_{j}$ are defined by (6.11) and $\psi_{j}$ is defined by (6.12) in which $\bar{\partial} \varphi_{j}$ is replaced by $\psi_{j}$ for $j=1, \ldots, N$.

Applying Lemma 6.6 in which $\varphi$ is $K_{q}^{0} \varphi$, we immediately obtain the following.
Proposition 6.7. Let $r \in(0, \infty), \varepsilon>0,0 \leq \delta \leq 1 / 2$, and $q \geq 1$. Let $M \Subset$ $\mathcal{M}: \rho<0$ be a domain with $C^{2}$ boundary satisfying the conditions $a_{q}^{+}$. Let $V$ be a holomorphic vector bundle of finite rank over $\mathcal{M}$. Then

$$
\varphi=\bar{\partial} H_{q} \varphi+H_{q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi+K_{q} \varphi
$$

for any $(0, q)$ forms $\varphi$ on $M$ such that $\varphi, \bar{\partial} \varphi \in \Lambda^{r}(M, V)$. Here $K_{q} \varphi$ are $\bar{\partial}$ closed $V$-valued $(0, q)$ forms on $\bar{M} \otimes \bar{M}$. Further, $H_{q}, H_{q+1}, K_{q}$ are independent of $r$ and we have the following.
(a) If $b M \in C^{2}$ is strictly $(n-q)$ convex, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|H_{j} \varphi\right|_{M, r+1 / 2} & \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}\left(\nabla \rho, \nabla^{2} \rho\right)\|\varphi\|_{M, r}, \quad j=q, q+1 \\
\left\|K_{q} \varphi\right\|_{\bar{M}, r} & \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}\left(\nabla \rho, \nabla^{2} \rho\right)\|\varphi\|_{M, \varepsilon}
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) If $b_{q+1}^{-} M \in \Lambda^{r+2+\delta}$, then for $j=q, q+1$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|H_{j} \varphi\right|_{M, r+\delta} & \leq C_{r, \delta, \varepsilon}\left(\nabla \rho, \nabla^{2} \rho\right)\left(\|\rho\|_{r+2+\delta}^{*} \|\rho\|_{2+\varepsilon}^{s b}|\varphi|_{M, \varepsilon}+|\varphi|_{M, r}\right) \\
\left\|K_{q} \varphi\right\|_{\bar{M}, r} & \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}\left(\nabla \rho, \nabla^{2} \rho\right)\|\rho\|_{2+\varepsilon}^{* b}\|\varphi\|_{M, \varepsilon}
\end{aligned}
$$

Furthermore, the positive constants $b, C_{r, \varepsilon}\left(\nabla \rho, \nabla^{2} \rho\right)$ and $C_{r, \delta, \varepsilon}\left(\nabla^{\rho}, \nabla^{2} \rho\right)$ are stable under small $C^{2}$ perturbations of $\rho$.

Proof. By Propositions 6.4 and 6.6, we obtain

$$
\varphi=\bar{\partial} T_{q} \varphi+\bar{\partial} B_{q} K_{q}^{0} \varphi+T_{q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi+B_{q+1} \bar{\partial} K_{q}^{0} \varphi+K_{q}^{1} K_{q}^{0} \varphi
$$

Define $H_{q} \varphi=T_{q} \varphi+B_{q} K_{q}^{0} \varphi$ and $H_{q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi=T_{q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi+B_{q+1} \bar{\partial} K_{q}^{0} \varphi$. Define $K_{q} \varphi=$ $K_{q}^{1} K_{q}^{0} \varphi$. Note that $H_{q+1} \varphi$ is well-defined. Indeed, if $\bar{\partial} \varphi=\bar{\partial} \bar{\varphi}$ on $M$, we have $T_{q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi=T_{q+1} \bar{\partial} \bar{\varphi}$. Also, by (6.9) and estimate (6.3) for $K_{q}^{0}$, we have

$$
\left|B_{q+1} \bar{\partial} K_{q}^{0} \bar{\varphi}-B_{q+1} \bar{\partial} K_{q}^{0} \varphi\right|_{M, \varepsilon} \leq C_{\varepsilon}\left|\bar{\partial} K_{q}^{0} \bar{\varphi}-\bar{\partial} K_{q}^{0} \varphi\right|_{\bar{M}, \varepsilon} \leq C_{\varepsilon}^{\prime}\left|\bar{\partial} \bar{\varphi}-\bar{\partial} \varphi\right|_{M, \varepsilon}=0
$$

The estimates follow from Propositions 6.4 and 6.6. Note that $\|\varphi\|_{\varepsilon}$, instead of $\|\varphi\|_{\varepsilon}$ is need in this proposition, since estimates in Proposition 6.4 requires $r>0$.

6.2. An application of $\bar{\partial}$-Neumann operators. To construct the global homotopy formula by removing the compact operator in the approximate homotopy formula, we will use the $\bar{\partial}$-Neumann solution operators in Kohn [30,31] and KohnRossi [32]. Suppose that $\mathcal{M}$ is a hermitian manifold and $V$ is a hermitian holomorphic vector bundle on $\mathcal{M}$. Let $M$ be a relatively compact domain in $\mathcal{M}$ with smooth boundary. (We will take $M$ to be the $\widetilde{M}$ in our application.) Then $M$ is defined by $\rho<0$ with $|d \rho|=1$ at each point in $\partial M$. Locally, for each $\zeta \in b M$, we can choose a special unitary frame $\omega^{1}, \ldots, \omega^{n}$ for $(1,0)$ forms on a neighborhood $U$ of $\zeta$ such that on $b M \cap U, \omega^{n}=\sqrt{2} \partial \rho$, and a unitary frame $e_{1}, \ldots, e_{m}$ for $V$ such that a $V$-valued $(0, q)$ form $\varphi$ can be written as

$$
\varphi=\sum \varphi_{I}^{j} \bar{\omega}^{I} \otimes e_{j}, \quad \bar{\partial} \varphi=\sum \varphi_{I ; \alpha}^{j} \bar{\omega}^{\alpha} \wedge \bar{\omega}^{I} \otimes e_{j}
$$

Let $d V$ be the volume on $\mathcal{M}$ with respect to the hermitian metric on $\mathcal{M}$. For $\varphi, \psi \in L_{(0, q)}^{2}(M, V)$, define

$$
(\varphi, \psi):=\int_{M}\langle\varphi, \psi\rangle d V, \quad\langle\varphi, \psi\rangle=\sum \varphi_{I}^{j} \overline{\psi_{I}^{j}}, \quad\|\varphi\|^{2}:=(\varphi, \varphi)
$$

Let $\bar{\partial}_{q}: L_{(0, q)}^{2}(M, V) \rightarrow L_{(0, q+1)}^{2}(M, V)$ be the standard closed and densely defined $\bar{\partial}$ operator. Let $\operatorname{Dom} \bar{\partial}_{q}$ be the domain of $\bar{\partial}_{q}$. Define $g \in \operatorname{Dom} \bar{\partial}_{q}^{*} \subset L_{(0, q+1)}^{2}(M, V)$ and write $\bar{\partial}^{*} g=v$, if $\left(\bar{\partial}_{q} u, g\right)=(u, v)$ for $u \in \operatorname{Dom} \bar{\partial}_{q}$. Define $\bar{\partial}$-Neumann Laplacian $\square_{q}=\bar{\partial}_{q}^{*} \bar{\partial}_{q}+\bar{\partial}_{q-1} \bar{\partial}_{q-1}^{*}$ for $q>0$, where we use convention $\bar{\partial}_{n}^{*}=0$. We recall the following.

Theorem 6.8 ([32], Thm. 3.9; [9], Thm. 3.1.14, p. 51 and p. 77). If bM satisfies the $a_{q}$ condition with $q>0$ and $b M \in C^{\infty}$, then for any hermitian vector bundle $V$ on $\mathcal{M}$ there exists a bounded operator $N_{q}: L_{0, q}^{2}(M, V) \rightarrow L_{0, q}^{2}(M, V)$ satisfying the following
(a) $N_{q} L_{(0, q)}^{2}(M, V) \subset \operatorname{Dom}\left(\square_{q}\right)$ and

$$
\varphi=\square_{q} N_{q} \varphi+H_{q}^{0} \varphi, \quad H_{q}^{0} \varphi \in \mathcal{H}_{(0, q)}(M, V), \quad \forall \varphi \in L_{(0, q)}^{2}(M, V)
$$

where $\mathcal{H}_{(0, q)}(M, V)$ is the space of $V$-valued harmonic $(0, q)$-forms.
(b) $N_{q}$ commutes with $\square_{q}$ on $\operatorname{Dom} \square_{q}$. Assume further that $N_{q+1}$ is defined on $L_{(0, q+1)}^{2}(M, V)$. Then $N_{q+1} \bar{\partial}_{q} \varphi=\bar{\partial}_{q} N_{q} \varphi$ if $\varphi \in \operatorname{Dom} \bar{\partial}_{q}$.
(c) $N_{q}\left(C_{(0, q)}^{\infty}(\bar{M}, V)\right) \subset C_{(0, q)}^{\infty}(\bar{M}, V)$ and $\left\|N_{q} \varphi\right\|_{H^{s+1}(M)} \leq C_{s}\|\varphi\|_{H^{s}(M)}$ for all $\varphi \in C_{(0, q)}^{\infty}(\bar{M})$.

Remark 6.9. As mentioned in Folland-Kohn [9, p. 51], $N_{q+1}$ is defined whenever $\square_{q+1}$ has closed range, whether the basic estimate (i.e. condition $a_{q+1}$ ) holds or not for $(0, q+1)$ forms.

Theorem 6.10. Let $r>0, \varepsilon>0$ and $0 \leq \delta \leq 1 / 2$. Suppose that bM satisfies conditions $a_{q}^{+}$with $q>0$. Assume that $r \in(0, \infty)$. Then for $\varphi, \bar{\partial} \varphi \in \Lambda^{r}(M, V)$ we have on $M$

$$
\varphi=\bar{\partial} R_{q} \varphi+R_{q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi+\tilde{H}_{q} \varphi
$$

where $\tilde{H}_{q} \varphi \in \mathcal{H}_{(0, q)}(\widetilde{M}, V)$ and $\widetilde{M} \otimes M$ is an $a_{q}^{+}$domain with smooth boundary.
(a) If $b M \in C^{2}$ is strictly $(n-q)$ convex, then

$$
|R_{s} \varphi|_{r+1 / 2} \leq C_{r}|\varphi|_{r}, \quad\left\|\tilde{H}_{q} \varphi\right\|_{r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}|\varphi\|_{\varepsilon}
$$

(b) For $j=q, q+1$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|R_{j} \varphi\right|_{r+\delta} \leq C_{r, \delta, \varepsilon}\left(|\rho|_{r+2+\delta}^{*}|\rho|_{2+\varepsilon}^{* b}|\varphi|_{\varepsilon}+|\varphi|_{r}\right) \\
& \left\|\tilde{H}_{q} \varphi\right\|_{r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}\|\rho\|_{2+\varepsilon}^{* b}\|\varphi\|_{\varepsilon}
\end{aligned}
$$

Furthermore, if $0<\delta_{0}<\delta_{1}$, then for any $\delta^{\prime}, \delta^{\prime \prime}$ satisfying $\delta_{0}<\delta^{\prime}<\delta^{\prime \prime}<\delta_{1}$, we have

$$
\left|R_{s} \varphi\right|_{M \backslash \mathcal{N}_{\delta^{\prime \prime}}\left(k_{q+1}^{-}, M\right), r+1 / 2} \leq \frac{C_{r, \varepsilon}}{\left(\delta^{\prime \prime}-\delta^{\prime}\right)^{r+\epsilon_{*}}}\left(\|\varphi\|_{\varepsilon}+|\varphi|_{M \backslash \mathcal{N}_{\delta^{\prime}}\left(k_{q+1}^{-}, M\right), r}\right)
$$

Here $C_{r, \varepsilon}=C_{r, \varepsilon}\left(\nabla \rho, \nabla^{2} \rho\right)$ are stable under small $C^{2}$ perturbations of $\rho$.
Proof. By Proposition 6.7, we have $\varphi=\bar{\partial} H_{q} \varphi+H_{q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi+K_{q} \varphi$, where $K_{q} \varphi$ is defined on $\widetilde{M}$. By Theorem $6.8(a)-(b)$ applied to the domain $\widetilde{M}$, we decompose

$$
K_{q} \varphi=\bar{\partial} T_{q} \varphi+\tilde{T}_{q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi+H_{q}^{0} K_{q} \varphi
$$

with

$$
\tilde{T}_{q} \varphi=\bar{\partial}^{*} N_{q} K_{q} \varphi, \quad \tilde{T}_{q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi=\bar{\partial}^{*} N_{q+1} \bar{\partial} K_{q} \varphi
$$

Here $N_{s}, H_{q}^{0}$ are the corresponding operators in Theorem 6.8 for the $a_{q}^{+}$domain $\tilde{M}$. Thus, we have obtained $\varphi=\bar{\partial} R_{s} \varphi+R_{q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi+\tilde{H}_{q} \varphi$ with $R_{s} \varphi:=H_{q} \varphi+\tilde{T}_{s} \varphi$ and $\tilde{H}_{q} \varphi:=H_{q}^{0} K_{q} \varphi$.

We now need to derive interior estimates for $N_{j}$ for $j=q, q+1$. Recall that since $N_{j}$ exists, we have

$$
\square N_{j} \tilde{\varphi}_{j}=\tilde{\varphi}_{j}-H_{j}^{0} \tilde{\varphi}_{j}
$$

We will take $\tilde{\varphi}_{q}=K_{q} \varphi$ and $\tilde{\varphi}_{q+1}=\bar{\partial} K_{q} \varphi$.
We now derive the estimates using local interior estimates for the elliptic system that is valid for any relatively compact subdomain of $\widetilde{M}$, by using the global $L^{2}$ estimate in Theorem 6.8

$$
\left\|N_{j} \tilde{\varphi}_{j}\right\|_{L^{2}(\widetilde{M})} \leq C_{q}(\widetilde{M})\left\|\tilde{\varphi}_{j}\right\|_{L^{2}(\widetilde{M})}
$$

By the regularity of $\bar{\partial}$-Neumann operator, we know that for $a_{q}$ domain $\widetilde{M}$ which has $C^{\infty}$ boundary, harmonic forms on smooth on $\widetilde{\widetilde{M}}$. Therefore,

$$
\left|H_{j}^{0} \tilde{\varphi}_{j}\right|_{M, r} \leq C_{r}\left\|\tilde{\varphi}_{j}\right\|_{L^{2}(\widetilde{M})}, \quad \forall r>0
$$

The interior estimation is local and we may assume that $M$ is contained in $\mathbb{C}^{n}$. We still have

$$
\square N_{j} \tilde{\varphi}_{j}=\tilde{\varphi}-H_{j}^{0} \tilde{\varphi}_{j}
$$

Let $\chi$ be a smooth function with compact support on $\mathcal{N}_{\delta}(\bar{M})$. Let $u=\chi N_{j} \tilde{\varphi}_{j}$. Then

$$
\square u=v, \quad v:=a(\nabla \chi) \nabla N_{j} \tilde{\varphi}+b\left(\nabla^{2} \chi\right) N_{j} \tilde{\varphi}_{j}+\chi \tilde{\varphi}_{j}-\chi H_{j}^{0} \tilde{\varphi}_{j}
$$

Next, we recall two interior estimates on systems of elliptic equations in Morrey [42, Thm 6.4.4., p. 246]:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\|\tilde{u}\|_{W^{k+2, p}} \leq C_{k, p}\|v\|_{W^{k, p}}+C_{R}\|\tilde{u}\|_{W^{0,1}}, 1<p<\infty \\
\|\tilde{u}\|_{k+2+\alpha} \leq C_{k, \alpha}\|v\|_{k+\alpha}+C_{R}\|\tilde{u}\|_{L i p}
\end{gathered}
$$

provided the right-hand sides are finite and $\operatorname{supp} \tilde{u} \subset B_{R}$. Note that the latter is satisfied by our $\tilde{u}$. We can easily verify (see the proof of Prop. 8.5 in [14]) that

$$
\|\tilde{u}\|_{k+2+\alpha} \leq C_{k}\left(\left\|\chi\left(\tilde{\varphi}-H_{j}^{0} \tilde{\varphi}_{j}\right)\right\|_{k+\alpha}+\|u\|_{L^{2}}\right) \leq C_{k}^{\prime}\|\chi\|_{k+1}\left\|\tilde{\varphi}_{j}\right\|_{k+\alpha}+C_{k}\|u\|_{L^{2}}
$$

Since $\|u\|_{L^{2}} \leq C\left\|\tilde{\varphi}_{j}\right\|_{L^{2}}$, we obtain

$$
\|\tilde{u}\|_{k+2+\alpha} \leq C_{k}^{\prime}\left\|\chi\left\|_{k+1}\right\| \tilde{\varphi}_{j}\right\|_{k+\alpha}+C_{k}\left\|\varphi_{j}\right\|_{C^{0}(\tilde{M})}
$$

Combining this estimate with the estimates Proposition 6.7, we can obtain (6.16)(6.18). The details are left to the reader.

To estimate (6.19), we take a smooth function $\tilde{\chi}$ on $\mathcal{M}$ that has compact support in $\bar{M} \backslash \mathcal{N}_{\delta^{\prime}}\left(b_{q+1}^{-} M\right)$ and equals 1 on $M \backslash \mathcal{N}_{\delta^{\prime \prime}}\left(b_{q+1}^{-} M\right)$. We may assume that $\|\chi\|_{C^{k}(\mathcal{M})} \leq C_{k}\left(r^{\prime}-r^{\prime}\right)^{k+1}$ where $C_{k}$ is independent of $\delta^{\prime}, \delta^{\prime \prime}$. Applying the above estimates to $u=\tilde{\chi} N_{j} \tilde{\varphi}$, this gives us (6.19). We left the details to the reader.
6.3. Stability of cohomology groups and proof of Corollary 1.3. We also need to identify the cohomology groups after bumping. Let us collect some known results. Let $\bar{H}_{(0, q)}(M, V)$ be the quotient of $\bar{\partial}$-closed $V$-valued $(0, q)$ forms on $M$ by $L_{(0, q)}^{2}(M, V) \cap \bar{\partial} L_{(0, q-1)}^{2}(M, V)$.

Proposition 6.11. Let $M \Subset \mathcal{M}$ be an $a_{q}$ domain with $C^{2}$ boundary defined by $\rho<0$ and let $M^{a}$ be defined by $\rho<a$. Let $V$ be a hermitian holomorphic vector bundle on $\mathcal{M}$. Then we have
(a) Suppose that $M^{-c}$ are $a_{q}$ domains for $0<c \leq c_{*}$. Then the restriction of $\bar{H}_{(0, q)}(M, V)$ on $\bar{H}_{(0, q)}\left(M^{-c_{*}}, V\right)$ is injective.
(b) $\bar{H}_{(0, q)}(M, V)$ and $\mathcal{H}_{(0, q)}(M, V)$ are isomorphic.
(c) If $H^{q}(M, \mathcal{O}(V))=0$, then $\mathcal{H}_{(0, q)}(\widetilde{M}, V)=0$, where $\widetilde{M}$ is given by Theorem 6.10 via the Grauert bumping; hence, Theorem 1.2 holds.
(d) If $M$ further satisfies $a_{q}^{+}$condition, then $H^{q}(M, \mathcal{O}(V))$ and $\mathcal{H}_{(0, q)}(M, V)$ are isomorphic.

Proof. By Dolbeault isomorphism, we have $H^{(0, q)}(\mathcal{M}, V) \approx H^{q}(\mathcal{M}, \mathcal{O}(V))$ for a holomorphic vector bundle $V$ on a complex manifold $\mathcal{M}$.
(a) is in Hörmander [25, Thm. 3.4.6] when $V$ is trivial and $\partial M \in C^{3}$; see also Appendix B in [14] for the general case.
(b) is in Folland-Kohn [9, p. 77] and (d) is in Folland-Kohn [9, Thm. 4.3.1], when $b M \in C^{\infty}$. The restriction for $b M \in C^{\infty}$ can be relaxed to $b M \in C^{2}$; see Appendix B in [14].
(c) Suppose that $f$ is an $V$-valued $(0, q)$ form on $M^{\prime}$ satisfying $\bar{\partial}_{q} f=0$ and $\bar{\partial}_{q-1}^{*} f=0$. Then $f \in C^{\infty}$. Now $H^{(0, q)}(M, V)=0$ implies that $f=\bar{\partial} u$ for some $u \in C^{\infty}(M)$. Since $u \in L^{2}\left(M^{-c}\right)$, then $f=\bar{\partial} \tilde{u}$ for some $\tilde{u} \in L^{2}\left(M^{\prime}\right)$ by $(a)$. Thus $(f, f)=(f, \bar{\partial} u)=\left(\bar{\partial}^{*} f, u\right)=0$.

Before we prove Theorem 1.1, let us first prove its corollary.
Proof of Corollary 1.3. Shaw [50, Thm. 2.2] showed that when $D_{1}, D_{2}$ are bounded strongly pseudoconvex domains in $\mathbb{C}^{n}$ with smooth boundary with $D_{1} \Subset D_{2}$ and $n \geq 3$, the harmonic space $\mathcal{H}_{(0,1)}\left(D_{2} \backslash \overline{D_{1}}\right)$ vanishes. Since the tangent bundle of $\mathbb{C}^{n}$ is trivial, applying this result to $\tilde{M}$ when $M$ is contained in $\mathbb{C}^{n}$, we obtain $\mathcal{H}_{(0,1)}(\widetilde{M}, \Theta)=0$. Therefore, Corollary 1.3 follows from Theorem 1.1 directly.

Remark 6.12. Note that we need $n \geq 4$ instead of $n \geq 3$ for Corollary 1.3, because our proof relies on regularity of $N_{1}$ and $N_{2}$. On $\mathbb{C}^{n}$, there is no need of time-one maps. It is plausible that the requirement of $r_{0}>5 / 2$ in Corollary 1.3 can be lowed to $r_{0}>3 / 2$ as in Shi [52].

As mentioned in Folland-Kohn [9, p. 77], the relations between these important cohomology groups are non-trivial. It seems that it is unknown if the conclusion in (c) holds for $a_{q}$ domains. For vanishing of cohomology groups, see Chakrabarti-Laurent-Thiébaut-Shaw [4, Thm. 1.8]. For recent work on stability on spectrum of the $\bar{\partial}$-Neumann Laplacian for families of domains, see Fu-Zhu [10].

# 7. ESTIMATES FOR THE MAIN INDUCTIVE STEP 

In this section and next, we prove Theorem 1.1 and a detailed version Theorem 8.2, using Theorem 1.2. The proof does not need condition $a_{1}^{+}$and it only requires the existence of homotopy formulas, the estimates of the homotopy operators and the $a_{1}$ condition to ensure the stability of the existence of homotopy formulas under small $C^{2}$ perturbations of the domain $M$ as stated in Theorem 1.2 and an use of Hartogs's extension in Subsection 8.4 is valid.

This section provides the inductive step for a Nash-Moser iteration. We finish the proof in Section 8.
7.1. Strongly pseudoconvex case. Let $M$ be a strictly pseudoconvex domain in $\mathcal{M}$. Given the initial integrable almost complex structure on $M$, we want to find a transformation $F$ defined on $\bar{M}$ to transform the structure to a new structure closer to the standard complex structure while $\bar{M}$ is transformed to a new domain that is still strictly pseudoconvex.

Our homotopy formula requires that $A$ and $\bar{\partial} A$ to be $\Lambda^{r}$ for $r>0$. We need further initial conditions to derive estimates. Thus, we will assume the following initial conditions

$$
\begin{gathered}
t^{-\alpha}|A|_{s}<1, \quad \alpha>1, s>0 \\
|A|_{m} \leq L_{m}, \quad m>1
\end{gathered}
$$

Eventually, we will need $s>1$ and $m>2$ as we carry out the required estimates. Here and in what follows, we write $|\cdot|_{M, r}$ as $|\cdot|_{r}$. Then

$$
|A|_{m^{\prime}} \leq C_{s, m^{\prime}, m} t^{\alpha\left(1-\frac{m^{\prime}-s}{m-s}\right)}|A|_{m}, \quad m \geq m^{\prime} \geq s
$$

where $t$ is the parameter of the smoothing operator which will converge to 0 in the iteration. We shall later verify condition (7.3) at each induction step.

We will use $C_{m}$ (resp. $C_{s}, C_{r}$ etc.) to denote a constant depending on $m$, and which is stable under small $C^{2}$ perturbations of the domain $M$.

We apply the homotopy formula to $A$ on $\bar{M}$ so that on $M$

$$
A=\bar{\partial} P A+Q \bar{\partial} A, \quad A \in \Lambda^{r}, \quad r>1
$$

where $P=R_{1}$ and $Q=R_{2}$ are given by Theorem 6.10. We have estimates

$$
\begin{array}{cl}
|P \varphi|_{r+1 / 2} \leq C_{r}\left(\bar{\partial}^{2} \rho\right)|\varphi|_{r}, & r>0 \\
|Q \psi|_{r+1 / 2} \leq C_{r}\left(\bar{\partial}^{2} \rho\right)|\psi|_{r}, & r>0
\end{array}
$$

Here $P A$ is a global vector field of type $(1,0)$ of class $\Lambda^{r+1 / 2}$.
On $\bar{M}$, we use the time-one flow of $v$ :

$$
F=F_{v}^{1} \quad \text { on } M, \quad v:=-S^{t} P A \in C^{\infty}(\overline{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M)} ; \Theta)
$$

where $S^{t}$ is the smoothing operator given by (3.15). We extend $v$ from $\mathcal{N}_{t}(M)$ to $\mathcal{M}$ so that

$$
\|v\|_{\mathcal{M}, r} \leq C_{r}(M)\|v\|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M), r}, \quad|v|_{\mathcal{M}, r} \leq C_{r}(M)|v|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M), r}
$$

Here $C_{r}$ is independent of $t$ and stable under small perturbations of $M$. To apply Proposition 4.2, we need

$$
C_{0}(M)\|v\|_{0} \leq t, \quad C_{1}(M)\|v\|_{1+\varepsilon} \leq \delta_{1, \varepsilon}, \quad C_{2, \varepsilon}(M)\|v\|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M), 2+\varepsilon} \leq \delta_{2, \varepsilon}
$$

(Here the parameter $\varepsilon$ will be determined only via (7.25)-(7.26) below.) Thus, the above conditions hold since $C|v|_{s+1 / 2} \leq C C_{s}|A|_{s} \leq C C_{s} t^{\alpha}<t$ for $\alpha>1$ and $t \in\left[0, t_{0}^{*}\right]$, where $t_{0}^{*}>0$ is fixed. This allows us to replace all norms $|v|_{r}^{*}$ in Proposition 4.2 by $|v|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M) ; r}$. Then Proposition 4.2 gives us

$$
M^{1}=F(M) \subset \mathcal{N}_{C_{n}\|v\|_{0}}(M), \quad F_{v}^{-1}: \mathcal{N}_{C_{n}\|v\|_{0}}(M) \rightarrow \mathcal{N}_{C_{n}\left(C_{n}+1\right)\|v\|_{0}}(M)
$$

and $F^{-1}=\left.F_{v}^{-1}\right|_{M^{1}}$. Furthermore, we can use the estimates in Proposition 4.2.
In local charts $\left(U_{k}, \psi_{k}\right)$, we have

$$
F_{k}=I+f_{k}, \quad f_{k}=v_{k}+w_{k}
$$

where $v_{k}\left(z_{k}\right)=\left(-S^{t} P A\right)_{k}, z_{k}=\psi_{k}$, and $w_{k}$ regarded as smaller than $v_{k}$ is given as in Proposition 4.2. Thus, $w_{k}$ is defined on $\mathcal{N}_{t}\left(D_{k}\right)$, where $D_{k}=\psi_{k}\left(U_{k} \cap M\right)$. Here by an abuse of notation, we denote $w_{k}(\cdot, 1)$ by $w_{k}(\cdot)$. We have

$$
A_{k}=\sum A_{k, \bar{\partial}}^{\alpha} d \bar{z}_{k}^{\beta} \otimes \frac{\partial}{\partial z_{k}^{\alpha}}, \quad f_{k}=\left(f_{k}^{1}, \ldots, f_{k}^{n}\right)
$$

By Lemma 4.1, the new structure $A^{\prime}$ takes the form

$$
A_{k}^{\prime} \circ F_{k}=\left(I+\overline{\partial f}_{k}+A_{k} \bar{\partial} f_{k}\right)^{-1}\left(A_{k}+\bar{\partial} f_{k}+A_{k} \partial f_{k}\right)
$$

Thus on $D_{k}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
A_{k} & +\bar{\partial} f_{k}+A_{k} \partial f_{k}=A_{k}-\bar{\partial}\left(S^{t} P A\right)_{k}-A_{k} \partial\left(S^{t} P A\right)_{k}+A_{k} \partial w_{k}+\bar{\partial} w_{k} \\
& =A_{k}-\left(S^{t} \bar{\partial} P A\right)_{k}-A_{k} \partial\left(S^{t} P A\right)_{k}+A_{k} \partial w_{k}+\bar{\partial} w_{k}+\left(\left[S^{t}, \bar{\partial}\right] P A\right)_{k}
\end{aligned}
$$

We now apply the homotopy formula for a second time as in [17], by writing

$$
\bar{\partial} P A=A-Q \bar{\partial} A
$$

We obtain for $A \in \Lambda^{r}$ with $r>1$

$$
\begin{aligned}
A_{k} & +\bar{\partial} f_{k}+A_{k} \partial f_{k} \\
& =A_{k}-\left(S^{t} A\right)_{k}+\left(S^{t} Q \bar{\partial} A\right)_{k}-\left(A \partial S^{t} P A\right)_{k}+A_{k} \partial w_{k}+\bar{\partial} w_{k}+\left(\left[S^{t}, \bar{\partial}\right] P A\right)_{k}
\end{aligned}
$$

We shall use the following notation

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{1} & =\left[\left(I-S^{t}\right) A\right]_{k}, \quad I_{2}=\left[S^{t} Q \bar{\partial} A\right]_{k}, \quad I_{3}=\left[\left[S^{t}, \bar{\partial}\right] P A\right]_{k} \\
I_{4} & =-\left(A \partial S^{t} P A\right)_{k}, \quad I_{5}=A_{k} \partial w_{k}+\bar{\partial} w_{k}, \quad \mathcal{K}_{k}=\overline{\partial f_{k}}+A_{k} \bar{\partial} f_{k}
\end{aligned}
$$

We remark that among $I_{1}, \ldots, I_{4}$, only $I_{2}$ requires $A \in \Lambda^{r}$ with $r>1$. The other terms are well-defined for $A \in \Lambda^{r}$ with $r>0$. Of course, $I_{j}$ depend on $k$. Consequently, we can rewrite (7.6) as

$$
\tilde{A}_{k}=\left(I+\mathcal{K}_{k}\right)^{-1}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{5} I_{j}\right), \quad \tilde{A}_{k}=A_{k}^{\prime} \circ F_{k}
$$

We first estimate the $I_{j}$-s. By Lemma 3.9 and noting that $\left.S^{t} E A\right|_{M}=\left.S^{t} A\right|_{M}$, we get

$$
\left|I_{1}\right|_{D_{k} ; r} \leq\left|\left(I-S^{t}\right) A\right|_{r} \leq C_{m, r} t^{m-r}\left|A\right|_{m}, \quad 0<r \leq m<r+m_{*}
$$

where $m_{*}$ is a fixed large number. Thus

$$
\left|I_{1}\right|_{D_{k} ; s}<C_{s, m} t^{m-s}|A|_{m} \leq C_{s, m} L_{m} t^{m-s} \leq t^{d \alpha}
$$

provided

$$
m-s>d \alpha+\varepsilon, \quad C_{s, m} L_{m} t^{\varepsilon}<1
$$

We need to take

$$
d>1
$$

By (7.7), we also have

$$
\left|I_{1}\right|_{D_{k} ; r} \leq C_{r}|A|_{r}, \quad \forall r>0
$$

For $I_{2}$, we need to use the integrability condition $\bar{\partial} A=-\frac{1}{2}[A, A]$. Recall that $[A, A]$ is a sum of products of $A$ and its first-order derivatives. Thus

$$
\left|[A, A]\right|_{r-1} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}|A|_{\varepsilon}|A|_{r}, \quad r>1
$$

Since $M$ is strongly pseudoconvex, we have by Theorem 6.10

$$
|Q \bar{\partial} A|_{r+\frac{1}{2}} \leq C_{r}|\bar{\partial} A|_{r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}\|A\|_{\varepsilon}|A|_{r+1}, \quad r>0
$$

Applying Lemma 3.9, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|I_{2}\right|_{D_{k} ; r} & =\left|S^{t} Q \bar{\partial} A\right|_{r} \leq C_{r} t^{-\frac{1}{2}}|Q \bar{\partial} A|_{r-\frac{1}{2}} \\
& \leq C_{r}^{\prime} t^{-\frac{1}{2}}|\bar{\partial} A|_{r-1} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}^{\prime} t^{-\frac{1}{2}}|A|_{\varepsilon}|A|_{r}, \quad r>1
\end{aligned}
$$

In particular, we have

$$
\left|I_{2}\right|_{D_{k} ; s} \leq C_{s} t^{-\frac{1}{2}+2 \alpha}<t^{d \alpha}
$$

by the last inequality in (7.8), provided

$$
2 \alpha-\frac{1}{2}>d \alpha+\varepsilon, \quad s>1
$$

Here we emphasize that (7.11) requires $s>1$. Also

$$
\left|I_{2}\right|_{D_{k} ; r} \leq C_{r}|A|_{r}, \quad \forall r>1
$$

By Lemma 3.9 and (7.4) we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|I_{3}\right|_{D_{k} ; m^{\prime}} & =\left|\left[S^{t}, \bar{\partial}\right] P A\right|_{m^{\prime}} \leq C_{m^{\prime}, r} t^{r-m^{\prime}}|P A|_{r} \\
& \leq C_{m^{\prime}, r}^{\prime} t^{r-m^{\prime}}|A|_{r-1 / 2}, \quad r>\frac{1}{2}, m^{\prime}>0,\left|r-m^{\prime}\right|<m_{*}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, we simply use the estimates for $I_{1}$ to estimate $I_{3}$.
Next, we estimate $I_{4}$. By using (3.2), (3.18) and (7.4) we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|I_{4}\right|_{D_{k} ; r} & =\left|A \partial S^{t} P A\right|_{r} \\
& \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}\left(|A|_{r}\left|\partial S^{t} P A\right|_{\varepsilon}+|A|_{\varepsilon}\left|\partial S^{t} P A\right|_{r}\right) \\
& \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}^{\prime}\left(|A|_{r}\left|S^{t} P A\right|_{1+\varepsilon}+|A|_{\varepsilon}\left|S^{t} P A\right|_{r+1}\right) \\
& \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}^{\prime \prime}\left(|A|_{r} t^{-1 / 2}|A|_{\varepsilon}+t^{-\frac{1}{2}}|A|_{\varepsilon}|A|_{r}\right), \quad r>0
\end{aligned}
$$

Applying the above with $s$ in place of $r$, we get

$$
\left|I_{4}\right|_{D_{k} ; s} \leq 2 C_{\varepsilon, s}^{\prime \prime} t^{-\frac{1}{2}+2 \alpha}<t^{d \alpha}
$$

by (7.12) for a possibly larger $C_{s}$. Also

$$
\left|I_{4}\right|_{D_{k} ; r} \leq C_{r}|A|_{r}, \quad r>0
$$

We now estimate $I_{5}=A \partial w+\bar{\partial} w$. Recall that $v=-S^{t} P A$. By Theorem 6.10, we obtain

$$
\begin{gathered}
|v|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M) ; r+1 / 2} \leq C_{r}|A|_{r}, \quad r>0 \\
|v|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M) ; s+1 / 2} \leq C_{s} t^{\alpha}, \quad|v|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M) ; r+1} \leq C_{r} t^{-1 / 2}|A|_{r}
\end{gathered}
$$

Thus, we have for $r>0$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|w_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; r+1} \leq C_{r}|v|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M) ; r+1} \leq C_{r} t^{-1 / 2}|A|_{r} \\
& \left|w_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}|v|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M) ; r+1}|v|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M) ; 1+\varepsilon} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}^{\prime} t^{-1 / 2}|A|_{r} t^{\alpha}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, for $r>0$ we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|A_{k} \partial v_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; r} & \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}\left(|A|_{r}\left|\partial v_{k}\right|_{D_{k}, \varepsilon}+|A|_{\varepsilon}\left|\partial v_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; r}\right) \\
& \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}^{\prime}\left(|A|_{r}|A|_{s}+|A|_{s}|v|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M) ; r+1}\right) \leq 2 C_{r, \varepsilon}^{\prime \prime} t^{-1 / 2}|A|_{s}|A|_{r}
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly,

$$
\left|A_{k}\left(\bar{\partial} v_{k}, \partial w_{k}, \bar{\partial} w_{k}\right)\right|_{D_{k} ; r} \leq 2 C_{r, \varepsilon}^{\prime \prime} t^{-1 / 2}|A|_{s}|A|_{r, \varepsilon}, \quad r>0
$$

It follows that

$$
\left|A_{k}\left(\partial v_{k}, \bar{\partial} v_{k}, \partial w_{k}, \bar{\partial} w_{k}\right)\right|_{D_{k} ; s} \leq C_{s, \varepsilon} t^{2 \alpha-\frac{1}{2}}<t^{d \alpha}
$$

by (7.12). We also have

$$
\left|A_{k}\left(\partial v_{k}, \bar{\partial} v_{k}, \partial w_{k}, \bar{\partial} w_{k}\right)\right|_{D_{k} ; r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}|A|_{r}, \quad r>0
$$

We now estimate $\bar{\partial} w_{k}$ on $D_{k}$. By Proposition 4.2, we have for $r>0$

$$
\left|\bar{\partial} w_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}|\bar{\partial} v|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M) ; r+1}|v|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M) ; 1+\varepsilon}+C_{r, \varepsilon}|v|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M) ; 1+\varepsilon}|v|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M) ; r+1}
$$

Recall that $v=-S^{t} P A$ is well defined on the neighborhood $\mathcal{N}_{t}(M)$ of $M$.
To apply estimate on time-one mappings stated in Proposition 4.2, we need to estimate $\bar{\partial} v$ on $\mathcal{N}_{t}(M)$. Applying the homotopy formula for the third time, we can express on $\mathcal{N}_{t}(M)$,

$$
\bar{\partial} v=\left[S^{t}, \bar{\partial}\right] P A-S^{t} \bar{\partial} P A=\left[S^{t}, \bar{\partial}\right] P A-S^{t} A+S^{t} Q \bar{\partial} A
$$

Recall (3.20) says that

$$
\left|\left[\bar{\partial}, S^{t}\right] v\right|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M), a} \leq C_{a, b} t^{b-a}|v|_{M, b}, \quad 0<a \leq b<a+L
$$

Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\bar{\partial} v\right|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M) ; r+1} & \leq C_{r}\left(t^{-1 / 2}|P A|_{r+1 / 2}+t^{-1}|A|_{r}+t^{-3 / 2}\left|Q \bar{\partial} A\right|_{r-1 / 2}\right) \\
& \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}\left(2 t^{-1}|A|_{r}+2 t^{-3 / 2}|A|_{r}|A|_{\varepsilon}\right), \quad r>1
\end{aligned}
$$

where we again use the integrability condition to get $\left|Q \bar{\partial} A\right|_{r-\frac{1}{2}} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}|A|_{\varepsilon}|A|_{r}$ by (7.10). Since $|A|_{\varepsilon} \leq t^{\alpha}$ for $\alpha>1$, we get $\left|\bar{\partial} v\right|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M) ; r+1} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon} t^{-1}|A|_{r}$ for $r>0$ and hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\bar{\partial} v\right|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M) ; r+1}|v|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M) ; 1+\varepsilon} \leq 3 C_{r, \varepsilon}^{\prime} t^{\alpha-1}|A|_{r}, \quad r>1 \\
& |v|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M) ; 1+\varepsilon}|v|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M) ; r+1} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}^{\prime \prime} t^{\alpha-1 / 2}|A|_{r}, \quad r>1
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus

$$
\left|\bar{\partial} w_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon} t^{\alpha-1}|A|_{r}, \quad r>1
$$

Using the initial condition (7.1)-(7.2), we get

$$
\left|\bar{\partial} w_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; s} \leq C_{s, \varepsilon} t^{2 \alpha-1}, \quad \alpha>1 ; \quad\left|\bar{\partial} w_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon} t^{\alpha-1}|A|_{r}, \quad r>1
$$

Combining them with (7.15)-(7.16), we get for $I_{5}=\bar{\partial} w_{k}+A_{k} \partial w_{k}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|I_{5}\right|_{D_{k} ; s} \leq C_{s, \varepsilon} t^{2 \alpha-1}<t^{d \alpha} \\
& \left|I_{5}\right|_{D_{k} ; r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}|A|_{r}, \quad r>1
\end{aligned}
$$

Next, we estimate the low and high-order norms of $\left(I+\mathcal{K}_{k}\right)^{-1}$. Recall that

$$
\mathcal{K}_{k}=\overline{\partial f_{k}}+A_{k} \bar{\partial} f_{k}=\overline{\partial v_{k}}+\overline{\partial w_{k}}+A_{k} \bar{\partial} v_{k}+A_{k} \bar{\partial} w_{k}
$$

Thus

$$
\left|\mathcal{K}_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}\left(\left|v_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; r+1}+\left|w_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; r+1}+\left|A_{k} \bar{\partial} v_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; r}+\left|A_{k} \bar{\partial} w_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; r}\right)
$$

By (7.13), we get

$$
\left|w_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; s+1} \leq C_{s, \varepsilon}|v|_{s+1} \leq C_{s, \varepsilon}^{\prime} t^{-1 / 2+\alpha}, \quad\left|w_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; r+1} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}|v|_{r+1} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}^{\prime} t^{-1 / 2}|A|_{r}
$$

By (7.15)-(7.16), we get better estimates for the last two terms in $\mathcal{K}_{k}$. Therefore,

$$
\left|\mathcal{K}_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; s} \leq C_{s, \varepsilon} t^{-1 / 2+\alpha}<1 / 2
$$

provided

$$
C_{s, \varepsilon} t^{-1 / 2+\alpha}<1 / 2
$$

With this, we also have

$$
\left|\mathcal{K}_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon} t^{-1 / 2}|A|_{r}, \quad r>1
$$

We now estimate $\left(I+\mathcal{K}_{k}\right)^{-1}$. Using the formula $\left(I+\mathcal{K}_{k}\right)^{-1}=\left[\operatorname{det}\left(I+\mathcal{K}_{k}\right)\right]^{-1} B$, where $B$ is the adjugate matrix of $I+\mathcal{K}_{k}$, we see that every entry in $\left(I+\mathcal{K}_{k}\right)^{-1}$ is a polynomial in $\left[\operatorname{det}\left(I+\mathcal{K}_{k}\right)\right]^{-1}$ and entries of $\mathcal{K}_{k}$. By using the product and quotient rules (3.2)-(3.3), and (7.17) and (7.19), we get

$$
\left|\left(I+\mathcal{K}_{k}\right)^{-1}\right|_{D_{k} ; s}<C_{s, \varepsilon}, \quad\left|\left(I+\mathcal{K}_{k}\right)^{-1}\right|_{D_{k} ; r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon} t^{-1 / 2}|A|_{r}
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\left(I+\mathcal{K}_{k}\right)^{-1} I_{j}\right|_{D_{k} ; s} \leq C_{s, \varepsilon}\left|I_{j}\right|_{D_{k} ; s} \leq C_{s, \varepsilon}^{\prime} t^{d \alpha} \\
& \left|\left(I+\mathcal{K}_{k}\right)^{-1} I_{j}\right|_{D_{k} ; r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}(\left|\left(I+\mathcal{K}_{k}\right)\right|_{r}\left|I_{j}\right|_{D_{k} ; s}+\left|\left(I+\mathcal{K}_{k}\right)\right|_{D_{k} ; s}\left|I_{j}\right|_{D_{k} ; r}\right) \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}|A|_{r}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus $\widetilde{A}_{k}=\left(I+\mathcal{K}_{k}\right)^{-1}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{5} I_{j}\right)$ satifies

$$
|\widetilde{A}|_{s} \leq C_{s, \varepsilon} t^{d \alpha}, \quad|\widetilde{A}|_{r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}|A|_{r}, \quad r>1
$$

provided (7.8) holds.
Finally, we estimate the norms of $A^{\prime}=\widetilde{A} \circ G$, where $G=F^{-1}$. Let $G_{k}=I+g_{k}$. Then $g_{k}=-(v)_{k}+\tilde{w}_{k}$ with $\tilde{w}_{k}(\cdot)=w_{k}(\cdot,-1)$. Set

$$
D_{k}^{1}:=\psi_{k}\left(U_{k} \cap M_{1}\right)
$$

By Proposition 4.2, we have

$$
\left|f_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; r+1 / 2}+\left|g_{k}\right|_{D_{k}^{\prime} ; r+1 / 2} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}|A|_{r}
$$

Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|f_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; s+1 / 2}+\left|g_{k}\right|_{D_{k}^{1} ; s+1 / 2} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon} t^{\alpha} \\
& \left|f_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; m+1 / 2}+\left|g_{k}\right|_{D_{k}^{1} ; m+1 / 2} \leq C_{m, \varepsilon}|A|_{m}
\end{aligned}
$$

With (7.8), we already require $m>2$. Thus, via interpolation,

$$
\left|f_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; 2}+\left|g_{k}\right|_{D_{k}^{1} ; 2} \leq C_{s, m, \varepsilon} t^{\frac{m-4 / 2}{m-s}}|\alpha| \frac{2 / 2-s}{m}
$$

This will allow us to control the $C^{2}$ norm of $\rho \circ G$ of the new domain $M^{\prime}=F(M)$.
By estimate (3.5) for composition, we have

$$
\left|A^{\prime}\right|_{M^{1}, r}=|\widetilde{A} \circ G|_{M^{1}, r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}\left(|\widetilde{A}|_{r}\left(1+|G|_{M^{1}, 1+\varepsilon}^{2}\right)+\|\widetilde{A}\|_{1+\varepsilon}|G|_{M^{1}, r}+\|\widetilde{A}\|_{\varepsilon}\right)
$$

Using estimates (7.20) for $\widetilde{A}$ and (7.21)-(7.22) for $g_{k}$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|A^{\prime}\right|_{M^{1}, s} & \leq C_{s, \varepsilon} t^{d \alpha} \\
\left|A^{\prime}\right|_{M^{1}, m} & \leq C_{m, \varepsilon}|A|_{m}
\end{aligned}
$$

We now determine the parameters. For (7.8), (7.12), (7.18) to hold, we need

$$
\begin{gathered}
d \alpha<m-s-2 \varepsilon, \quad d \alpha<2 \alpha-\frac{1}{2}-\varepsilon, \quad m>2+2 \varepsilon \\
C_{s, m, \varepsilon} L_{m} t^{\varepsilon} \leq 1, \quad C_{s} t^{-1 / 2+\alpha}<1 / 2
\end{gathered}
$$

So we take $d=1+\varepsilon, \alpha=1+\varepsilon, s=1+\varepsilon$. Fix a small $\varepsilon>0$. Thus, it is easy to check that conditions (7.25)-(7.26) are satisfied by

$$
m=2+C \varepsilon, \quad 0<t \leq t_{0}^{*}
$$

where $t_{0}^{*}$ depends on $C_{s, m}, C_{s}$ which in turn depends on $M$. Further, $t_{0}^{*}, C_{s, m}, C_{s}$ are stable under small $C^{2}$ perturbations of $b M$. We can write (7.23) as

$$
\left|A^{\prime}\right|_{s} \leq t^{d \alpha}
$$

which is possible provided $t_{0}^{*}$ is sufficiently small. Thus, we can rewrite (7.24) as

$$
\left|A^{\prime}\right|_{M^{1}, m} \leq C_{m} L_{m}, \quad m>1
$$

which is possible as $m, s, \alpha, d, \varepsilon$ are fixed now while $t_{0}^{*}>0$ can still be chosen sufficiently small.
7.2. A preview for the sequence of embeddings. We now outline the iteration process in the next section. Set

$$
t_{j}=t_{j-1}^{d}=t_{0}^{d^{j}}, \quad M^{0}=M, \quad A^{0}=A \in \Lambda_{(0,1)}^{m}(M, \Theta)
$$

By shrinking $t_{0}^{*}$ further, we will find a sequence of strongly pseudoconvex domains $M^{j}$ in $\mathcal{M}$, a sequence of complex structures defined by vector fields $X^{j}:=$ $\left\{X_{1}^{j}, \ldots, X_{m}^{j}\right\}$ with an adapted frame determined by $A^{j} \in \Lambda_{(0,1)}^{m}\left(M^{j}, \Theta\right)$, and a sequence of smooth mappings $F^{j}$ such that $M^{j+1}=F^{j}\left(M^{j}\right), F^{j}$ transforms $X^{j}$ into $X^{j+1}$, and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|A^{j}\right|_{M^{j}, s} & \leq t_{j}^{s} \\
\left|A^{j}\right|_{M^{j}, m} & \leq L_{j, m} \\
t_{j}^{s} C_{s, m, \varepsilon} L_{j, m} & \leq 1
\end{aligned}
$$

provided (7.27)-(7.29) hold for $j=0$. Further, $F_{k}^{j}\left(z_{k}\right)=z_{k}+f_{k}^{j}\left(z_{k}\right)$ and $G_{k}^{j}\left(z_{k}\right)=$ $z_{k}+g_{k}^{j}\left(z_{k}\right)$ with $G_{k}^{j}=\left(\left(F^{j}\right)^{-1}\right)_{k}$ satisfy

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|f_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j} ; s+1 / 2}+\left|g_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j+1} ; s+1 / 2} & \leq C_{s} t_{j}^{\alpha} \\
\left|f_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j} ; m+1 / 2}+\left|g_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j+1} ; m+1 / 2} & \leq C_{m}\left|A^{j}\right|_{m} \\
\left|A^{j+1}\right|_{M^{j+1}, m} & \leq C_{s, m}\left|A^{j}\right|_{M^{j}, m}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $D_{k}^{j}=\psi_{k}\left(M^{j} \cap U_{k}\right)$. Note that (7.32) shows that

$$
\left|f_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j} ; m+1 / 2}+\left|g_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j+1} ; m+1 / 2} \leq C_{m}\left|A^{j}\right|_{M^{j}, m} \leq C_{m, s}^{\prime j+1}\left|A^{0}\right|_{M, m}
$$

which grows slowly, whereas

$$
\left|f_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j}, s+1 / 2}+\left|g_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j+1}, s+1 / 2} \leq C_{s} t^{\alpha d^{j}}
$$

decays rapidly. Then the compositions $F^{j} \circ \cdots \circ F^{0}$ converge in $\Lambda^{m^{\prime}}(M)$ norm for any $m^{\prime}<m+1 / 2$.
7.3. General case: $b M \in \Lambda^{s_{*}} \cap C^{2}$ with $s_{*} \geq 2$. When we deal with a domain $M$ whose boundary is less smooth, we first smooth defining function of the domain to get a smooth and larger domain. We then extend the formally integrable complex structure $A$ to the larger domain and smooth the structure. Of course, both the extension and smoothing destroy the formal integrability of the structure. Nevertheless, the failure of formal integrability can be measured by a commutator of $\left[S^{t}, \widetilde{\partial}\right]$ that has a good estimate on the larger domain $\mathcal{N}_{t}(M)$. This allows us to use the homotopy formula on the larger domain and construct smoothing diffeomorphism defined on a (larger) domain that contains $M$. Its restriction on the original $M$ will be used to transform the structure to new one that is still formally integrable on the new domain. Repeating this via a Nash-Moser iteration scheme, the composed diffeomorphism will transform the structure on $M$ to the standard complex structure on $\mathcal{M}$.

We apply smoothing to the defining function $\rho$ of $M$ by setting

$$
\rho_{\hat{t}}=\rho * \chi_{\hat{t}}, \quad \hat{t}=\left(c_{*} t\right)^{\frac{1}{s_{*}}}, \quad M_{\hat{t}}^{t}=\left\{\rho_{\hat{t}}<t\right\}
$$

Here using $t^{\frac{1}{s_{*}}}$ instead of $t$ reflects that $\rho \in \Lambda^{s_{*}}$. See Yie [62] and [14] for similar uses. We now have

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left\|\rho_{\hat{t}}-\rho\right\|_{0} \leq C_{2} \hat{t}^{s^{*}}|\rho|_{s^{*}} \\
\left\|\rho_{\hat{t}}-\rho\right\|_{2} \leq \varepsilon, \quad \hat{t}<\hat{t}^{*}\left(\nabla^{2} \rho\right) \\
\left|\rho_{\hat{t}}\right|_{b} \leq C_{b, 2} \hat{t}^{s_{*}-b}|\rho|_{s_{*}}, \quad b \geq s_{*}
\end{gathered}
$$

We also have $\hat{t}^{s_{*}}=c_{*} t$. When $c_{*}$ is sufficiently small, we have $C_{s_{*}} \hat{t}^{s_{*}}\|\rho\|_{s_{*}}<t / C$ by (7.34). Thus

$$
M \subset \mathcal{N}_{t / C_{*}}(M) \subset M_{\hat{t}}^{t} \subset \mathcal{N}_{C_{*} t}(M)
$$

We emphasize that $\hat{t}^{*}\left(\partial^{2} \rho\right)$ in (7.35) depends on the modulus of continuity of $\partial^{2} \rho$. When $s_{*}=2,|\rho|_{s_{*}}$ needs be replaced by $\|\rho\|_{2}$. Then we can replace all norms in (7.34)-(7.36), which are stronger inequalities.

To simplify formulas, we set

$$
\mu(a)=\frac{\left(a-s_{*}\right)_{+}}{s_{*}}
$$

Then (7.36) becomes $\left\|\rho_{\bar{I}}\right\|_{b} \leq C_{b} t^{-\mu(b)}\|\rho\|_{s_{*}}$, where $C_{b}$ depends on $s_{*}$ also.
To limit the loss of derivatives, we will use $M_{t}^{t} \subset \mathcal{N}_{C_{*}, t}(M)$, which allows us to apply the estimates of $S^{t} v$ and $\left|\bar{\partial}, S^{t}\right| v$ on $\mathcal{N}_{C_{*}, t}(M)$, as well as the homotopy formula on the smooth subdomain $M_{t}^{t}$ of $\mathcal{N}_{C_{*}, t}(M)$. Note that the original $S^{t} v$ is defined on $\mathcal{N}_{t}(M)$. Replacing $S^{t} v$ by $S^{t / C} v$ which is still denoted it by $S^{t} v$, we may assume that $S^{t} v$ and its estimates in Lemma 3.6 hold on $\mathcal{N}_{C_{*}, t}(M)$ for any given $C_{*}$. We will also have

$$
\|v\|_{C^{0}\left(\mathcal{N}_{t}(M)\right)}<t / C
$$

Since $M_{t}^{t}$ contains $\mathcal{N}_{t / C_{*}}(M)$, the time-one map $F$ of $v$ is well-defined on the original domain $M$; consequently, we can define a new almost complex structure $A$ on $M^{\prime}=F(M)$ that is still formally integrable.

We have homotopy operators satisfying

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|P_{M_{t}^{t}} \varphi\right|_{M_{t}^{t}, r} & \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}\left(\nabla \rho_{\bar{I}_{I}} \nabla^{2} \rho_{\bar{I}}\right)\left(\left|\varphi\right|_{M_{t}^{t}, r-1 / 2}+\left|\rho_{\bar{I}}\right|_{r+2}\left|\rho_{\bar{I}}\right|_{2+\varepsilon}^{b}\left|\varphi\right|_{M_{t}^{t}, \varepsilon}\right) \\
& \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}\left(\nabla \rho_{\bar{I}}, \nabla^{2} \rho_{\bar{I}}\right)\left(\left|\varphi\right|_{M_{t}^{t}, r-1 / 2}+t^{-\mu(r+2)-b \varepsilon} L_{0}\left|\varphi\right|_{M_{t}^{t}, \varepsilon}\right), \quad r>1 / 2
\end{aligned}
$$

The same estimate holds when $P_{M_{t}^{t}}$ is replaced by $Q_{M_{t}^{t}}$.
For the rest of this section, we denote $P_{M_{t}^{t}}, Q_{M_{t}^{t}}$ by $P, Q$.
Recall that $S^{t} A$ is smooth on $\mathcal{N}_{t / C_{*}}(M)$ and it depends only on the values of $A$ on $M$. To ease notation, replace $S^{t}$ by $S^{C_{*} t}$, we may assume that $S^{t} A$ is defined on $\mathcal{N}_{t}(M)$. Thus, we set $v=-P S^{t} A$, which is well-defined on $\mathcal{N}_{t}(M)$ without further extension. Notice that unlike the strongly pseudoconvex case, $S^{t}$ is applied to $A$ directly. Let $F$ be the time-one map of $v$ on $\mathcal{N}_{t}(M)$. We have $f_{k}=v_{k}+w_{k}$.

In the following, we will denote by $\partial$ a partial derivative of order 1. Then on $D_{k}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
A_{k} & +\bar{\partial} f_{k}+A_{k} \partial f_{k}=A_{k}-\bar{\partial}\left(P S^{t} A\right)_{k}-A_{k} \partial\left(P S^{t} A\right)_{k}+A_{k} \partial w_{k}+\bar{\partial} w_{k} \\
& =\left(\left(I-S^{t}\right) A\right)_{k}+\left(Q S^{t} \bar{\partial} A\right)_{k}-A_{k} \partial\left(P S^{t} A\right)_{k}+\left(A_{k} \partial w_{k}+\bar{\partial} w_{k}\right)+\left(Q\left[\bar{\partial}, S^{t}\right] A\right)_{k} \\
