& =I_{1}+I_{2}-I_{3}+I_{4}+I_{5}
\end{aligned}
$$

with $A \equiv \mathcal{E}_{M} A$ and

$$
\begin{aligned}
& I_{1}=\left(\left(I-S^{t}\right) A\right)_{k}, \quad I_{2}=\left(Q S^{t} \bar{\partial} A\right)_{k}, \quad I_{3}=A_{k} \partial\left(P S^{t} A\right)_{k}, \\
& I_{4}=A_{k} \partial w_{k}+\bar{\partial} w_{k}, \quad I_{5}=\left(Q\left[\bar{\partial}, S^{t}\right] A\right)_{k}, \quad \mathcal{K}_{k}=\overline{\partial f_{k}}+A_{k} \bar{\partial} f_{k} .
\end{aligned}
$$

We assume

$$
\begin{gathered}
|A|_{s}<t^{\alpha}, \quad \alpha>1, s>1 \\
|A|_{m} \leq L_{m, \varepsilon}, \quad m>3 / 2 \\
\| \rho \|_{s_{*}} \leq R_{s_{*}}, \quad R_{s_{*}} \leq L_{m, \varepsilon}, \quad m+1 / 2>s_{*}
\end{gathered}
$$

(Here $\varepsilon$ is determined via (7.57)-(7.58).) Then by (7.38), we have

$$
\left|I_{1}\right|_{D_{k} ; s}=\left|\left(\left(I-S^{t}\right) A\right)_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; s} \leq C_{s, m} t^{m-s}|A|_{m}, \quad s \leq m<s+L
$$

Assume that

$$
m-s>d \alpha+\varepsilon, \quad t^{\varepsilon} C_{s, m} L_{m}<1
$$

Then we have

$$
\left|I_{1}\right|_{D_{k} ; s} \leq t^{d \alpha}, \quad\left|I_{1}\right|_{D_{k}, \ell} \leq C_{\ell}|A|_{\ell}, \quad \forall \ell>0
$$

We will seek additional conditions to achieve

$$
\left|I_{j}\right|_{D_{k} ; s} \leq t^{d \alpha}, \quad\left|I_{j}\right|_{D_{k} ; m} \leq C_{m, \varepsilon} L_{m}, \quad j=2, \ldots, 5
$$

Recall that $S^{t} \bar{\partial} E A=S^{t} \bar{\partial} A$ on $\mathcal{N}_{\ell}(M)$. Therefore, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
|v|_{M^{t}, r} & =\left|P_{M^{t}} S^{t} A\right|_{M^{t}, r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}^{\prime}\left|\rho_{\ell}\right|_{2+\varepsilon}^{b}\left|S^{t} A\right|_{M^{t}, \varepsilon}\left|\rho_{\ell}\right|_{r+2}+C_{r, \varepsilon}^{\prime}\left|S^{t} A\right|_{M^{r}, r-1 / 2} \\
& \leq C_{r, \varepsilon} t^{-\mu(r+2)-b \varepsilon} R_{s_{*}}|A|_{\varepsilon}+C_{r, \varepsilon}\left|S^{t} A\right|_{M^{t}, r-1 / 2}, \quad r>1
\end{aligned}
$$

(7.41) $|v|_{M^{t}, \varepsilon}=\left|P_{M^{t}} S^{t} A\right|_{M^{t}, \varepsilon} \leq C_{\varepsilon}\left(\left|\rho_{\ell}\right|_{2+\varepsilon}^{b+1}\right| S^{t} A\left|{ }_{M^{t}, \varepsilon}+\left|S^{t} A\right|_{M^{t}, \varepsilon}\right) \leq C_{\varepsilon}^{\prime} t^{\alpha-b \varepsilon}$.

Note that $\mu(a+\varepsilon) \leq \mu(a)+\varepsilon$ and

$$
\mu(3) \leq \frac{1}{2}
$$

In particular,

$$
\left|w_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; 1+\varepsilon} \leq C_{\varepsilon}|v|_{1+\varepsilon} \leq 2 C_{\varepsilon}^{\prime} R_{s_{*}} t^{\alpha-1 / 2-b \varepsilon}
$$

For $r>1 / 2$, we have

$$
|I_{2}|_{D_{k} ; r}=\left|Q S^{t} \bar{\partial} A\right|_{D_{k}, r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}^{\prime \prime}\left(\left|\rho_{\ell}\right|_{r+2}\left|\rho\right|_{2+\varepsilon}^{b}\left|S^{t} \bar{\partial} A\right|_{M^{t}, \varepsilon}+\left|S^{t} \bar{\partial} A\right|_{M^{t}, r-1 / 2}\right)
$$

Since $s>1+\varepsilon$, we have $\left|S^{t} \bar{\partial} A\right|_{M^{t}, \varepsilon} \leq C_{\varepsilon}|A|_{s}^{2}$. Then

$$
|I_{2}|_{D_{k} ; s}<C_{s, \varepsilon} t^{-\mu(s+2)-b \varepsilon} R_{s_{*}} t^{2 \alpha}+C_{s, \varepsilon} t^{-1 / 2} t^{2 \alpha}<t^{d \alpha}
$$

assuming

$$
2 \alpha-\mu(s+2)>d \alpha+b \varepsilon+\varepsilon, \quad 2 \alpha-\frac{1}{2}>d \alpha, \quad C_{s, \varepsilon} t^{\varepsilon}<1
$$

We also have a coarse estimate

$$
|I_{2}|_{D_{k} ; \ell} \leq C_{\ell, \varepsilon}\left(t^{2 \alpha-\mu(\ell+2)-b \varepsilon} R_{s_{*}}+|A|_{\ell}\right), \quad \forall \ell>0
$$

In particular,

$$
|I_{2}|_{D_{k} ; m} \leq C_{m, \varepsilon}\left(t^{-\mu(m+2)-b \varepsilon} t^{2 \alpha} R_{s_{*}}+|A|_{m}\right) \leq C_{m} L_{m}
$$

assuming

$$
2 \alpha-\mu(m+2)>b \varepsilon, \quad C_{m} t^{\varepsilon} \leq 1 / 2
$$

We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
|I_{3}|_{D_{k} ; r} & =\left|A_{k} \partial\left(P_{M^{t}} S^{t} A_{k}\right)\right|_{D_{k}, r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}\left(|A|_{r}\left|P S^{t} A\right|_{D_{k}, 1+\varepsilon}+|A|_{\varepsilon}\left|P S^{t} A\right|_{D_{k}, r+1}\right) \\
& \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}^{\prime}|A|_{r}\left|\rho_{\ell}\right|_{2+\varepsilon}^{b}\left|\rho_{\bar{\ell}}\right|_{3+\varepsilon} t^{\alpha}+C_{r, \varepsilon}^{\prime} t^{\alpha}\left(\left|\rho_{\bar{\ell}}\right|_{r+3}\left|\rho_{\ell}\right|_{2+\varepsilon}^{b} t^{\alpha}+t^{-1 / 2}|A|_{r}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, we get

$$
|I_{3}|_{D_{k} ; s}<3 C_{s, \varepsilon}\left(t^{2 \alpha-\mu(s+3)-2 b \varepsilon} R_{s_{*}}+t^{2 \alpha-1 / 2} L_{m}\right)<t^{d \alpha}
$$

assuming

$$
2 \alpha-\mu(s+3)>d \alpha+2 b \varepsilon+\varepsilon, \quad 2 \alpha-1 / 2>d \alpha+\varepsilon, \quad 3 C_{s, \varepsilon} R_{s_{*}} t^{\varepsilon}<1
$$

We have a coarse estimate

$$
|I_{3}|_{\ell} \leq C_{\ell, \varepsilon}(2|A|_{\ell}+t^{2 \alpha-\mu(\ell+3)-2 b \varepsilon} R_{s_{*}}), \quad \forall \ell>0
$$

In particular,

$$
|I_{3}|_{m, \varepsilon} \leq C_{m, \varepsilon}(2|A|_{m}+t^{2 \alpha-\mu(m+3)-2 \varepsilon} R_{s_{*}}) \leq 3 C_{m, \varepsilon} L_{m}
$$

assuming

$$
2 \alpha>\mu(m+3)+2 b \varepsilon
$$

We have by $(7.40)$

$$
|w_{k}|_{D_{k} ; r+1} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}|v|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M) ; r+1} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}^{\prime}\left(t^{-\mu(r+3)-b \varepsilon} R_{s_{*}}|A|_{s}+t^{-1 / 2}|A|_{r}\right)
$$

for $r>0$. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|A_{k} \partial w_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; r} & \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}\left(|A|_{r}\left\|\partial w_{k}\right\|_{D_{k} ; 0}+\|A\|_{0}\left|\partial w_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; r}\right) \\
& \leq C_{r, s, \varepsilon}^{\prime}\left(\left(3 t^{\alpha-\mu(3)-b \varepsilon}+2 t^{\alpha-1 / 2-b \varepsilon}\right)|A|_{r}+t^{\alpha-\mu(r+3)-b \varepsilon} R_{s_{*}}|A|_{s}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|A_{k} \partial w_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; s} \leq C_{s, \varepsilon}\left(t^{2 \alpha-\mu(s+3)-b \varepsilon}+t^{2 \alpha-1 / 2-b \varepsilon}\right) R_{s_{*}} \\
& \left|A_{k} \partial w_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; \ell} \leq C_{\ell, \varepsilon}\left(R_{s_{*}}|A|_{\ell}+\left(t^{2 \alpha-\mu(\ell+3)-b \varepsilon}+t^{\alpha-1 / 2-b \varepsilon}\right) R_{s_{*}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We also have a coarse estimate.

$$
\left|A_{k} \partial w_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; \ell} \leq C_{\ell, \varepsilon}\left(|A|_{\ell}+t^{2 \alpha-\mu(\ell+3)-b \varepsilon} R_{s_{*}}\right)
$$

In particular, we have

$$
\left|A_{k} \partial w_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; m} \leq C_{m, \varepsilon} L_{m}
$$

On $M^{t}$, we have $v=-P S^{t} A$ and hence by the homotopy formula

$$
\bar{\partial} v=-\bar{\partial} S^{t} A+Q \bar{\partial} S^{t} A
$$

Note that $\bar{\partial} S^{t} A=\left[\bar{\partial}, S^{t}\right] A+S^{t} \bar{\partial} A$ implies that

$$
\left|\bar{\partial} S^{t} A\right|_{r+1} \leq C_{r, m}\left(2 t^{m-r-1}|A|_{m}+2 t^{-2}|A|_{s}|A|_{r}\right), \quad r>1
$$

Combining with estimate on $Q$, we obtain for $m \geq r \geq s>1$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\bar{\partial} v\right|_{r+1} \leq & C_{r, m, \varepsilon}\left(2 t^{m-r-1}|A|_{m}+2 t^{-2}|A|_{s}|A|_{r}+\left|\rho_{1}\right|_{r+3}\left|\rho_{t}\right|_{2+\varepsilon}^{b}\left|\bar{\partial} S^{t} A\right|_{\varepsilon}\right) \\
& \leq C_{r, m, \varepsilon}^{\prime}\left(2 t^{m-r-1}|A|_{m}+2 t^{-2}|A|_{s}|A|_{r}+t^{2 \alpha} t^{-\mu(r+3)-b \varepsilon} R_{s_{*}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We now estimate $\bar{\partial} w_{k}$ on $D_{k}$. Recall that (7.42) says $\mu(3) \leq 1 / 2$. By (4.5), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\bar{\partial} w_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; r} \leq & C_{r, \varepsilon}\left|\bar{\partial} v\right|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M) ; r+1}|v|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M) ; \varepsilon}+C_{r, \varepsilon}|v|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M) ; 1+\varepsilon}|v|_{\mathcal{N}_{t}(M) ; r+1} \\
\leq & C_{r, \varepsilon} t^{\alpha-b \varepsilon}\left(t^{m-r-1}|A|_{m}+t^{\alpha-2}|A|_{r}+t^{2 \alpha-\mu(r+3)-b \varepsilon} R_{s_{*}}\right) \\
& +C_{r, \varepsilon} t^{\alpha-1 / 2-b \varepsilon}\left(t^{-\mu(r+3)-b \varepsilon}|A|_{\varepsilon}+t^{-1 / 2}|A|_{r}\right) \\
\leq & C_{r, \varepsilon}^{\prime} t^{\alpha-b \varepsilon}\left(t^{m-r-1}|A|_{m}+t^{\alpha-2}|A|_{r}+t^{2 \alpha-\mu(r+3)} R_{s_{*}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Recall that $I_{4}=\bar{\partial} w_{k}+A_{k} \partial w_{k}$. Thus

$$
\left|I_{4}\right|_{D_{k} ; s} \leq C_{s, \varepsilon} t^{2 \alpha-\mu(s+3)-b \varepsilon}+C_{s, \varepsilon} t^{3 \alpha-2}+C_{m, \varepsilon} t^{\alpha+m-s-1-b \varepsilon}|A|_{m} \leq t^{d \alpha}
$$

assuming
$2 \alpha-\mu(s+3)>d \alpha+(b+1) \varepsilon, \quad 3 \alpha-2>d \alpha+\varepsilon, \quad \alpha+m-s-1>d \alpha+(b+1) \varepsilon$.
Hence, we have a coarse estimate

$$
\left|I_{4}\right|_{\ell} \leq C_{\ell, \varepsilon}\left(|A|_{\ell}+t^{2 \alpha-\mu(\ell+3)-b \varepsilon} R_{s_{*}}\right), \quad \forall \ell>1
$$

Also by (7.45), we have $\left|I_{4}\right|_{m} \leq C_{m, \varepsilon} L_{m}$.
We have

$$
\left|I_{5}\right|_{D_{k} ; r}=\left|Q\left(\left|\bar{\partial}, S^{t}\right| A\right)\right|_{r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}\left(\left|\rho_{1}\right|_{r+5 / 2}\left|\rho_{1}\right|_{2+\varepsilon}^{b}\left|\bar{\partial}, S^{t}\right| A\right|_{\varepsilon}+\left|\left|\bar{\partial}, S^{t}\right| A\right|_{r}\right), \quad r>0
$$

Recall that $\left|\left|\bar{\partial}, S^{t}\right| A\right|_{b} \leq C_{a, b} t^{a-b}|A|_{a}$ for $a \geq b$. We can estimate the last term like $I_{1}$. Also, $\left|\left|\bar{\partial}, S^{t}\right| A\right|_{\varepsilon} \leq C_{\varepsilon} t^{s-\varepsilon} t^{\alpha}$. Therefore,

$$
\left|I_{5}\right|_{s} \leq t^{d \alpha}, \quad\left|I_{5}\right|_{m} \leq C_{m, \varepsilon} L_{m}
$$

assuming

$$
s+\alpha-\mu(s+5 / 2)>d \alpha+b \varepsilon+\varepsilon, \quad s+\alpha-\mu(m+5 / 2)>b \varepsilon+\varepsilon
$$

We also have a coarse estimate

$$
\left|I_{5}\right|_{D_{k} ; \ell} \leq C_{\ell, \varepsilon}\left(t^{s+\alpha-\mu(\ell+5 / 2)-b \varepsilon} R_{s_{*}}+|A|_{\ell}\right), \quad \forall \ell>0
$$

Next, we estimate the low and high-order norms of $\left(I+\mathcal{K}_{k}\right)^{-1}$. Recall that

$$
\mathcal{K}_{k}=\overline{\mathcal{\delta} f_{k}}+A_{k} \overline{\mathcal{\delta}} f_{k}=\overline{\mathcal{\delta v}_{k}}+\overline{\mathcal{\delta} w_{k}}+A_{k} \overline{\mathcal{\delta}} v_{k}+A_{k} \overline{\mathcal{\delta}} w_{k}
$$

Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\mathcal{K}_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; r} & \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}\left(\left|v_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; r+1}+\left|w_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; r+1}+\left|A_{k} \overline{\mathcal{\delta}} v_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; r}+\left|A_{k} \overline{\mathcal{\delta}} w_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; r}\right) \\
& \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}^{\prime}\left(2\left|v_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; r+1}+2\left|w_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; r+1}+\left|A_{k}\right|_{r}\left(|v|_{\varepsilon}+\left|w_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; 1+\varepsilon}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Recall that $|v|_{1+\varepsilon}+\left|w_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; 1+\varepsilon}<C_{\varepsilon} R_{s_{*}} t^{\alpha-\mu(3)-b \varepsilon} \leq C_{\varepsilon}^{\prime} R_{s_{*}} t^{\alpha-1 / 2-b \varepsilon}$. By (7.46), we have

$$
\left|w_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; r+1} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}|v|_{M^{t_{1}}, r+1} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}^{\prime}\left(R_{s_{*}} t^{-\mu(r+3)-b \varepsilon}|A|_{s}+t^{-1 / 2}|A|_{r}\right)
$$

Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\mathcal{K}_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; s} \leq C_{s, \varepsilon} R_{s_{*}}\left(t^{-\mu(s+3)-b \varepsilon}+t^{-1 / 2-b \varepsilon}\right) t^{\alpha} \\
& \left|\mathcal{K}_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}\left(t^{-1 / 2-b \varepsilon}|A|_{r}+R_{s_{*}} t^{\alpha-\mu(r+3)-b \varepsilon}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Assume that

$$
\alpha>\mu(s+3)+b \varepsilon+\varepsilon, \quad C_{s, \varepsilon} t^{\varepsilon}<1 / 2
$$

We now estimate $\left(I+\mathcal{K}_{k}\right)^{-1}$. Using the formula $\left(I+\mathcal{K}_{k}\right)^{-1}=\left[\operatorname{det}\left(I+\mathcal{K}_{k}\right)\right]^{-1} B$, where $B$ is the adjugate matrix of $I+\mathcal{K}_{k}$, we see that every entry in $\left(I+\mathcal{K}_{k}\right)^{-1}$ is a polynomial in $\left[\operatorname{det}\left(I+\mathcal{K}_{k}\right)\right]^{-1}$ and entries of $\mathcal{K}_{k}$. By using the product rule (3.2) and (7.49), we get

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left|\left(I+\mathcal{K}_{k}\right)^{-1}\right|_{D_{k} ; s}<C_{s, \varepsilon} \\
\left|\left(I+\mathcal{K}_{k}\right)^{-1}\right|_{D_{k} ; \ell} \leq C_{\ell, \varepsilon}\left(t^{-1 / 2-b \varepsilon}|A|_{\ell}+R_{s_{*}} t^{\alpha-\mu(\ell+3)-b \varepsilon}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\left(I+\mathcal{K}_{k}\right)^{-1} I_{j}\right|_{D_{k} ; s} & \leq C_{s, \varepsilon}\left|I_{j}\right|_{s} \leq t^{d \alpha} \\
\left|\left(I+\mathcal{K}_{k}\right)^{-1} I_{j}\right|_{D_{k} ; r} & \leq C_{r}\left|\left(I+\mathcal{K}_{k}\right)^{-1}\right|_{s}\left|I_{j}\right|_{r}+C_{r}\left|\left(I+\mathcal{K}_{k}\right)^{-1}\right|_{r}\left|I_{j}\right|_{s} \\
& \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}^{\prime}\left(\left|I_{j}\right|_{r}+R_{s_{*}} t_{j}^{d \alpha+\alpha-\mu(r+3)-b \varepsilon}+R_{s_{*}} t^{d \alpha-1 / 2-b \varepsilon}|A|_{r}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

In particular, we have

$$
\left|\left(I+\mathcal{K}_{k}\right)^{-1} I_{j}\right|_{D_{k} ; m} \leq C_{m, \varepsilon} L_{m}
$$

since $d \alpha>1 / 2$ and

$$
d \alpha+\alpha-\mu(m+3)>b \varepsilon
$$

Therefore, $\tilde{A}_{k}=\left(I+\mathcal{K}_{k}\right)^{-1} \sum I_{j}$ satisfies

$$
\begin{gathered}
|\widetilde{A}|_{s} \leq C_{s, \varepsilon} t^{d \alpha}, \quad|\widetilde{A}|_{m} \leq C_{m, \varepsilon} L_{m} \\
|\widetilde{A}|_{\ell} \leq C_{\ell, \varepsilon}\left(|A|_{\ell}+\left(t^{2 \alpha-\mu(\ell+3)-b \varepsilon}+t^{s+\alpha-\mu(\ell+5 / 2)-b \varepsilon}\right) R_{s_{*}}\right), \quad \forall \ell>0
\end{gathered}
$$

where the last estimate is obtained from (7.43), (7.44), (7.47), (7.48).
Finally, we estimate the norms of $A^{\prime}=\widetilde{A} \circ G$, where $G=F^{-1}$. Let $G_{k}=\mathrm{id}+g_{k}$. Then $g_{k}=-(v)_{k}+\hat{w}_{k}$. By Proposition 4.2, we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left|w_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; r+1 / 2} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}|v|_{r+1 / 2} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}^{\prime}\left(R_{s_{*}} t^{-\mu(r+5 / 2)-b \varepsilon}|A|_{s}+|A|_{r}\right) \\
\left|g_{k}\right|_{D_{k}^{\prime} ; r+1 / 2} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}\left|f_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; r+1 / 2} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}^{\prime}|v|_{r+1 / 2}
\end{gathered}
$$

Recall that we assume $R_{s_{*}} \leq L_{m}$. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|g_{k}\right|_{D_{k}^{1} ; s+1 / 2} \leq C_{s, \varepsilon}\left|f_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; s+1 / 2} \leq C_{s, \varepsilon}^{\prime} R_{s_{*}} t^{\alpha-\mu(s+5 / 2)-b \varepsilon} \\
& \left|g_{k}\right|_{D_{k}^{1} ; m+1 / 2} \leq C_{m, \varepsilon}\left|f_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; m+1 / 2} \leq C_{m, \varepsilon}^{\prime} L_{m}
\end{aligned}
$$

assuming

$$
\alpha-\mu(m+5 / 2)>b \varepsilon+\varepsilon
$$

We also have a coarse estimate

$$
\left|g_{k}\right|_{D_{k}^{1} ; \ell+1 / 2} \leq C_{\ell, \varepsilon}\left|f_{k}\right|_{D_{k} ; \ell+1 / 2} \leq C_{\ell, \varepsilon}^{\prime}\left(|A|_{\ell}+R_{s_{*}} t^{\alpha-\mu(\ell+5 / 2)-b \varepsilon}\right)
$$

Then we obtain

$$
\left|A^{\prime}\right|_{M^{1}, r}=|\widetilde{A} \circ G|_{M, r} \leq C_{r, \varepsilon}\left(|\widetilde{A}|_{r}\left(1+|G|_{M, 1+\varepsilon}^{2}\right)+|\widetilde{A}|_{1+\varepsilon}|G|_{M, r}+|\widetilde{A}|_{\varepsilon}\right)
$$

Using estimates (7.50) for $\widetilde{A}$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|A^{\prime}\right|_{M^{1} ; s} \leq C_{s, \ell} t^{d \alpha}, \quad\left|A^{\prime}\right|_{M^{1} ; m} \leq C_{m, \ell} L_{m} \\
& \left|A^{\prime}\right|_{M^{1} ; \ell} \leq C_{\ell, \varepsilon}\left(|A|_{M ; \ell}+\left(t^{2 \alpha-\mu(\ell+3)-b \varepsilon}+t^{s+\alpha-\mu(\ell+5 / 2)-b \varepsilon}\right) R_{s_{*}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Here we have used the fact that $\mu(\ell+3) \leq \mu(\ell+5 / 2)+\frac{1}{2 s_{*}} \leq \mu(\ell+5 / 2)+\frac{1}{2}$. Our initial conditions need to control $\|\rho \circ G\|_{2}$, which can be achieved through (7.52)-(7.53). We also by $m+1 / 2>s_{*}$ and (7.53)

$$
\left|\rho^{1}\right|_{s_{*}} \leq C_{s_{*}, \varepsilon}\left(|\rho|_{s_{*}}|G|_{1+\varepsilon}^{2}+\|\rho\|_{2}|G|_{s_{*}}\right) \leq C_{s_{*}, \varepsilon}^{\prime} L_{m}
$$

We have obtained

$$
\max \left\{\left|A^{\prime}\right|_{m},\left|\rho^{1}\right|_{s_{*}}\right\} \leq C_{m, \varepsilon} L_{m}
$$

We need

$$
m>s+d \alpha, \quad s_{*} \geq 2, \quad m+\frac{1}{2}>s_{*}>s
$$

Thus, take $s=1+\varepsilon$ and $d=1+\varepsilon$, where $\varepsilon>0$ is sufficiently small. We want to achieve

$$
\begin{gathered}
s+\alpha-\frac{\left(s+5 / 2-s_{*}\right)_{+}}{s_{*}}>d \alpha+2 b \varepsilon+\varepsilon \\
\alpha-\frac{\left(m+5 / 2-s_{*}\right)_{+}}{s_{*}}>\varepsilon+2 b \varepsilon
\end{gathered}
$$

Since $s=1+\varepsilon, \alpha>1$ and $s_{*} \geq 2$, we always have (7.57). Hence, we must have

$$
m-1>\alpha>\frac{m+\frac{5}{2}-s_{*}}{s_{*}}, \quad \alpha>1
$$

Assume that $m>2$ and

$$
m>\frac{m+5 / 2}{s_{*}}, \quad \text { i.e. } \quad m>\frac{5 / 2}{s_{*}-1}
$$

Therefore, for the existence of $\alpha, \varepsilon$ it is equivalent to have

$$
m>\max \left\{s_{*}-\frac{1}{2}, \frac{5 / 2}{s_{*}-1}, 2\right\}, \quad \text { i.e. } \quad m>\max \left\{\frac{5 / 2}{s_{*}-1}, 2\right\}
$$

For instance, when $s_{*}=2$, we need $m>5 / 2$. When $s_{*} \geq 9 / 4$, we just use $s_{*}=9 / 4$ and require $m>2$.

To prove the theorem, we need to combine the Nash-Moser iteration and an application of Hartogs's extension when concavity is present.

We will use the estimates in Section 6 to complete the proof in the next section. To simplify notations, we will not indicate the dependence of various constants on $\varepsilon$ in Section 6 since the $\varepsilon$ has been fixed now.

# 8. The convergence of iteration and Hartogs type extension 

In this section we set up the iteration scheme. We apply an infinite sequence of diffeomorphisms $F^{j}$ as constructed in the previous section. The goal is to show that the maps $F^{j} \circ F^{j-1} \circ \cdots \circ F^{0}$ converge to a limiting diffeomorphism $F$, while the error $A^{j}$ converges to 0 .

For this scheme to work we need to ensure that for each $i=0,1,2, \ldots$, the $F^{i}$ maps $M^{i}$ to a new domain $M^{i+1}=F^{i}\left(M^{i}\right)$ which is an $a_{q}$ domain with $C^{2}$ boundary. Hence, we need to control the $C^{2}$-norms of $F^{j}$ and a defining function $\rho^{j}$ of $M^{j}$.

In what follows we assume that

$$
M^{0}=\left\{z \in \mathcal{M}: \rho^{0}(z)<0\right\} \Subset \mathcal{U}
$$

with $b M^{0}=\left\{z \in \mathcal{M}: \rho^{0}(z)=0\right\}$, where $\rho^{0}$ is a $C^{2}$ function on $\mathcal{M}$ such that $d \rho^{0}(z) \neq 0$ for each $z \in b M^{0}$ and $\rho^{0}-1$ has compact support in $\mathcal{M}$.
Lemma 8.1 ([11, Lem. 7.1]). Let $M^{0}, \rho^{0}$ be as above. For $j=0,1, \ldots$, let $F^{j}=$ $I+f^{j}$ be a $C^{m}$ diffeomorphism which maps $\mathcal{M}$ onto $\mathcal{M}$ and maps $M^{j}$ onto $M^{j+1}$, where $M^{j+1}=F^{j}\left(M^{j}\right)$. Let $\rho^{j+1}=\rho^{j} \circ G^{j}$ with $G^{j}=\left(F^{j}\right)^{-1}$. For any $\varepsilon>0$, there exists $\delta=\delta\left(\rho^{0}, \varepsilon\right)>0$ such that if

$$
\left\|F^{j}-\mathrm{id}\right\|_{\mathcal{M}, 2} \leq \frac{\delta}{(j+1)^{2}}, \quad \forall j \in \mathbb{N}
$$

then $\tilde{F}^{j}=F^{j} \circ \cdots \circ F^{0}, \tilde{G}^{j}=\left(\tilde{F}^{j}\right)^{-1}$ and $\rho^{j+1}$ satisfy

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left\|\tilde{F}^{j+1}-\tilde{F}^{j}\right\|_{\mathcal{M}, 2} \leq C \frac{\delta}{(j+1)^{2}}, \quad \forall j \in \mathbb{N} \\
\left\|\tilde{G}^{j+1}-\tilde{G}^{j}\right\|_{\mathcal{M}, 2} \leq C^{\prime} \frac{\delta}{(j+1)^{2}}, \quad \forall j \in \mathbb{N} \\
\left\|\rho^{j+1}-\rho^{0}\right\|_{\mathcal{M}, 2} \leq \varepsilon
\end{gathered}
$$

We now prove our main theorem.
Theorem 8.2. Let $M: \rho<0$ be a relatively compact domain in $\mathcal{M}$, where $\rho$ is a $C^{2}$ defining function. Assume that $H^{1}(M, \Theta)=0$. Assume that $\delta>0, \varepsilon_{0}>0$ and

$$
\varepsilon_{1}:=r_{0}-\max \left\{\frac{5 / 2}{s_{*}-1}, 2\right\}>0, \quad 2 \leq s_{*} \leq \frac{9}{4}, \quad 2<r_{0}<3
$$

There exist $\tilde{t}_{0}>0$ and $\beta>1$ such that if $A \in \Lambda_{(0,1)}^{r}(M, \Theta)$ defines a formally integrable almost complex structure on $\bar{M}$ and
(8.2) $\left.t_{0}^{-\beta}|A|_{1+\varepsilon_{0}}<1, \quad t_{0}^{\varepsilon_{1}} \max \left\{|A|_{r_{0}},\|\rho\|_{2},\left|\rho\right|_{s_{*}}\right\}<1, \quad\right)$ for some $t_{0} \in\left(0, \tilde{t}_{0}\right]$,
there exists a diffeomorphism $F \in \Lambda^{\ell}(M)$ for all $\ell<r_{0}+1 / 2$ from $M$ onto $M^{\prime} \subset \mathcal{M}$ such that $\|F-\mathrm{id}\|_{C^{2}(\bar{M})}<\delta$, and $F$ transforms the complex structure defined by $A$ into the given complex structure of $\mathcal{M}$, provided
(a) $M$ is strongly pseudoconvex, $s_{*}=2$ and $b M \in C^{2}$; or
(b) $M$ satisfies $a_{1}^{+}$condition and $\rho \in C^{2} \cap \Lambda^{s_{*}}$.

Further, $\hat{t}_{0}=\hat{t}_{0}\left(\rho, \varepsilon_{0}, \varepsilon_{1}, \delta\right), \beta=\beta\left(\rho, \varepsilon_{0}, \varepsilon_{1}, \delta\right)$ are stable under small $C^{2}$ perturbations of $\rho$. Assume further that $r>r_{0}$ and $A \in \Lambda^{r}(M)$. Then the constructed $F$ is in $\Lambda^{\ell}(M)$ for all $\ell<r+1 / 2$.

Remark 8.3. (a) The first two cases cover the case where $b M$ and $A$ are $C^{\infty}$. The result was proved by Hamilton $[18,19]$ who did not specify the value of $r_{0}$.
(b) When $\mathcal{M}$ is $\mathbb{C}^{\alpha}$ and $M$ is strongly pseudoconvex, Shi [52] can low $r_{0}$ to the range $(3 / 2, \infty)$, improving an early result of Gan-Gong [11]. We need $r_{0}>2$ even for the strongly pseudoconvex case since we have to use flows to construct the diffeomorphism $F$.
(c) (8.2) can be restated as

$$
|A|_{1+\varepsilon_{0}} \leq \min \left\{\tilde{t}_{0}^{\beta},\left[\min \left\{|A|_{r_{0}},\|\rho\|_{2}, \quad|\rho|_{s_{*}}\right\}\right]^{-\beta / \varepsilon_{1}}\right\}
$$

Proof of Theorem 8.2. Assume that $H^{1}(M, \Theta)=0$. Let $A \in \Lambda_{(0,1)}^{r}(M, \Theta)$ define a formally integrable almost complex structure on $\bar{M}$, where $2<r \leq \infty$. We need to find a diffeomorphism $F$ from $M$ onto $M^{\prime} \subset \mathcal{M}$, which transforms the complex structure defined by $A$ into the given complex structure of $\mathcal{M}$. To derive the estimates, let us assume that $r<\infty$.
8.1. Convergence for the strongly pseudoconvex case. Fix any finite $r_{0}>2$. Let us recall how $\varepsilon$ is choosen. Set $\alpha=1+\varepsilon, d=1+\varepsilon$ and $s=1+\varepsilon$. When $\varepsilon>0$ is sufficiently small, we have

$$
d \alpha<r_{0}-s-2 \varepsilon, \quad d \alpha<2 \alpha-1-\varepsilon, \quad r_{0}>2+C \varepsilon
$$

After $\varepsilon$ is chosen. We then choose $t_{0}$ such that

$$
0<t_{0}<1, \quad C_{s, r_{0}} t_{0}^{\varepsilon}<1, \quad C_{s} t_{0}^{-1 / 2+\alpha}<1 / 2
$$

We now define $t_{j+1}=t_{j}^{d}$.
We are given a formally integrable almost complex structure $A^{0} \in C^{1}\left(\overline{M^{0}}, \Theta\right)$. Assume that

$$
\left|A^{0}\right|_{M^{0}, s} \leq t_{0}^{\alpha}, \quad\left|A^{0}\right|_{M^{0}, r_{0}} \leq L_{0, r_{0}}
$$

We now apply the homotopy formula

$$
A^{0}=\bar{\partial} H_{0} A^{0}+H_{1} \bar{\partial} A^{0}, \quad \text { on } M_{0}
$$

This gives a vector field $v^{0}=-H_{0} A^{0} \in \Lambda^{s+1 / 2}\left(M^{0}\right)$. We now apply Moser's smoothing operator $S^{t_{0}}$ and define

$$
\tilde{v}^{0}=\chi E_{\mathcal{N}_{t_{0}}\left(M^{0}\right)} S^{t_{0}} v^{0}
$$

where $\chi=1$ on $\mathcal{N}_{t_{0}}\left(M^{0}\right)$ and $\chi$ is compact support on $\mathcal{M}$.
The extension and cut-off allow us to define a time-one map $F^{0}$ on the whole space $\mathcal{M}$ that is the identity map away from the support of $\tilde{v}^{0}$. Since $\tilde{v}^{0}=S^{t_{0}} v^{0}$ on $\mathcal{N}_{t_{0}}\left(M_{0}\right)$, then $\left.F^{0}\right|_{M^{0}}$ agrees with the time-one map of the flow of $S^{t_{0}} v^{0}=$ $-S^{t} P_{0} A^{0}$ on $\mathcal{N}_{t_{0} / C}\left(M^{0}\right)$. Therefore, $F^{0}$ transforms the almost complex structure defined by $A^{0}$ into a almost complex structure defined by $A^{1} \in \Lambda^{r_{0}}\left(M^{1}, \Theta\right)$ where $M^{1}=F^{0}\left(M^{0}\right)$.

We have

$$
\left|\tilde{v}^{0}\right|_{\mathcal{M}, r} \leq C_{r}\left|v^{0}\right|_{M^{0}, r}
$$

Further, $F_{k}^{0}\left(z_{k}\right)=z_{k}+f_{k}^{0}\left(z_{k}\right)$ and $G_{k}^{0}\left(z_{k}\right)=z_{k}+g_{k}^{0}\left(z_{k}\right)$ with $G_{k}^{0}=\left(\left(F^{0}\right)^{-1}\right)_{k}$ satisfy

$$
\begin{aligned}
t_{0}^{\varepsilon} L_{0, r_{0}} & \leq 1 \\
\left|f_{k}^{0}\right|_{D_{k}^{0} ; s+1 / 2}+\left|g_{k}^{0}\right|_{D_{k}^{0+1} ; s+1 / 2} & \leq C_{s} t_{0}^{\alpha} \\
\left|f_{k}^{0}\right|_{D_{k}^{0} ; r_{0}+1 / 2}+\left|g_{k}^{0}\right|_{D_{k}^{i} ; r_{0}+1 / 2} & \leq C_{r_{0}}\left|A^{0}\right|_{r_{0}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Here we may need to adjust $t_{0}$.
This gives us for $j=0$ the following

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|A^{j+1}\right|_{M^{j+1}, s} & \leq t_{j+1}^{\alpha} \\
\left|A^{j+1}\right|_{M^{j+1}, r_{0}} \leq C_{r_{0}}\left|A^{j}\right|_{M_{0}, r_{0}} & \leq C_{r_{0}} L_{j, r_{0}} \\
t_{j+1}^{\alpha} L_{j+1, r_{0}} & \leq 1 \\
\left|f_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j} ; s+1 / 2}+\left|g_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j+1} ; s+1 / 2} & \leq C_{s} t_{j}^{\alpha} \\
\left|f_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j} ; r_{0}+1 / 2}+\left|g_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j+1} ; r_{0}+1 / 2} & \leq C_{r_{0}} L_{j, r_{0}}
\end{aligned}
$$

The iteration can be repeated when $j$ is replaced by $j+1$, if we have

$$
\left|f_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j}, 2}+\left|g_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j+1}, 2} \leq \frac{C_{2}}{(j+1)^{2}}
$$

By Lemma 8.1, the latter implies that the stability of constants in various estimates holds for $M^{j+1}: \rho^{j+1}=\rho^{j} \circ G^{j}$ with $G^{j}=\left(F^{j}\right)^{-1}$. Then (8.9) implies that we can repeat the procedure to construct the sequence of $\left\{M^{j}, F^{j}, \rho^{j+1}\right\}_{j=0}^{\infty}$.

By (8.12), we have $\left|f_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j} ; s+1 / 2}+\left|g_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j+1} ; s+1 / 2} \leq C_{s} t_{j}^{\alpha} \leq C_{s} t_{0}^{d^{j}}$. This shows that $\hat{F}^{j}=F^{j} \circ \cdots \circ F^{0}$ converges to $\hat{F}$ and $\hat{G}^{j}=G^{0} \circ \cdots G^{j}$ converges in $\Lambda^{s}$ norm. By (8.13), we have $\left|f_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j} ; r_{0}+1 / 2}+\left|g_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j+1} ; r_{0}+1 / 2} \leq C_{r_{0}} L_{j, r_{0}} \leq C_{t_{0}}^{j} L_{0, r_{0}}$. Using interpolation, we know that $\left|f_{k}^{j}\right|_{r_{\theta}}$ converges rapidly in $\Lambda^{r_{\theta}}$ norm for $r_{\theta}=$ $(1-\theta) s+\theta r_{0}+1 / 2$ for any $0<\theta<1$.

We now apply a standard bootstrapping argument. For the above fixed parameters, we want to show that $F$ is actually in $\Lambda^{\ell}$ for any $\ell<m+1 / 2$, provided

$$
r_{0}<m<\infty, \quad A^{0} \in \Lambda^{m}\left(M_{0}\right)
$$

In this case, define $L_{j, m}=\left|A^{0}\right|_{M^{j}, m}$ Then (8.10), (8.13) still hold for $j \geq 0$, if we replace $r_{0}$ by $m$. Thus,

$$
\left|A^{j+1}\right|_{M^{j+1}, m} \leq C_{m} L_{j, m}, \quad\left|f_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j} ; m+1 / 2} \leq C_{m} L_{j, m}
$$

Consequently, $L_{j+1, m} \leq C_{m} L_{j, m} \leq C_{m}^{j+1} L_{0, m}$ and $\left|f_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j} ; m+1 / 2} \leq C_{m}^{j} L_{0, m}$. We know that $\left|f_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j} ; s+1 / 2}$ converges rapidly. By interpolation, we conclude that $\left|f_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j}, \ell}$ converges rapidly for any $\ell<m+1 / 2$.
8.2. Convergence in finite many derivatives for the general case. Let us recall the choice of parameters in subsection 6.4. Assume that

$$
r_{0}>s+1, \quad s_{*} \geq 2, \quad r_{0}>\frac{5 / 2}{s_{*}-1}
$$

Take $s=1+\varepsilon$ and $d=1+\varepsilon$, where $\varepsilon>0$ is sufficiently small. Thus, we assume

$$
r_{0}>\max \left\{2, \frac{5 / 2}{s_{*}-1}\right\}, \quad s_{*} \geq 2
$$

We now define $t_{j+1}=t_{j}^{d}$ and choose $t_{0}$ such that

$$
0<t_{0}<1, \quad C_{s, r_{0}} t_{0}^{\varepsilon}<1, \quad C_{s} t_{0}^{-1 / 2+\alpha}<1 / 2
$$

We are given a formally integrable almost complex structure $A^{0} \in \mathcal{C}^{1}\left(\overline{M^{0}}, \Theta\right)$. Assume that

$$
\left|A^{0}\right|_{M^{0}, s} \leq t_{0}^{\alpha}, \quad\left|A^{0}\right|_{M^{0}, r_{0}} \leq L_{0, r_{0}}
$$

We now apply the homotopy formula

$$
A^{0}=\bar{\partial} P_{0} A^{0}+Q_{0} \bar{\partial} A^{0}, \quad \text { on } M_{0}^{t_{0}}
$$

Here $M_{0}^{t_{0}}=\left(M^{0}\right)^{t_{0}}, P_{0}=P_{M_{0}^{t_{0}}}$ and $Q_{0}=Q_{M_{0}^{t_{0}}}$. This yields a vector field $v_{0}=-P_{0} A_{0} \in \Lambda^{s+1 / 2}\left(M^{0}\right)$. We now apply Moser's smoothing operator $S^{t_{0}}$ and define

$$
\bar{v}^{0}=\chi E_{\mathcal{N}_{t_{0}}\left(M^{0}\right)} S^{t_{0}} v^{0}
$$

where $\chi=1$ on $\mathcal{N}_{t_{0}}\left(M^{0}\right)$ and $\chi$ is compact support on $\mathcal{M}$.
The extension and cut-off allow us define a time-one map $F^{0}$ on the whole space $\mathcal{M}$ that is the identity map away from the support of $\bar{v}^{0}$. Since $\bar{v}^{0}=S^{t_{0}} v^{0}$ on $\mathcal{N}_{t_{0}}\left(M^{0}\right)$, then $F^{0}\left\lvert\,_{M^{0}}\right.$ agrees with the time-one map of the flow of $S^{t_{0}} v^{0}=$ $-S^{t_{0}} P_{0} A^{0}$ on $\mathcal{N}_{t_{0} / C}\left(M^{0}\right)$. Therefore, $F^{0}$ transforms the almost complex structure defined by $A^{0}$ into a almost complex structure defined by $A^{1} \in \Lambda^{m}\left(M^{1}, \Theta\right)$ where $M^{1}=F^{0}\left(M^{0}\right)$.

We have

$$
\left|\bar{v}^{0}\right|_{\mathcal{M}, r} \leq C_{r}\left|v^{0}\right|_{M^{0}, r}
$$

Further, $F_{k}^{0}\left(z_{k}\right)=z_{k}+f_{k}^{0}\left(z_{k}\right)$ and $G_{k}^{0}\left(z_{k}\right)=z_{k}+g_{k}^{j}\left(z_{k}\right)$ with $G_{k}^{0}=\left(\left(F^{0}\right)^{-1}\right)_{k}$ satisfy

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|f_{k}^{0}\right|_{D_{k}^{0} ; s+1 / 2}+\left|g_{k}^{0}\right|_{D_{k}^{1} ; s+1 / 2} & \leq C_{s} t_{0}^{\alpha} \\
\left|f_{k}^{0}\right|_{D_{k}^{0} ; r_{0}+1 / 2}+\left|g_{k}^{0}\right|_{D_{k}^{1} ; r_{0}+1 / 2} & \leq C_{r_{0}}\left|A^{0}\right|_{r_{0}}
\end{aligned}
$$

This give us for $j=0$ the following

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|A^{j+1}\right|_{M^{j+1}, s} & \leq t_{j+1}^{\alpha} \\
\left|A^{j+1}\right|_{M^{j+1}, r_{0}} \leq C_{r_{0}}\left|A_{j}\right|_{M^{j}, r_{0}} & \leq L_{j+1, r_{0}} \\
\left|f_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{1} ; s+1 / 2}+\left|g_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j+1} ; s+1 / 2} & \leq C_{s} t_{j}^{\alpha} \\
\left|f_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j} ; r_{0}+1 / 2}+\left|g_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j+1} ; r_{0}+1 / 2} & \leq C_{m} L_{j, r_{0}}
\end{aligned}
$$

The iteration can be repeated when $j$ is replaced by $j+1$, if we have

$$
\left|f_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j} ; 2}+\left|g_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j+1} ; 2} \leq \frac{C_{2}}{(j+1)^{2}}
$$

By Lemma 8.1, the latter implies that the stability of constants in various estimate holds for $M^{j+1}: \rho^{j+1}=\rho^{j} \circ G^{j}$. Then (8.17) implies that we can repeat the procedure to construct the sequence of $\left\{M^{j}, F^{j}, \rho^{j+1}\right\}_{j=0}^{\infty}$.

By (8.19), we have $\left|f_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j} ; s+1 / 2}+\left|g_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j+1} ; s+1 / 2} \leq C_{s} t_{j}^{\alpha} \leq C_{s} t_{0}^{j^{j}}$. This shows that $\tilde{F}_{j}=F^{j} \circ \cdots \circ F^{0}$ converges to $\tilde{F}$ and $\tilde{G}^{j}=G^{0} \circ \cdots G^{j}$ converges in $\Lambda^{s}$ norm. By (8.20), we have $\left|f_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j} ; r_{0}+1 / 2}+\left|g_{k}^{j}\right|_{D_{k}^{j+1} ; r_{0}+1 / 2} \leq C_{r_{0}} L_{j, r_{0}} \leq C_{r_{0}}^{j} L_{r_{0}, 0}$. Using interpolation, we know that $\left|f_{k}^{j}\right|_{r_{\theta}}$ converges rapidly in $\Lambda^{r_{\theta}}$ norm for $r_{\theta}=$ $(1-\theta) s+\theta r_{0}+1 / 2$ for any $0<\theta<1$.

Suppose now that $b M^{0} \in C^{\ell+1 / 2}$ and $A^{0} \in \Lambda^{\ell}$ with $\ell \in\left(r_{0}, \infty\right) \backslash \frac{1}{2} \mathbb{N}$. We want to show that without further adjusting the parameters $\alpha, d, m, s$ the above sequence $f_{j}, g_{j}$ converge rapidly in $\Lambda^{\ell^{\prime}}$ for any $\ell^{\prime}<\ell+1 / 2$.

We still keep $s_{*}$ and $\bar{t}=\left(c_{*} t\right)^{1 / s_{*}}$ in (7.33) unchanged. However, we replace the $s_{*}$ in $|\rho|_{s_{*}}$ by any $\ell+1 / 2$ for the third inequality below and replace $\mu(a)$ by

$$
\mu_{\ell}(a):=\frac{(a-\ell-1 / 2)_{+}}{s_{*}}
$$

Then we obtain

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left\|\rho_{\bar{t}}-\rho\right\|_{0} \leq C_{s} \bar{t}^{s_{*}}\|\rho\|_{s_{*}} \\
\left\|\rho_{\bar{t}}-\rho\right\|_{2} \leq \varepsilon, \quad \bar{t}<\bar{t}^{*}\left(\nabla^{2} \rho\right) \\
\left\|\rho_{\bar{t}}\right\|_{b} \leq C_{b, \ell} t^{-\mu_{\ell}(b-\ell-1 / 2)}\|\rho\|_{\ell+1 / 2}, \quad b>0
\end{gathered}
$$

Recall $R_{s_{*}}=|\rho|_{s_{*}}$ by definition. Then

$$
\mu_{\ell}(a) \leq \mu_{\ell}(\ell+3)=\frac{5}{2 s_{*}}=\mu\left(s_{*}+\frac{5}{2}\right), \quad \forall a \leq \ell+3
$$

By (7.51) in which we take $s_{*}=\ell$ and $\mu=\mu_{\ell}$, we obtain

$$
|\tilde{A}|_{\ell} \leq C_{\ell}\left(|A|_{\ell}+\left(t^{2 \alpha-\mu_{\ell}(\ell+3)-b \varepsilon}+t^{\alpha+s-\mu_{\ell}(\ell+5 / 2)}\right)|\rho|_{\ell+1 / 2}\right)
$$

By (7.49) and (7.58), we have

$$
\alpha-\mu_{\ell}(\ell+3)=\alpha-\mu\left(s_{*}+5 / 2\right)>0, \quad \alpha+s-\mu_{\ell}(\ell+3)>0
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
& |\tilde{A}|_{\ell} \leq C_{\ell}^{\prime} \max \left(|\rho|_{\ell+1 / 2},|A|_{\ell}\right) \\
& \left|g_{k}\right|_{\ell+1 / 2} \leq C_{\ell}\left|f_{k}\right|_{\ell+1 / 2} \leq C_{\ell}^{\prime}\left(t^{\alpha-\mu_{\ell}(\ell+3)}|\rho|_{\ell+1 / 2}+|A|_{\ell}\right) \leq C_{\ell}^{\prime \prime} \max \left(|\rho|_{\ell+1 / 2},|A|_{\ell}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

By (7.55), we have

$$
\left|A^{\prime}\right|_{\ell} \leq C_{\ell}\left(|\tilde{A}|_{\ell}+|g|_{\ell}+L_{0}\right) \leq C_{\ell}^{\prime} \max \left(|\rho|_{\ell+1 / 2},|A|_{\ell}\right)
$$

We also have

$$
|\rho \circ G|_{\ell+1 / 2} \leq C_{\ell}\left(|\rho|_{\ell+1 / 2}\left(1+|G|_{1+\varepsilon}\right)+C_{\ell}|\rho|_{1+\varepsilon}|G|_{\ell+1 / 2}\right) \leq C_{\ell}^{\prime} \max \left(|\rho|_{\ell+1 / 2},|A|_{\ell}\right)
$$

Therefore, we have

$$
\max \left\{\left|A^{j+1}\right|_{\ell},\left|\rho^{j+1}\right|_{\ell+1 / 2}\right)\right\} \leq C_{\ell}^{\prime} \max \left(\left|A^{0}\right|_{\ell},\left|\rho^{0}\right|_{\ell+1 / 2}\right)
$$

By interpolation, we see that $\left|f_{j}\right|_{\ell^{\prime}}$ and $\left|g_{j}\right|_{\ell^{\prime}}$ converge rapidly for any $\ell^{\prime}<\ell+1 / 2$. Therefore, under conditions (8.14) and

$$
A \in \Lambda^{\ell}, \quad b M \in \Lambda^{\ell+1 / 2}, \quad \ell>r_{0}>2
$$

we have an embedding $F_{\infty} \in \Lambda^{\ell^{\prime}}$ for any $\ell^{\prime}<\ell+1 / 2$.
We remark that conditions (8.4), (8.5), (8.6) can be written as (8.2) when we replace $t_{0}$ by $\bar{t}_{0}^{\mu}$ for some constant $\mu>1$ that depends on $\varepsilon, \varepsilon_{1}$.

In summary, we have proved the following.
Proposition 8.4. Theorem 8.2 holds if we assume additionally

$$
\rho \in \Lambda^{r+1 / 2}
$$

for its last assertion.

In next two subsections, we will remove the extra condition (8.24). Then the proof of Theorem 8.2 is complete.
8.3. Improving regularity away from concave boundary. It is well-known that by the classical Newlander-Nirenberg theorem that $F_{0}$ gains one derivative on $M$. To improve the regularity of $F_{0}$ in a neighborhood of the strongly pseudoconvex boundary $b_{n-1}^{+} M$, we only need to slightly modify the arguments in the previous subsection.

Fix a neighborhood $\omega^{+}$of $b_{n-1}^{+} M$ in $\bar{M}$ and a neighborhood $\omega^{-}$of $b_{2}^{-} M$ in $\bar{M}$ so that $\overline{\omega^{+}} \cap \overline{\omega^{-}}=\emptyset$. Recall that using Grauert bumping, we have

$$
\varphi_{j}=\varphi_{j-1}-\bar{\partial}\left(\chi_{j} H_{U_{j}, q} \varphi_{j-1}\right)-\chi_{j} H_{U_{j}, q+1} \bar{\partial} \varphi_{j-1}, \quad j=1, \ldots, N
$$

We can choose $\omega_{j}, \omega_{j}^{\prime}$ so that $\omega_{j}^{\prime} \subset \omega^{+}$(resp. $\omega_{j}^{\prime} \subset \omega^{-}$) if $\omega_{j} \cap b_{n-1}^{+} M \neq \emptyset$ (resp. $\omega_{j} \cap b_{2}^{-} M \neq \emptyset$ ). Consequently,

$$
\left|\varphi_{N}\right|_{\omega^{+}, a} \leq C_{a}|\varphi|_{M, a}, \quad\left|\bar{\partial} \varphi_{N}\right|_{\omega^{+}, a} \leq C_{a}|\bar{\partial} \varphi|_{M, a}
$$

for any $a>0$ even if $b M$ is merely $C^{2}$.
We still use (6.17)-(6.18). Hence, we still have all estimates the previous subsection. Next, we improve and in fact simplify the estimates away from $b_{2}^{-} M$, using (6.19) on subdomains of $\omega^{+}$containing $b_{n-1}^{+} M$.

Recall that $M$ is defined by $\rho<0$. Set

$$
M_{j, \varepsilon}=M^{j} \backslash\left\{\rho^{j} \geq-\varepsilon+\frac{\varepsilon}{\sqrt{j+2}}\right\}, \quad M_{j, \varepsilon}^{ \pm}=M^{j} \backslash\left\{\rho_{j} \geq-\varepsilon+\frac{\varepsilon}{\sqrt{j+1 \mp 1 / 2}}\right\}
$$

where $\varepsilon$ is a small positive number. We have

$$
M_{j+1, \varepsilon}^{+} \subset M_{j, \varepsilon}^{-} \subset M_{j, \varepsilon} \subset M_{j, \varepsilon}^{+} \quad F^{j}\left(M_{j, \varepsilon}^{-}\right) \supset M_{j+1, \varepsilon}^{+} \quad j>\ell_{\varepsilon}
$$

Consequently, $G^{\ell_{\varepsilon}} \cdots G^{\ell}: M_{\ell_{\varepsilon}+1, \varepsilon}^{+} \rightarrow M_{\ell, \varepsilon}^{+}$is well-defined.
We now have

$$
\left|v^{j}\right|_{M_{j, \varepsilon}, r+1 / 2} \leq \frac{C_{r}}{(j+1)^{2}}\left(\left|A^{j}\right|_{M_{j, \varepsilon}^{+}, r}+\left|A^{j}\right|_{M^{j}, 0}\right)
$$

This allows us to carry over the estimates for strongly pseudoconvex domains. Further, we only need to improve estimates for the highest order derivatives. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|f^{j}\right|_{M_{j, \varepsilon}^{-}, m+1 / 2} \leq \frac{C_{m}(j+1)^{m+C}}{\varepsilon^{m+C}}\left(\left|A^{j}\right|_{M_{j, \varepsilon}^{+}, m}+\left\|A^{j}\right\|_{M^{j}, 0}\right) \\
& \left|g^{j}\right|_{M_{j+1, \varepsilon}^{+}, m+1 / 2} \leq \frac{C_{m}(j+1)^{m+C}}{\varepsilon^{m+C}}\left(\left|A^{j}\right|_{M_{j, \varepsilon}^{+}, m}+\left\|A^{j}\right\|_{M^{j}, 0}\right) \\
& \left|A^{j+1}\right|_{M_{j+1, \varepsilon}^{+}, m} \leq \frac{C_{m}(j+1)^{m+C}}{\varepsilon^{m+C}}\left(\left|A^{j}\right|_{M_{j, \varepsilon}^{+}, m}+\left\|A^{j}\right\|_{M^{j}, 0}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

By (8.27) and the rapid convergence of $\left|A_{j+1}\right|_{s}$ via (8.17), we obtain

$$
\left|A^{j+1}\right|_{M_{+}^{j+1, \varepsilon}, m}+\left\|A^{j+1}\right\|_{M^{j}, 0} \leq C_{m} \varepsilon^{-m-C}(j+1)\left)^{j}\left(\left|A^{0}\right|_{M_{i, \varepsilon}^{+}, m}+\left\|A^{0}\right\|_{M^{0}, 0}\right)
$$

By (8.26), (7.52), and interpolation, we see that $\left|g^{j}\right|_{M_{+}^{j+1}, a}$ converges rapidly for any $a<m+1 / 2$. This shows that $\lim _{\ell \rightarrow \infty} G^{\ell_{\varepsilon}} \cdots G^{\ell}$ is in $\Lambda^{a}\left(M_{\ell_{\varepsilon}+1, \varepsilon}^{+}\right)$. Therefore, $F_{\infty}$ is in $\Lambda^{a}$ on a neighborhood of $b_{n-1}^{+}(M)$ in $\bar{M}$ for any $a<r+1 / 2$.

8.4. Improving regularity near concave boundary via Hartogs extension. Let us summarize the results we have proved so far when $r_{0}, s_{*}$ satisfy (8.1)-(8.2). Suppose

$$
t_{0}^{n}\|A\|_{M, s} \leq 1, \quad t_{0}^{-\varepsilon}\|A\|_{M, r_{0}} \leq 1
$$

(a) On $M$, we have founded a global coordinate map $F: \bar{M} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}$ for $A$ (i.e. that $F$ transforms the almost complex structure defined by $A$ into the standard complex structure on $F(M)$ ). We also have $F \in C^{2}(\bar{M}) \cap$ $\Lambda^{\ell}\left(\mathcal{N}_{\ell}\left(b_{1}^{+} M\right)\right)$ for any $\ell<r_{0}+1 / 2$. Further, $F(M)$ is still an $a_{1}^{+}$domain.
(b) Suppose $m>r_{0}$. Suppose $\bar{M}$ with $b \bar{M} \in \Lambda^{m+1 / 2}$ is a small $C^{2}$ perturbation of $b M$ and $\tilde{A} \in \Lambda^{m}(\bar{M})$ defines a formal integrable almost complex structure with $|\tilde{A}|_{r_{0}}$ being sufficiently small. There is a global coordinate map $\tilde{F} \in$ $\Lambda^{\ell}(\bar{M})$ for $\tilde{A}$, for any $\ell<r+1 / 2$. Furthermore, $\|\tilde{F}-\mathrm{id}\|_{2}<\delta$ and $\tilde{F}(M)$ is still an $a_{1}^{+}$domain.
We want to show that without requiring $b_{1}^{+} M$ to be more smooth, the $F$ in $(a)$ is actually in $\Lambda^{\ell}(M)$ for any $\ell<m+1 / 2$, assuming $A \in \Lambda^{m}$. Here we apply Hartogs's extension. This technic has been used recently in [14] for solving the $\bar{\partial}$ problem.

Suppose $\zeta \in b M$. By Lemma 6.2, we can find a smoothly bounded subdomain $M_{\zeta}^{*}$ of $M$ that is a small perturbation of $M$ in class $C^{2} \cap \Lambda^{s_{*}}$ such that $\zeta \in b M_{\zeta}^{*}$. Since $M_{\zeta}^{*}$ is a subdomain of $M,(8.28)$ implies that

$$
\left.t_{0}^{\alpha}\left|A\right|_{M_{\zeta}^{*}}\right|_{M_{\zeta}^{*}, s} \leq 1, \quad t_{0}^{-\varepsilon}\left|A\right|_{M_{\zeta}^{*}}\right|_{M_{\zeta}^{*}, r_{0}} \leq 1
$$

Therefore, we can apply (b) and find a coordinate map $F_{\zeta}$ for $\left.A\right|_{M_{\zeta}^{*}}$ that is smooth on $\overline{M_{\zeta}^{*}}$ such that $\left|F_{\zeta}-\right.$ id $\left.\right|_{M_{\zeta}^{*}}<\varepsilon$. It is clear that

$$
M=\bigcup_{\zeta \in b_{1}^{-} M} M_{\zeta}^{*}
$$

To apply Hartogs's extension theorem, we take a local homomorphic coordinate map $\phi$ from a small neighborhood $U_{\zeta}$ of $\zeta$ onto $P_{\delta, \varepsilon}=\Delta_{\delta}^{n-1} \times([-\delta, \delta]+i[-\varepsilon, \varepsilon])$. We may assume that $\phi(\zeta)=0$. Further, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
D & :=\phi\left(U_{\zeta} \cap M\right)=\left\{z \in P_{\delta, \varepsilon}: y_{n}>-\left|z_{1}\right|^{2}+\sum \lambda_{j}\left|z_{j}\right|^{2}+R\left(x, y^{\prime}\right)\right\} \\
D_{\zeta} & :=\phi\left(U_{\zeta} \cap M_{\zeta}^{*}\right)=\left\{z \in P_{\delta, \varepsilon}: y_{n}>-\left|z_{1}\right|^{2}+\sum \lambda_{j}\left|z_{j}\right|^{2}+R_{\zeta}^{*}\left(x, y^{\prime}\right)\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\left|\lambda_{j}\right|<1 / 4,\left|R_{\zeta}^{*}\left(x, y^{\prime}\right)\right|+\left|R\left(x, y^{\prime}\right)\right| \leq\left|\left(x, y^{\prime}\right)\right|^{2} / 4$. Both domains contain the Hartogs domain

$$
\Gamma:=\left\{z \in P_{\delta, \varepsilon}: y_{n}>-\frac{1}{2}\left|z_{1}\right|^{2}+\sum \frac{1}{2}\left|z_{j}\right|^{2}\right\}
$$

Since $M_{\zeta}^{*}$ is contained in $M^{0}$, then the composition

$$
H:=\phi F_{\zeta} F^{-1} \phi^{-1}
$$

is a holomorphic map from $D$ into $\mathbb{C}^{n}$. In particular, $H=\left(H_{1}, \ldots, H_{n}\right)$ is holomorphic on $\Gamma$. By the Cauchy formula, we obtain

$$
H_{j}(z)=\frac{1}{(2 \pi i)^{n}} \int_{\left|\eta_{1}\right|=\varepsilon} \int_{\left|\eta_{2}\right|=\delta} \cdots \int_{\left|\eta_{n}\right|=\delta} \frac{H_{j}(\eta) d \eta_{1} \cdots d \eta_{n}}{\left(\eta_{1}-z_{1}\right) \cdots\left(\eta_{n}-z_{n}\right)}
$$

on $\omega:=\left(\Delta_{\delta / C}^{n-1} \times \Delta_{\delta}\right) \cap D \cap\left\{y_{n}>\delta / 2\right\}$. By uniqueness theorem, (8.29) is valid on $\omega$. This shows that

$$
|H|_{\omega, \ell} \leq C_{\delta, \epsilon, \ell}\|H\|_{\Gamma \cap D, 0}
$$

Consequently, $H^{-1}$ is in $\Lambda^{\ell}$ on $H(\omega)$. Then $F=\phi^{-1} H^{-1} \phi F_{\zeta}$ satisfies

$$
|F|_{M_{\zeta}^{*} \cap \tilde{\Delta}_{\delta, \epsilon}(\zeta), \ell} \leq C_{\ell}|F_{\zeta}|_{M_{\zeta}, \ell} \leq C_{\ell}^{\prime}|A|_{M_{\zeta}^{*}, \ell} \leq C_{\ell}^{\prime}|A|_{M^{0}, \ell}
$$

The latter is independent of $\zeta$. This shows that $|F|_{M, \ell}<\infty$ for any $\ell<m+\frac{1}{2}$.
Remark 8.5. In our main results on the global Newlander-Nirenberg problem, we only use estimate in Theorem 1.2 for $\delta=1 / 2$ when $b M$ has the concave component. It is likely that arguments in Sections 7 and 8 can lead to new results, if we apply Theorem 1.2 for $0 \leq \delta<1 / 2$.

# Appendix A. Stability of constants in equivalence norms 

The main purpose in this appendix is to describe the stability of various constants in Rychkov [49] and Dispa [6]. In this appendix, we use notation in [6,49].
A.1. Case of special Lipschitz domains. We will only focus on the case that $\Omega$ is a special Lipschitz domain in $\mathbb{R}^{n}$ given by

$$
x_{n}>\omega\left(x^{\prime}\right), \quad x^{\prime} \in \mathbb{R}^{n-1}
$$

with $\left|\omega\left(\tilde{x}^{\prime}\right)-\omega\left(x^{\prime}\right)\right| \leq A\left|\tilde{x}^{\prime}-x^{\prime}\right|$. Then the cone $K$ defined by $x_{n}>A\left|x^{\prime}\right|$ satisfies $\Omega+K \subset \Omega$. We call $A$ a Lipschitz constant of $\Omega$.

Assume that $s \in \mathbb{R}$. We describe some properties on $\mathcal{C}^{s}(\Omega)$, which is the Besov space $B_{\infty, \infty}^{s}(\Omega)$ as defined in $[6,49]$ when $\Omega$ is a special Lipschitz domain and more general a bounded Lipschitz domain.

Let $\varphi_{0}$ be a smooth function on $\mathbb{R}^{n}$ with compact support in $-K$ and $\int \varphi_{0} d x=1$. Define

$$
\varphi(x)=\varphi_{0}(x)-2^{-n} \varphi_{0}(x / 2), \quad \varphi_{j}(x)=2^{j n} \varphi\left(2^{j} x\right), \quad j \geq 1
$$

We say that $\varphi$ satisfies the moment condition of order $L_{\varphi}$, namely

$$
\int x^{\alpha} \varphi(x) d x=0, \quad|\alpha| \leq L_{\varphi}
$$

Analogously, suppose $\lambda_{0} \in \mathcal{D}(-K)$ also satisfies the moment condition of order $L_{\lambda}$.
We have $\varphi_{0}+\cdots+\varphi_{j}=2^{j n} \varphi_{0}\left(2^{j} x\right)$. For $f \in \mathcal{D}^{\prime}(\Omega)$, we have

$$
f=\sum_{j=0}^{\infty} \varphi_{j} * f
$$

For $f \in \mathcal{D}^{\prime}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$, define

$$
\|f\|_{\mathcal{C}^{s}}:=\sup _{j} \sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{n}} 2^{s j}\left|\varphi_{j} * f(x)\right|
$$

Note that $\|f\|_{\mathcal{C}^{s}}=\sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{n}, j} 2^{s j}\left|\varphi_{j} * f(x)\right|$. Define for $f \in \mathcal{D}^{\prime}(\Omega)$

$$
\|f\|_{\mathcal{C}^{s}(\Omega)}=\inf \left\{\|\tilde{f}\|_{\mathcal{C}^{s}}: \tilde{f} \in D^{\prime}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right), \tilde{f} \mid \Omega=f \text { in } \mathcal{D}^{\prime}(\Omega)\right\}
$$

Let $\mathcal{C}^{s}(\Omega)$ be the set of all such $f \in \mathcal{D}^{\prime}(\Omega)$ with $\|f\|_{\mathcal{C}^{s}(\Omega)}<\infty$, i.e. $\tilde{f} \mid \Omega=f$ for some $\tilde{f} \in \mathcal{C}^{s}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$. When $s>0, \Lambda^{s}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)=\mathcal{C}^{s}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ in equivalent norms (see [6] and references therein.)

The Peetre-type maximum functions of $f \in \mathcal{D}^{\prime}(\Omega)$ are

$$
\varphi_{j, N}^{\Omega} f(x)=\sup _{y \in \Omega} \frac{\left|\varphi_{j} * f(y)\right|}{\left(1+2^{j}|x-y|\right)^{N}}, \quad x \in \Omega
$$

Remark A.1. It holds trivially that for $f \in \mathcal{D}^{\prime}(\Omega)$

$$
\left\|\varphi_{j, N}^{\Omega} f\right\|_{L^{\infty}(\Omega)}=\left\|\varphi_{j} * f\right\|_{L^{\infty}(\Omega)}, \quad N \geq 0
$$

Lemma A.2. Suppose that $\min \left\{L_{\varphi}, L_{\lambda}\right\} \geq M$ and $M$ is finite. Then

$$
\left\|\lambda_{\ell} * \varphi_{j}\right\|_{L^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)} \leq C_{\varphi_{0}, \lambda_{0}, K, M} 2^{-|j-\ell|(M+1)}
$$

for any $j, \ell \geq 0$,
Proof. This is a consequence of estimate $[49,(2.13)]$

$$
\int\left|\lambda_{\ell} * \varphi_{j}\right|(z)\left(1+2^{j}|z|\right)^{N} d z \leq \begin{cases}C 2^{-|\ell-j|\left(L_{\varphi}+1-N\right)} & j \geq \ell \\ C 2^{-|\ell-j|\left(L_{\lambda}+1\right)}, & j<\ell\end{cases}
$$

for $\ell, j \geq 0$ and $N \geq 0$, where $C$ depends on $\lambda_{0}, \varphi_{0}$ and is independent of $\ell, j$. See [54, Lemma 4.3] for further details.

Proposition A. 3 ([49, Prop. 2.1]). Fix $L \geq 0$ and fix $\varphi_{0} \in \mathcal{D}^{\prime}(-K)$ with $\int \varphi_{0}=$ 1. There exists $\psi_{0}, \psi \in \mathcal{D}^{\prime}(-K)$ such that $\psi$ has vanishing moments up to order $L_{\psi} \geq L$ and

$$
f=\sum_{j=0}^{\infty} \psi_{j} * \varphi_{j} * f, \quad \forall f \in \mathcal{D}^{\prime}(\Omega)
$$

Here $\psi_{j+1}(x)=2^{j n} \psi\left(2^{j} x\right)$ for $j \geq 0$.
Remark A.4. (a) Unlike $\varphi, \varphi_{0}$ the relation $\psi(x)=\psi_{0}(x)-2^{-n} \psi_{0}(x / 2)$ may not hold. In [54], $\left\{\varphi_{j}\right\}_{j=0}^{\infty}$ is called a regular dyadic resolution, while $\left\{\psi_{j}\right\}_{j=0}^{\infty}$ is called a generalized dyadic resolution.
(b) The proof of [49, Prop. 2.1] does not use Proposition A. 5 below. This allows us to simplify the proof of [49, Prop. 1.2]

Proposition A. 5 ([49, Prop. 1.2]). Let $\lambda_{0}, \varphi_{0} \in \mathcal{D}(-K)$ with $\min \left\{L_{\lambda}, L_{\varphi}\right\} \geq|s|$. Then for any $f \in \mathcal{D}^{\prime}(\Omega)$

$$
\sup _{j} 2^{s j}\left\|\lambda_{j} * f\right\|_{L^{\infty}}=\sup _{j} 2^{s j}\left\|\lambda_{j, N}^{\mathbb{R}^{n}} f\right\|_{L^{\infty}} \leq C_{s} \sup _{j} 2^{s j}\left\|\varphi_{j} * f\right\|_{L^{\infty}}, \quad N>0
$$

The constants are for $\mathbb{R}^{n}$ and depend only on the Lipschitz norm of $\Omega$.
Proof. Write $\min \left\{L_{\varphi}, L_{\lambda}\right\} \geq M \geq|s|$ with $M<\infty$. Applying Proposition A. 3 to $\Omega=\mathbb{R}^{n}$, we find $\eta_{0}, \eta$ such that $L_{\eta} \geq M$ and

$$
f=\sum_{j=0}^{\infty} \eta_{k} * \varphi_{k} * f
$$

By moment conditions on $\eta$ and $\psi$, Young's inequality $\|u * v\|_{L^{\infty}} \leq\|u\|_{L^{1}}\|v\|_{L^{\infty}}$, and Lemma A.2, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\lambda_{j} * f\right\|_{L^{\infty}} & \leq \sum_{k}\left\|\lambda_{j} * \eta_{k} * \varphi_{k} * f\right\|_{L^{\infty}} \leq \sum_{k}\left\|\lambda_{j} * \eta_{k}\right\|_{L^{1}}\left\|\varphi_{k} * f\right\|_{L^{\infty}} \\
& \leq C_{M} \sum_{k} 2^{-|j-k|(M+1)}\left\|\varphi_{k} * f\right\|_{L^{\infty}} \\
& \leq C_{M} 2^{-j s}\left(\sup _{k} 2^{s k}\left\|\varphi_{k} * f\right\|_{L^{\infty}}\right) \sum_{k} 2^{-|j-k|(M+1-|s|)}
\end{aligned}
$$

The last sum is bounded by 3 since $M \geq|s|$.
Proposition A. 3 allows Rychkov [49] to define an extension operator $\mathcal{E}$ for $\Omega$.
Theorem A. 6 ([49, Thms. 2.2, 2.3, 3.2]). Let $\varphi, \psi_{0}, \psi$ be as in Proposition A.3. Let $g_{\Omega}$ be the trivial extension by 0 on $\mathbb{R}^{n} \backslash \Omega$. Suppose $\min \left\{L_{\lambda}, L_{\varphi}\right\} \geq|s|$.
(a) Suppose $f \in \mathscr{S}^{\prime}(\Omega)$, i.e. $|\langle f, \gamma\rangle| \leq C \sup \left|D^{\alpha} \gamma(x)\right|(1+|x|)^{M}$ for some $M=M_{f}$ and $C=C_{f}$. Then

$$
\|f\|_{\mathcal{C}^{s}(\Omega)} \approx \sup 2^{j s}\left\|\varphi_{j} * f\right\|_{L^{\infty}(\Omega)}
$$

(b) Let $\mathcal{E}: \mathscr{S}^{\prime}(\Omega) \rightarrow D^{\prime}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ be defined by

$$
\mathcal{E} f:=\sum \psi_{j} *\left(\varphi_{j} * f\right)_{\Omega}
$$

Then $\|\mathcal{E} f\|_{\mathcal{C}^{s}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)} \leq C_{s}(\Omega)\|f\|_{\mathcal{C}^{s}(\Omega)}$ for $f \in C^{s}(\Omega)$.
Proof. (a) For any $g \in \mathcal{C}^{s}$ with $\left.g\right|_{\Omega}=f$, we have $\varphi_{j} * g=\varphi_{j} * f$ on $\Omega$. Thus $\sup 2^{j s}\left\|\varphi_{j} * f\right\|_{L^{\infty}(\Omega)}=\sup 2^{j s}\left\|\varphi_{j} * g\right\|_{L^{\infty}(\Omega)} \leq\|g\|_{\mathcal{C}^{s}}$. This shows that $\sup 2^{j s}\left\|\varphi_{j} *\right.$ $f \|_{L^{\infty}(\Omega)} \leq\|f\|_{\mathcal{C}^{s}(\Omega)}$.

To show the inequality in the other direction, it suffices to verify (b). Note that the estimate in the proof of Proposition A. 5 does not use the moment conditions on $\varphi_{k} * f$. Replacing the latter by $\left(\varphi_{k} * f\right)_{\Omega}$ and $\eta_{j}$ by $\varphi_{j}$, we get

$$
\begin{gathered}
\varphi_{j} * \mathcal{E} f(x)=\sum_{k} \varphi_{j} * \psi_{k} *\left(\varphi_{k} * f\right)_{\Omega}(x) \\
2^{j s}\left\|\varphi_{j} * \mathcal{E} f\right\|_{L^{\infty}} \leq C \sup 2^{k s}\left\|\left(\varphi_{k} * f\right)_{\Omega}\right\|_{L^{\infty}}
\end{gathered}
$$

We have verified $\|\mathcal{E} f\|_{\mathcal{C}^{s}} \leq \sup 2^{k s}\left\|\varphi_{k} * f\right\|_{L^{\infty}(\Omega)}$.
Theorem A. 7 ([6, Thm. 3.18]). Let $\infty>M>s>0$ and let $\Omega$ be a special Lipschitz domain in $\mathbb{R}^{n}$. Then for any $f \in \mathcal{C}^{s}(\Omega)$,

$$
\|f\|_{\mathcal{C}_{M}^{s}(\Omega)}:=\|f\|_{L^{\infty}(\Omega)}+\sup _{h, 0<|h| \leq 1}|h|^{-s}\left\|\Delta_{h}^{M} f\right\|_{L^{\infty}(\Omega)}
$$

is equivalent to $\|f\|_{\mathcal{C}^{s}(\Omega)}$. That is if $f \in \mathcal{C}^{s}(\Omega)$ then

$$
C_{s}^{-1}\|f\|_{\mathcal{C}^{s}(\Omega)} \leq\|f\|_{\mathcal{C}_{M}^{s}(\Omega)} \leq C_{s}\|f\|_{\mathcal{C}^{s}(\Omega)}
$$

where $C_{s}$ depends on only the Lipschitz norm of $\partial \Omega$.
Proof. Dispa computed $C_{s}$ via constants in Theorems 2.3 and 3.2 in [49].

A.2. Case of bounded Lipschitz domains. Let $\Omega$ be a relatively compact Lipschitz domain in $\mathbb{R}^{n}$. Let $M \subset \cup U_{j}$. Let $\left\{\chi_{j}\right\}$ be a partition of unity subordinate to the covering $\left\{U_{j}\right\}$. Then for a function $f$ on $\Omega$. We may assume that $\Omega \cap \operatorname{supp} \chi_{j}$ is contained in a special Lipschitz domain $\Omega_{j} \subset \mathbb{R}^{n}$ and $U_{j} \cap b \Omega \subset b \Omega_{j}$. Thus, $\chi_{j} f$ is defined on $\Omega_{j}$ by trivial extension of being 0 on $\Omega_{j} \backslash\left(\Omega \cap U_{j}\right)$. Define

$$
\|f\|_{\mathcal{C}^{s}(\Omega)}^{*}:=\max _{j}\left\|\chi_{j} f\right\|_{\mathcal{C}^{s}\left(\Omega_{j}\right)}, \quad\|f\|_{\mathcal{C}_{\mathcal{U}}^{s}(\Omega)}^{*}:=\max _{j}\left\|\chi_{j} f\right\|_{\mathcal{C}_{\mathcal{U}}^{s}\left(\Omega_{j}\right)}
$$

Then Theorem A. 7 implies that $\|\cdot\|_{\mathcal{C}^{s}(\Omega)}^{*}$ and $\|\cdot\|_{\mathcal{C}_{\mathcal{U}}^{s}(\Omega)}^{*}$ are equivalent.
Definition A. 8 ([6,49]). Let $D$ a bounded Lipschitz domain $\mathbb{R}^{n}$. Let $\mathcal{C}^{s}(\Omega)$ be the set of functions $f$ on $\Omega$ such that there is $\tilde{f} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$ such that $\tilde{f} \mid \Omega=f$. For $f \in \mathcal{C}^{s}(\Omega)$, define

$$
\|f\|_{C^{s}(\Omega)}=\inf \left\{\|\tilde{f}\|_{\mathcal{C}^{s}}: \tilde{f} \in \mathcal{C}^{s}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right), \tilde{f} \mid \Omega=f\right\}
$$

Finally, we mention that a classical theorem [1, Thm. 18.5, p. 65] says that when $s>0$ and $\Omega$ is bounded Lipschitz domain in $\mathbb{R}^{n}$, then $\|f\|_{\mathcal{C}_{\mathcal{U}}^{s}(\Omega)}^{*}<\infty$ implies that $f \in \mathcal{C}^{s}(\Omega)$, i.e. $f$ extends to a function in $\mathcal{C}^{s}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$.

Corollary A.9. Suppose that $s>0$. Theorem A. 7 holds when $\Omega$ is a bounded Liptschitz domain i.e.

$$
C_{s}^{-1}\|f\|_{C^{s}(\Omega)} \leq\|f\|_{\mathcal{C}_{\mathcal{U}}^{s}(\Omega)}^{*} \leq C_{s}\|f\|_{C^{s}(\Omega)}
$$

and $C_{s}$ depends only on the Liptschitz norm of $\partial \Omega$.
Proof. Fix $f \in C^{s}(\Omega)$. By definition, there is $\tilde{f} \in \mathcal{C}^{s}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ such that $\|\tilde{f}\|_{\mathcal{C}^{s}} \leq$ $2\|f\|_{C^{s}(\Omega)}$. On $\Omega$ we have $f=\sum \chi_{j} \tilde{f}$. Inductively, we can verify that

$$
\Delta_{h}^{M}(f \chi)(x)=\sum_{i, j, k} \sum_{j \leq i, j \leq M-k} C_{i, j, k} \Delta_{h}^{i} \tilde{f}(x+j h) \Delta_{h}^{M-i} \chi(x+k h)
$$

Therefore, $\left|\Delta_{h}^{M}(f \chi)(x)\right| \leq C_{s} \sum_{i, 0}^{M}|h|^{s-M+i}\left|\tilde{f}\right|_{\mathcal{C}^{s-i}}|h|^{M-i}\|\chi\|_{C^{M-i}}$. On $\mathbb{R}^{n}$, it is well-known that $\|\tilde{f}\|_{\mathcal{C}^{a}} \leq C_{a, b}\|\tilde{f}\|_{\mathcal{C}^{b}}$ for $a<b$. This shows that $\|f\|_{\mathcal{C}_{\mathcal{U}}^{s}(\Omega)}^{*} \leq$ $C_{s}\|\tilde{f}\|_{\mathcal{C}^{s}} \leq 2 C_{s}\|f\|_{\mathcal{C}^{s}(\Omega)}$.

For the other inequality, we start with

$$
\|f\|_{\mathcal{C}^{s}(\Omega)}=\left\|\sum \chi_{j} f\right\|_{\mathcal{C}^{s}(\Omega)} \leq \sum\left\|\chi_{j} f\right\|_{\mathcal{C}^{s}(\Omega)} \leq \sum\left\|\chi_{j} f\right\|_{\mathcal{C}^{s}\left(\Omega_{j}\right)}
$$

Let $\mathcal{E}_{j}$ be the Rychkov extension for $\Omega_{j}$. We have

$$
\mathcal{E}_{j}\left(\chi_{j} f\right)=\sum_{k} \psi_{j, k} *\left(\varphi_{j, k} *\left(\chi_{j} f\right)\right)_{\Omega_{j}}
$$

By Theorem A. 6 (b), we have $\left\|\chi_{j} f\right\|_{\mathcal{C}^{s}\left(\Omega_{j}\right)} \leq\left\|\mathcal{E}_{j}\left(\chi_{j} f\right)\right\|_{\mathcal{C}^{s}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)} \leq C_{s}\left\|\chi_{j} f\right\|_{\mathcal{C}^{s}\left(\Omega_{j}\right)}$. By Theorem A. 7 for special Lipschitz domains, we get $\left\|\chi_{j} f\right\|_{\mathcal{C}^{s}\left(\Omega_{j}\right)} \leq\left\|\chi_{j} f\right\|_{\mathcal{C}_{\mathcal{U}}^{s}\left(\Omega_{j}\right)}$. Hence $\|f\|_{C^{s}(\Omega)} \leq C_{s}\|f\|_{\mathcal{C}_{\mathcal{U}}^{s}(\Omega)}^{*}$.

abstract:
Let $M$ be a relatively compact $C^2$ domain in a complex manifold $\mathcal
M$ of dimension $n$. Assume that $H^{1}(M,\Theta)=0$ where $\Theta$ is the
sheaf of germs of holomorphic tangent fields of $M$. Suppose that the Levi-form
of the boundary of $M$ has at least 3 negative eigenvalues or at least $n-1$
positive eigenvalues pointwise. We first construct a homotopy formula for
$\Theta$-valued $(0,1)$-forms on $\overline M$. We then apply a Nash-Moser
iteration scheme to show that if a formally integrable almost complex structure
of the H\"{o}lder-Zygmund class $\Lambda^r$ on $\overline M$ is sufficiently
close to the complex structure on $ M$ in the H\"{o}lder-Zygmund norm
$\Lambda^{r_0}(\overline M)$ for some $r_0>5/2$, then there is a diffeomorphism
$F$ from $\overline M$ into $\mathcal M$ that transforms the almost complex
structure into the complex structure on $F(M)$, where $F \in \Lambda^s(M)$ for
all $s<r+1/2$.
